I took the prisoner—I laid hold of one of his hands—he put his other hand up to his mouth—I struck his hand—this other bad half-crown fell on the pavement—I took it up—the prisoner said, "Don't hold me too tight, I have not any more"—I searched him at the station, and found 3s. 4d. in good money on him, and a tobacco-box and a mackerel concealed under his jacket.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit, and both cast in one mould.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

1216.
ROBERT HASTWAYTE,
GEORGE REEVES , and
WIL
LIAM HASTWAYTE were indicted for
a like offence.

MART ADKINS . I am the wife of Thomas Fletcher Adkins, and keep the Royal Oak, in Margaret-street, Hackney-road. On Friday, the 29th of March, a little after ten o'clock, Robert Hastwayte and Reeves came to our house—they had half a quartern of gin—Reeves gave me a new sixpence—it was bad—I refused it, and said it was bad—Reeves said he was not aware of it, but he knew where he took it—he put it into his pocket, on which Robert Hastwayte said, "You are a nice fellow, to come here to treat me, and offer a bad sixpence"—Robert Hastwayte paid me for the gin with 2d., and then they left the house.

MARY KERSCHNER . I am the wife of George Frederick Kerschner, of the Carpenters' Arms, Ann's-place, Hackney-road. At half-past nine o'clock, on the 29th of March, Reeves and Robert Hastwayte came to our house to-gether—Robert Hastwayte asked for half a quartern of gin—I served him—he gave me a new sixpence—I gave him 4d. change—both of them drank part of the gin—I put the sixpence into the till—there was another sixpence in the till with a hole pierced in it—I had noticed it a few minutes before—I gave the sixpence I received from Robert Hastwayte to Mr. Grafton.

MART ANN AMBROSE . I am the wife of David Ambrose, of the King's Arms, Ann's-place, Hackney-road, near the Carpenters' Arms. On the 29th of March, about a quarter to ten o'clock at night, Robert Hastwayte and Reeves came, in—Robert Hastwayte asked for half a quartern of gin, he gave me a shilling, I gave him 10d.—they drank the greater part of the gin, and left the rest—I did not much like the look of the shilling—I put it into the till—there were four sixpences, and a very old shilling of George the Fourth, and a lion on the reverse side—soon after I took the shilling which the pri
soner gave me out of the till—I am sure it was the same—I bit it, and found it was bad—I put it into the till again by itself—I gave it to Boyd about a quarter of an hour afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. From whom did you receive the George the Fourth shilling? A. I do not know—I had cleared the till about five minutes before—I noticed the one very particularly, because it was the only one with a lion on it—there were five or six shillings, but I had noticed that one when I first took it—I took up the other money, and put it into the bar parlour—I saw two gentlemen at Worship-street—I did not see any one from the Mint before I gave evidence.
JOHN BOYD (police-constable N 15.) I received this counterfeit shilling from Ambrose.

JAMES ROBERT GRAFTON , appraiser. I was in the Carpenters' Arms—I saw Robert Hastwayte and Reeves there drinking gin—they left the house, I followed them—I saw them join William Hastwayte, about twenty yards off—Robert Hastwayte and Reeves crossed, and went into the King's Arms, and William went on and stood at the corner of a turning—I went into a garden—I walked down, and William left the corner where he was—I thought he was going to run away—I went and secured him—I saw him raise his arm, and in chucking his arm out, he passed a paper over the wall—immediately the po
liceman received him, I went over the wall and picked up the paper, which contained eight shillings and six sixpences—I also got one sixpence from Kerschner—I gave them all to Dubois.
HENRY WILLIAM DUBOIS . 1 produce a paper, containing eight counterfeit shillings, and six counterfeit sixpences, which I got from Grafton.

MR. FIELD. I have examined the whole of the money, it is all counter
feit—the shillings are all cast in one mould, and the sixpences are also cast in one mould.

CHARLES EAST . I saw Robert Hastwayte and Reeves at the Royal Oak—about three minutes after they left, I followed them from the Royal Oak, and saw William meet them before they went to the Carpenter's Arms.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you see them? A. After they came out of the Oak—I followed them down Margaret-street to Ann's-place—I after
wards saw them turn back, and go in a different direction to me—I did not see them go into the Carpenter's Arms, but I peeped through the door, and saw Robert Hastwayte and Reeves in there—I did not see William till I came back—I then went home, and disguised myself, and went through the garden of the Carpenter's Arms.
GEORGE PETER LUTZ (police-constable N 104.) I searched William at a quarter past ten o'clock on Friday evening—I found on him 1s. 2l., in copper, and some sand and straw.

ROBERT HASTWAYTE—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

REEVES—
GUILTY . Aged 32

WM. HASTWAYTE—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

1217.
JOHN GREEVES was indicted
for a like offence.

HENRY CHARLES PARKER . I am servant to William Williams, of the Rose and Crown, in Oxford-street. On the 16th of March, at ten minutes past eight o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came for a pint of porter—it came to 1 1/2 d.—he gave me 1s.—I put it into the till where there was only a sixpence and a fourpenny-piece—I am sure of that—in about three minutes I looked at the shilling, and observed it was bad—I put it on the stove in the bar—about a quarter before ten the prisoner came again for a pint of beer, and gave me a shilling—I knew him again—I went into the counting-house and gave it to John Goodwin, who came out, and the prisoner ran away—I had not said anything to him, but Williams had told Goodwin to give him in charge.

JOHN GOODWIN . I received a shilling from. Parker. I went into the bar—the prisoner was standing there drinking porter—he ran away—I put the «hilling on the stove—I went after the prisoner, and saw him taken, I then took the two shillings off the stove, and put them into my pocket—I gave the same two shillings to the inspector.
WILLIAM M'BEAN (police-constable C 130.) I was present when the money was given to the inspector—he left it on the desk while he entered
the charge, and then he gave the money to me—I saw it on the desk all the time—this is it.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. I had just sold two ropes of onions; I ran out to see if I could catch the man to get him to come back, as they said it was bad; I thought I could get the onions back.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Six Months

1218.
THOMAS SMITH was indicted
for a like offence.

CASPAR DINCKELL . I am shopman to George Miller Galley, grocer and cheesemonger, Oxford-street, Mile-end. The prisoner came to me on the 27th of March, and asked for 14lbs. weight of coals, which came to 2d., and a halfpenny-worth of wood—he gave me a half-crown—I gave him 2s. 3 1/2, change—I put the half-crown into my pocket—I had no other silver there—I gave it directly to Mr. Kelly—a little after eight, on the 6th of April, the prisoner came again for a halfpenny-worth of wood, and gave me a hilling—I gave him change, and put the shilling into my mouth—I knew it—was a bad one, and showed the shilling to my master—he gave it me back—it was not out of my sight—I afterwards gave it to the policeman—I followed the prisoner three streets round—I could not run any further—I was obliged to call out, "Stop thief "—my master heard my voice, and ran out, and caught him—I have seen a halfpenny which the policeman showed me—I told him it was mine.
Prisoner. Q. How can you swear that I gave you the half-crown unless you marked it? A. I marked it before—I had only one half-crown in my pocket.

GEORGE MILLER GALLEY . I am Dinckell's master. I received a half crown on the 27th of March—I put it into a drawer away from all other money—I kept it in the drawer till the man came again on Saturday night, when I gave it to the policeman—it was the one I got from Dinckell—on Sa
turday, the 6th of April, I was standing at my shop door—Dinckell brought. me a shilling—I saw it was had—he said, "Never mind," and ran to the corner of the street—I ran after him—the prisoner went up one street, and down another, and hid himself behind a back gate—I called for assistance—a man came, and we took him out of the court—he was fumbling about, and put his hand to his mouth—I called the other person to hold his hand, but it was too late—he had been talking some time before he put his hand to his mouth, and then he was silent for some time.

WILLIAM NICOL (police-constable K 177.) On the 6th of April I got the half-crown and shilling—I searched the prisoner, and found 7 1/2 d. in copper in one pocket, and this halfpenny in the other—I asked Dinckell if he would know any of the halfpence—he said, "Yes, there was one with a hole in it" MR. JOHN FIELD. These are both counterfeit.

CASPAR DINCKELL
re-examined. I gave the prisoner the halfpenny with a hole in it on the 6th of April.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

1219.
SARAH ANIGER was indicted
for stealing 1 gown, value 2l. 2 shawls, 30s.; 1 scarf, 10s.; and 1 handkerchief, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Cocks: 2 sovereigns, 7 shillings, 2 sixpences, and 15l. Bank note; the monies of
Henry Cocks, in the dwelling-house of
John Cocks.

HENRY COCKS . I live with my father, John Cocks, in Frederick-place, Stepney. On the 12th of March my parents were out—I went out at seven o'clock that evening, and returned a little after nine—the prisoner was in my father's service—about twenty minutes to twelve that night he came down.

and said she heard an alarm, and that there were thieves in the house—I was playing at cards, waiting for my father and mother to come home—we went up stairs, and, on a chest near the staircase-window, I saw a bundle—the window was open seven or eight inches—I then went into the chamber, and saw a bundle there—we went up stairs, and found the drawer the money was contained in was locked, the other drawer adjoining it was open—I could not get my key into the lock—I came down again—the policeman was with me—he said the sergeant would be round in an hour—when he came we went up, and he got the escutcheon off the lock, and we got it open—there had been 9l. 10s. in the drawer—there was a 5l. Bank note—I had seen it safe about eleven in the day—they were all gone in the evening, except two sovereigns and 2s.—there was a 5l. note gone, two sovereigns, and 8s. in silver—there did not appear to have been any force used—I found no thieves in the house—some money has been found in the fire by my sister—nothing has been missed but the money.
ELIZABETH COCKS . On the Sunday morning after the 12th of March I stirred the kitchen-fire, and two sovereigns and 6s. 6d. fell out of the fire.

MARGARET COCKS . On Tuesday, the 12th of March, the prisoner asked leave to go out to get some rushlights—there was no person in the house but our own family—my brother was out, and my father and mother dined out—a little before twelve o'clock that night the prisoner came and beckoned me out, and said she heard a noise in my mother's bed-room, as though a chair or a bar from the window had fallen down—I was much alarmed, and went into the parlour to my brother—he went up, and did not discover anything, but when the second policeman came, a gown and other things were missed from a top room—on the Saturday night I emptied the waste-paper out of the candle-box—my sister lighted the fire on Sunday morning, and about twenty minutes after she stirred the fire, that lighted the paper, and the money was discovered—she ran out with the hot money in her hand—I took the 1s. 6d. from the fire—I discovered four different sorts of paper burning—one was very thin, as if it were the embers of a 5l., note.

HENRY MILSTEAD (police-constable K 208.) I went to the house—I went up stairs, and saw two drawers open in Mr. Cocks's bed-room—I did not see any marks of violences—they must have been opened by a key—I examined the window and doors—it did not appear that any one came in that way—I went into young Mr. Cocks's room—he said, "My money is all in this drawer, it is all right, but the escutcheon loose, and I can't get the key in"—I took a knife, and got it off—he got the drawer open, and missed the money—the prisoner was sitting on the bed in the room—I said, "This appears like an in-doors robbery"—she said, "I hope you are not going to accuse me"—she was given into custody—none of the gowns and things had been removed out of the house—it did not appear to me that any one had entered the house at all—the shutters were open, and the bar was down, which must have been opened inside.

Prisoners Defence. My young mistress sent me out four times in the course of the morning; I then went down into the kitchen, looked in the candle-box and found there were no rush-lights; I asked if I should fetch them; I was gone about five minutes; I sat down to needle-work, and soon after I heard a noise at the back kitchen door; I went up to the parlour and told my young mistress; I then sat down in the shop, and about ten minutes after we all went with a light into the yard and saw nothing; she told me to go to Cottage-grove and fetch her brother; he was not there; I returned between eight and nine o'clock; about an hour after he came with a gentle
man, and jokingly said it was only my young man trying to get in; between

twelve and one o'clock I heard a noise like a chair falling; I went to the par
lour; we went up stairs; mistress's bed-room window opened on the leads, and on the box was a bundle; in the passage was another bundle, and in another room another bundle; in the attic we found another bundle, and one of the drawers out of the chest was on the bed; I went with the policeman to the station next day; I was remanded, to know if I had changed the note.

HENRY COCKS
re-examined. I have heard that a young man visits the prisoner—I never saw him.

HENRY MILSTEAD
re-examined. She went to the station about a quarter to four o'clock.

MARGARET COCKS
re-examined. On the Saturday night I emptied the paper from the candle-box under the grate, and on the Sunday morning my sister threw it on the fire—there was such a quantity as these sovereigns might be wrapped up in and not drop out—my father is a plumber—we sometimes have five men and sometimes twenty men, but they have no business at the candle-box, which is kept in the beer-cellar—she could go to the cellar before the policeman came—she was out of the room several times.
NOT GUILTY .

1220.
CHARLES WOODS was indicted
for stealing 1 crown, 2 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Henry Bennett.

ELIZA ANN BENNETT . I am the wife of Henry Bennett, baker, Com
mercial-terrace, Kensington. About twelve o'clock, on the 25th of March, I was sitting at the back of my shop, and heard a noise—I went and found the prisoner behind the counter on his hands and knees—he got up—I saw the till open, and missed a five shilling piece—he was stopped and taken to the station, and the money found on him—I afterwards found about 4s. more gone from another part of the till.

DANIEL EVANS (police-constable T 176.) The prisoner was brought to the station—I searched him, and asked if he had anything—he said, no—I heard something rattle, and found inside the lining of his waistcoat, a crown
piece, two half-crowns, two shillings, and a sixpence—there was a little hole made in the sleeve of his waistcoat on purpose.
Prisoner. I beg for mercy.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Three Months.

1221.
ANN HARRINGTON was indicted
for stealing 1 jacket, value 10s., the goods of
Henry Richards.

HENRY RICHARDS . At half-past ten o'clock on the 19th of March, I went into the prisoner's house to see a shipmate—I went into an upper room, and bad a glass of gin from the prisoner—I laid down for half-an-hour—when I awoke I missed my jacket—I went down and charged her with stealing it—she said, "Come out, and have a glass of gin or rum out of the money"—I went with her about 100 yards off, and saw an officer, and gave her in charge—she and another female struck me.

THOMAS BARRETT . I produce this jacket, which was pawned by the pri
soner on the 19th of March.

WILLIAM PARAMORE (police-constable K 51.) I heard a disturbance—the prosecutor had the prisoner by her arm—he said, "Take this woman, she has got my jacket"—she said, "He has got the ticket," and I found the ticket in his hat—she struck him on the cheek, and said, "Take that."

Prisoner's Defence. He gave me the jacket to pledge for 8s.; he soon spent the money in drink; the next morning he came and brought the same jacket which he had redeemed the night before, and asked me to pawn it, which I did, for 10s.; he then began drinking rum at half-a-pint at a time.

HENRY RICHARDSON
re-examined. She put the ticket into my hand just after I came out—I laid in the bed with one of the women the night before,—I did not give her the jacket to pawn, but she pawned it—I took it out the night before, and said nothing about it—I had given her 4s.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Months

1222.
ANN TURNER was indicted
for stealing 18 yards of printed calico, value 10s., the goods of
Joseph Norberry; and that she had been be
fore convicted of felony.

JOHN ADAMS . I am shopman to Joseph Norbury, of Crawford-street, Brunswick-square. On the 26th of March I missed a piece of calico from outside the shop—it is my master's—I had seen it safe the same day.

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX (police-constable E 49.) I produce the calico. On the 26th of March I saw the prisoner with another girl, in Oxford-street—the prisoner had this calico wrapped up in her apron—I asked where she got it—she said, "What is that to you?"—I said, "You know me?"—she said, "Yes"—she said it was a piece of print she had bought of a woman—before the Magistrate she said she bought it of a woman in Oxford-street.

WILLIAM MILLERMAN (police-constable B 95.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Guildhall at Westmin
ster—(read)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1223.
JAMES OSBORNE was indicted
for stealing 8lbs. weight of pork, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Stephen Banks; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY STEPHEN BANKS , tripe-dresser, Church-street, Bethnal-green. About ten o'clock on the 16th of March, I saw the prisoner come and steal a pig's head from my window—I ran and stopped him—he dropped it.
Prisoner. I was walking down the street; he collared me, and said, "You have got my pig's head;" he took me a little way, and found it in a bag.
Witness. He had put it into a bag; he was running, and dropped it at his feet.
JOHN BRADDICK (police-constable R 64.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY .** Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1224.
THOMAS PARKER was indicted
for stealing 2 shillings, the mo
nies of
John Costello.

JOHN COSTELLO , labourer, Robert-street, Mill-wall, Poplar. I was in bed on the morning of the 18th of March, and heard money jingle on the floor—I awoke, and found the prisoner by the side of my bed, with my jacket in his hand, and the money falling out—2s. 6d. fell out on the floor—he gave me 6d.—he said, "This is my money"—I said, "It is not"—I got up, and the two shillings were gone—more men slept in the room, but they were gone—I had no time to send for an officer then, but gave him in charge at dinner time the same day.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. He was your bed-fellow, was he not? A. Yes; his clothes were on the top of the bed, and mine at the side—I had 4s. 6d. in my pocket at first, but after I had 2s. 6d. in silver, and some halfpence in my coat pocket—he did not shake my waistcoat pocket and hold it up to me—he asked what money I had in my pocket—I said 4s. 6d., and then some money fell, and he said 2s. of it was his.
CHARLES BUSHNELL (police-constable K 263.) The prosecutor came and
told me the prisoner had stolen 2s.—I went and took him, and found two half-crowns and 2s. 1d. on him.

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Three Month.

1225.
EMMA DRIVER was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of stockings, value 6 1/2 d., the goods of
Mary Ann Howse; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

ALBERT MOORE . I am shopman to Mary Ann Howse, of Whitechapel. On the 16th of March the prisoner and another girl came for tome black flowers, and as they were going out I saw the prisoner take a pair of stock-ings off some cambric at the door—I overtook her—I said, "Where are the stockings?" she said she had none, but as I took her back they dropped from her at the door.
Prisoner. The other girl took them, not me. Witness. I am sure the prisoner took them.
RICHARD THORPE (police-constable R 155.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1226.
MATILDA GREEN and
ANN CHAPMAN were indicted for
stealing 1 shawl, value 20s., the goods of
Lawrence Dillon.

FREDERICK LILLIY . I am in the service of William King and Spencer Lee, of Mary-street, Hampstead-road. This shawl was pledged for 8s. by Green, between four and fire o'clock, on the 26th of March—there was a female with her, who I could not swear to.

LAWRENCE DILLON . I live in Red-lion-court, Saffron-hill. About ten o'clock, on the 26th of March, I and my wife went out, leaving the prisoners and a little boy there—my box was locked, and this shawl in it—I came home at half-past five o'clock in the evening—the boy was crying on the stairs—the shawl was gone, and the prisoners too—I looked after the pri
soners, and met them just against the Regent's-barracks, talking to a young man—Chapman gave me the ticket of the shawl, and told me she was very sorry, she had nothing to do with it, further than Green giving her the ticket.

LAWRENCE DILLON , junior. I was left in the room with the prisoners—Green chucked me down stairs—I was sitting on the stairs—I heard the box break, and heard a hammering—I cried out and said, "The box is broke"—the prisoners ran down—I went into the room, and the box was broken.

Green's Defence. I did not intend to steal it, but I wanted a little money to purchase some food; Chapman knew nothing of it; the prosecutrix said she would not hurt us if we would give up the ticket; I told Chapman to give it to her.

LAWRENCE DILLON
re-examined. I did not say so—I believe my wife did.

GREEN—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

CHAPMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

1227.
MARY ANN SMITH and
ANN JONES were indicted for
stealing 9 veils, value 15s., the goods of
Digory Northy and another.

EDWARD THOMAS . I am in partnership with Digory Northy, a laceman, in Whitechapel. About half-past five o'clock, on the 13th of March, the prisoners came in—Smith asked for a shawl—I showed her one—it did not suit her—some other customers came in—I said if it did not suit she must leave it—I threw it on a box—Smith went to the veils—I saw the drawer was disturbed—they were going out—I went to the step and took Jones—I found on her nine veils—I secured her, and ran after Smith, who had ran about
a hundred yards—I took her—the shawl they looked at was worth 7s. 6d.—there was only 1s. and a few halfpence found on them.
Smith's Defence. I was going to pay a deposit.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 17. JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

1228.
JANE TURNER was indicted
for stealing 1 blanket, value 2s. 1 shawl, 1s.; 1 apron, 4d.; 1 pincushion, 2d.; 1 handkerchief, 4d.; and 1 comb, 2d.; the goods of
George Pearce.

JANE PEARCE . I am the wife of George Pearce, of Chapel-street, New-road, Paddington. I am a laundress—the prisoner is my daughter—I left her at home on the 19th of March to take care of the house—when I returned she had taken all her own clothes and some bedding for herself, and other things, these now produced are them—I have three children by my first husband.
CHARLES JOSEPH , pawnbroker. I have a shawl pawned by a companion of the prisoner, named Mary Nicholls—she is about seventeen—I have known her a long time.
Prisoner. I beg my mother's pardon.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Ten Days Solitary.

1229.
GEORGE BARRATT was indicted
for stealing 1 dead fowl, value 2s. 6d., the property of
William Roberts.

LYDIA ALFXANDRINA ROBERTS . I am the wife of William Roberts. I had a dead fowl—I saw it safe about five minutes before the police
man arrived.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was there any body in the shop but you? A. I was in the parlour—I had six fowls, and the other five were all safe—I could swear to this by that tear—it made the fowl of less value.

CHARLES ATKINS (police-constable S 91.) I found the prisoner with the fowl at Kilburn—I asked where he got it—he said he brought it from Willes
don—a man gave it to him there—he was about 150 yards from the prosecutor's.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

1230.
WILLIAM COOK and
CHARLES LOTTY were indicted for
stealing on the 19th of March, 23 telescopes, value 2l. 17s. 6d., the goods of
John Cetta: and
THOMAS ROBERT MOORE
for feloniously receiving 11 telescopes, part of the same, well knowing them to have been stolen.

JOHN CETTA , telescope-maker, Brook-street, Holborn. I missed these teles
copes on the 20th of March—they might have been gone a day or two—these are them.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is their value? A. About half-a-crown a piece—I had every reason to suspect one of my servants at first, and that servant told me on the 20th of March, that Cook and Lotty did it, that he had seen them outside the shop.

GEORGE EATON . I am the prosecutor's shop-boy—on the morning of the 19th of March, I had seen Cook and Lotty outside the window for about one minute—I am sure they are the persons—there were three parcels of teles
copes there then—they looked all full—I missed them the next morning—there was a pane of glass broken that they were near to.

THOMAS ARCHER (police-constable G 8.) I apprehended Lotty on the 22nd—I charged him with stealing telescopes from the prosecutor's window—he said he did not steal them, that he saw Cook and another boy standing against the window, he saw Cook put his hand in, take them out, and give them to another boy, they asked him to go to a chandler's shop on Clerkenwell-green,

and they sold them to a shop
keeper—I then took Cook—he said Eaton gave them to him, and told him his master had given them to him for good conduct—I then took him to the station—he said that Moore was the man he had sold them to—I went to Moore's, and asked him if he had bought any telescopes within the last two or three days—he said, "No"—I said, "I am certain you have, and I have a witness outside that can prove it—he said, opening a chest," "Here are four"—I said, "You have more than that"—he said, "I do not know how many I bought, if you will allow me to look in my book, I will tell you"—he said he bought eleven—he then said he bought one for 10d.; then six for 3s. 7 1/2 d.; and four for 1s. 10d.—I know Mr. Greenwood's handwriting, this is it (deposition read.)—"The prisoner Cook says, they were brought to me by Lotty, he said he wanted to sell them; on Clerken well-green a boy met Lotty, and told him where he could sell them; we went to Moore's; I sold them to Moore.—Lotty says, it is false; I saw Cook take them out; I did not know what was in them; he asked me to go with him to Turn mill-street.—Moore says, I did not know the value of them, or that they were stolen."
Cross-examined. Q. Does not Moore keep a marine-store shop? A. No, he is a general dealer, he sells cheese, butter, and sweet things for children.

GEORGE EATON
re-examined. I did not give any telescopes to Cook—I spoke to him that morning.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

COOK—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Six Months.

LOTTY—
NOT GUILTY .

MOORE—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Year.

1231.
JOHN PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing 1 flannel shirt, value 3s., the goods of
Edward Richard Blaker, in a vestel in a port of entry and discharge.

EDWARD RICHARD BLAKER . I am second mate of the steam ship Ma
jestic, in the West India Docks. Last Thursday night I took my shirts on shore—the prisoner was a seaman—on the following Tuesday I missed a shirt, and on the Wednesday I found it on the prisoner's back—he would not give it to me—I gave him in charge—he had no business with it—he must have taken it out of my cabin—he said he bought it in Rosemary-lane—I had pulled it off my back the Thursday night before—it has "G. D." on it, and it is my wife's marking.

CHARLES HASELTINE . I took the prisoner, and told him to deliver up the shirt—he said, "I shall not"—the prosecutor said it was marked "G. D. No. l"—the prisoner said he bought it in Rosemary-lane of a Jew on the Sunday morning—he did not want me to go to the man he bought it of.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it on Saturday night for 9s.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Two Months.

1232.
ELLEN GALVIN was indicted
for stealing 1 boa, value 1l.; 1 handkerchief, 1s.; 1 shift, 3s.; 1 petticoat, 2s.; and 1 pair of earrings, 4s.; the goods of
Mary Pack.
MARY PACK . I am in the service of Thomas Downing, of Sloane-street, Chelsea. The prisoner was cook—after she was gone I missed a boa, a crape handkerchief, a shift, and a petticoat—these are them.

WILLIAM THOMAS CASTLES , pawnbroker. These articles were pledged on different days—I do not know the prisoner as pawning them, but I know her as coming to the shop—these are the duplicates I gave of them.
ROBERT M'KENZIE (police-constable B 44.) I took the prisoner—she

gave her address No. 7, George-street—I went to a house in Paradise-walk, and found a box—I took it to the station, and asked her if it was her a—she said "Yes"—I found these duplicates and this crape handkerchief in it.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1233.
CHARLOTTE SMART was indicted
for stealing 1 shirt, value 3s.; and 1 blanket, 3s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Molero.

ELIZABETH MOLERO . I am a widow, and live in Pimlico. The prisoner occupied a furnished apartment in my house—she came on the 1st of Feb., and on the 17th of March I missed a sheet, blanket, and a great many things from my son's bed-room—these are them.
RICHARD M'KENZIE (police-constable B 44.) I took the prisoner—she gave me these duplicates with several others.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Six Months.

1234.
JAMES BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 shirt, value 3s.; 2 pairs of stockings, 2s.; 1 stock, 1s.; 3 collars, 1s. 6d.; 7 handkerchiefs, 5s.; and 5 shirt fronts, 5s.; the goods of
Susan Creech, from the person of
John Creech.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Daniel Clark.

JOHN CREECH . I live with my mother, Susan Creech, a laundress, in Walmer-street, Bryanston-square. On the 30th of March I was taking a bundle of clothes home—I got to Cavendish-street, when the prisoner snatched them out of my hand—I hallooed "Stop thief"—he saw some one after him, and threw it down—I took it up—this is the bundle—it contained clean clothes—he was immediately stopped—I am sure he is the man.

RICHARD PAGE WOOD . I was in Cavendish-street, and saw the prisoner running, and Creech after him—I stopped him, and held him till the police
man took him—he had thrown the bundle away.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

1235.
SARAH GRAHAM was indicted
for stealing 1 tame fowl, price 2s., the property of
William Ainslie.

ISABELLA AINSLIE . I am the wife of William Ainslie. On the 1st of April Connaly brought a fowl to me partly plucked—it was mine—I had it about nine months, and had seen it about three minutes before—the prisoner had come in a few minutes before for half a pint of beer.

CATHERINE CONNALY . I am servant to the prosecutor. The prisoner came in—I said, "What have you?"—she said, "Nothing"—I said, "Yes you have"—she said "No"—I said, "Yes, you have; I must see"—I lifted up her shawl, and she let the fowl fall on the floor—I took it to my mistress—it was half dead.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Two Months.

1236.
ELIZABETH TATE was indicted
for stealing 2 petticoats, value 3s., the goods of
John Grant and others.

WILLIAM THOMAS CASTLES . I am shopman to John Grant and others, pawnbrokers, Knightsbridge. On the 29th of March the prisoner entered our shop with another person, and while there she pulled down two petticoats, and placed them under her shawl—I mentioned it to an officer who was in the shop, and he took them from her.

ROBERT M'KENZIE (police-constable B 44.) I was in the shop—I heard the string break—I looked round, and saw the prisoner putting these petti
coats under her shawl—I took them from her.
Prisoners Defence. I was looking at the petticoats when the string broke.

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Two Months.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
1237.
JAMES THOROGOOD was indicted
for stealing 1 stove bottom, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Lynch; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

1238.
JOHN WARD was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM OLIVE THOMAS . I am store-clerk at Messrs. John Letton's, Elliott, and others' brewery, at Pimlico. and was so in Aug., 1642—our regular men have certain wages, and when they are absent we employ the extra men—an allowance of wages is paid to the extra men, and the rest goes as a gra
tuity to the invalid—the prisoner was an extra man—I had employed him about fifteen months—I prepared a puncheon of porter and three barrels of ale, to be sent to Mr. Gillingham, of Norwood—while I had employed the prisoner I had sent him with ale and porter to our customers, and he received the money, and accounted to me—I made out the invoice, and banded it to Major, our salesman—this is it, and this is the receipt I made out, as usual—this other paper is a return note, to be signed by the customer, that the goods have been received—the prisoner should account to me for the money, or, in my absence, to Major—on the 6th of August be did not account to me for 9l. 14s. 2d., received from Mr. Gillingham—I did not see him any more; from that day, till I saw him in the London Docks, on the 15th of March this year—he has never accounted to me for this money.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Does not the regular man pay the extra man? A. Not in all cases—I engaged the prisoner shortly after he came—he worked a day or two without my permission, and then I engaged him—I did not make an agreement with him for this particular job—I believe he had constant work at that time, and, to the best of my belief, for a month previous—there is a man named Geary in our employ—it was not Geary's place to employ the extra men.
MR. DOANE. Q. If any number of regular men are absent, you take on the same number of extra, men? A. Yes—it is not the duty of an extra man to take the work of any particular man.

RICHARD THOMAS MAJOR . I am cellarman, in the employ of the prose
cutors. On the 6th of Aug., 1842, the prisoner was employed to carry out porter and ale to Mr. Gilling
ham's—there were two other draymen going out at the same time, to other places—Mr. Thomas produced an invoice—I saw it on the desk—I delivered it to Geary, who was foreman of the three men who were to carry out beer—the prisoner did not account to me for, 9l. 14s. 2d., from Mr. Gillingham—he has never accounted to me for that—I never saw him again till he was taken.
Cross-examined. Q. Were the other two extra or regular men? A. One was a regular man and the other an extra man—Geary drove a dray.

ROBERT GEARY . I am the prosecutors' drayman. On the 6th of Aug., 1842, I was in their service—some beer was sent out by three draymen—I received the invoice from Mr. Major, for some ale and porter to Mr. Gilling
ham—the prisoner took the beer to Gillingham—I delivered him the proper: invoice—the other man and me went together to other jobs.

HENRY GILLINGHAM . I live at Norwood—I had a quantity of porter and ale, on the 6th of August, 1842, from Elliott's—the prisoner brought in the beer—I paid him 9l. 14s. 2d. for it—he signed the receipt with his initials, and left it with me.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you recollect him at all? A. Yes—I saw him put these initials J. W. on the paper—I believe it was in the evening.
MR. DOANE. Q. What did you do with the invoice and the receipt? A. I put them on the file—they sent for them, and I gave them back.

THOMAS BENJAMIN WALKER (police-inspector.) In consequence of in
formation I went on the 15th of March to the London Docks, and saw the prisoner—I asked if he had ever worked for Elliott's, the brewers, at Pimlico—he said, "No"—I said, "Well if you did, here is a gentleman here at hand who will know you"—I then took him to Mr. Thomas, and said, "This gentleman charges you with having absconded from the brewery after having received money on account of Messrs. Elliott, is that so?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "How was it?"—he said, "I got too much to drink, I lost the money, and was ashamed to return."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

1239.
WILLIAM SMITH and
JAMES WILLIAMS were indicted for
stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 12 sovereigns, 8 shillings, and 3 sixpences; the property of
Charlotte Kings Mill, from her person.

CHARLOTTE KINGS MILE . I am a widow, living in Guilford-street, Rus
sell-square. On the 9th of Feb. I left home at nine o'clock in the morning—I was in Liquor pond-street, and saw a person named Beard—in consequence of something I was told I searched my pocket, and missed my purse and money.
(The other witness did not appear.)
NOT GUILTY .

1240.
HENRY NORMAN was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN WILLIAMS . I am servant to Mr. Woodward, a news agent, in Bull's Head-court. The prisoner was in the "Magnet" newspaper office, in the Strand—on the 22nd of March I paid him 2l. 7s. 6d. for six quires and nine "Magnet" newspapers, on the prosecutor's account.

HENRY HALL . I am in the service of Mr. Brooks, a news agent, in War
wick-square. On the 21st of March I went to the "Magnet" newspaper office, in the Strand, and saw the prisoner—I paid him 3l. 5s. for eight quires and eighteen "Magnets"—I got this receipt from him.

JOSEPH HARRISON . I am in the service of Mr. Thomas, news agent, Finch-lane, Cornhill. On the 22nd of March I went to the "Magnet" office—I saw the prisoner, and paid him 2l. 7s. 6d. for six quires and nine copies of the "Magnet."

JOHN BROWN BELL . I am the proprietor of the "Magnet" newspaper, in the Strand. The prisoner was in my employ in March, and had been two or three years, as clerk and publisher of my newspaper—it was part of his duty to receive money when persons came for newspapers—when he received money from the agents it was his duty to enter it in the daily cash-book, which I have here—it was his duty to pay me every day as I might require it—I do not find any entry of 8l. 5s. from Mr. Brooks, of Warwick-square, on the 21st of March—if he has received that money he has not paid it to me or accounted for it, except stating in a memorandum that he had received these monies, and had not accounted for them—that memorandum he sent on Saturday, the 22nd—I do not find any entries on the 22nd of March for 2l. 7s. 6d. from Woodward, or 2l. 7s. 6d. from Thomas—the prisoner has paid no such sum or accounted for them, except as I have stated—he left on Friday, the 22nd, and had no opportunity of making any entries afterwards—I desired him to make up his account, and I would have nothing more to do with him as a servant—I took his money away, and had some strong suspicion

that he had not accounted for various sums—he said, "I will let yon know in the morning"—I said, "Depend upon it I shall prosecute you, you may send your account"—he sent his account by his wife in the morning—he ab
sented himself, but be came to my house on the following Wednesday, and I sent for an officer.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was his duty defined and the mode specified in a written agreement? A. No—we bad no written agree
ment connected with the payment to be made to him—I had a security for monies—I do not know whether be came to me for the purpose of surrender
ing himself—he was there when I came home—his brother became security for any defalcation of his—he had a regular salary, no per centage on the papers sold—on the 22nd of March be made up his book, and paid me a ba
lance of 18l. 15s.—he had been in the habit of accounting for the money every day—I said, "Is this all the money you have got?"—he hesitated, then put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out 30s. more—I said, "Is there any more?"—he said, "I will let you know in the morning"—I said I should prosecute him—this is the memorandum he supplied me with—it accounts for these sums, and there are several others—I was not aware of these sums then.
NOT GUILTY .

1241.
WILLIAM RATCLIFFE was indicted
for stealing 1 card-case, value 15s., the goods of
Thomas Wilkinson, his master.

WILLIAM JAMES LAUGHTON . I am apprentice to Thomas Wilkinson, iron
monger, Regent-street—the prisoner was his apprentice. This card-case is my master's property—it has never been sold, because it is not in a finished state—it was in a glass case on the table in our warehouse—I do not know when it was lost.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. There was a good deal of valuable property there? A. Yes—the prisoner and I used to sit together, and drink and smoke—this case is not lined inside—I am certain I did not give it to him—I will swear I did not sell it—we have a porter and another young man.
WILLIAM THOMAS CASTLES , pawnbroker, at Knightsbridge. This card-case was pawned on the 13th of Feb., by a woman.

RICHARD MACKENZIE (police-constable B 44.) I was at Queen-square police-office, before Mr. Burrell, on the 30th of March—I saw two females charged with felony—the prisoner was there—he came to me and claimed two waistcoats and this card-case, which he said he had purchased of a young man named Lowndes, and he had given it to his aunt, Mrs. Tate, to pawn—I had found the duplicate of this card-case on the woman Tate.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he bought it of a young man at Mr. Wilkinson's, in Regent-street? A. Yes—I got the card-case from the pawnbroker—it was produced before the prisoner at the office—he was in the dock at the time—he was taken on the 4th of April—on the 30th of March he said he had given it to his aunt—I had the ticket in my hand that day, and he saw it—I believe his aunt was a washerwoman—the prisoner lives at Knightsbridge—he said nothing when the card-case was produced.
NOT GUILTY .

1242.
GEORGE BROWN and
JAMES ANDERSON were indicted for
stealing 1 firkin, value 1s.; and 84lbs. weight of butter, 3l. 3s.; the goods of
Thomas Searle: and that they had both been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE TURNEY . I am in the service of Thomas Searle, a carrier, be
tween Hounslow and London. On the afternoon of the 28th of March, I took up five firkins of butter at Trinity-lane, to take to William Stacey, at Hounslow—there were two firkins on the outside, and three in the cart—the

outside ones were fastened with a chain and a rope—about eight o'clock that evening I was passing through Knightsbridge—before I got to Kensington turnpike I found a jerk came on the mare's back—I jumped down, and found one of the firkins gone from behind, and the rope cut—before that the shafts did not come down on the mare—I ran back to look for the policeman—I ran back to Knightsbridge-barracks, and saw two gentlemen—from what they said, I looked through the rails, and saw the two prisoners in the Park with the firkin of butter—I am sure it was them—I ran round Barrack-alley, and got a policeman—we met the prisoners together with the firkin on their backs—I caught hold of Brown, who had the butter—he threw it off his shoulder on to my arms, and I was forced to let the butter go—he tried to get away—the sentry at the barracks put up his legs, and both the prisoners fell down together—I caught hold of them, and the policeman directly came running up—I did not lose sight of them at all till they were taken—it was William Stacey's firkin of butter, but it was in my charge.

STEPHEN MASTERS (police-constable A 178.) About eight o'clock in the evening of the 28th of March, I met the prisoners together in Hyde-park, carrying this firkin of butter—they were coming from Kensington—I turned round after them—I soon after heard an alarm—I went up to Turney, and saw him catch Brown, who was carrying the butter, and he threw it down on to Turney's arms—he tried to run, but they were thrown down by the sen
tinel, and taken—I am sure they are the persons—they merely said they did not steal it—Brown said to a boy who was following, he wished be would go and tell the old woman what was up, he expected he should go this time—Anderson said he expected to be transported, when he was here before, but he only had six months.

ROBERT BLACKWELL . I produce a certificate of Brown's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person—I was present when he left the bar—he pleaded guilty before I came into the Court.

JAMES ANDERSON (police-constable V 17.) I produce a certificate of An
derson's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present when he received sentence—he is the person.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

ANDERSON—
GUILTY Aged 18.

1243.
EMMA ABLE was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 1l. 1 guard
chain, 7s.; 1 watch-key, 3s.; and 1 shawl, 5s.; the goods of
William Walker, her master.

SUSANNAH WALKER . I am the wife of William Walker, a dyer, in the Hackney-road. The prisoner was in my service four years—between five and six o'clock, on the 20th of March, I had a silver watch in my drawer in the front parlour—the prisoner was in the parlour—I had occasion to go out into the garden—I was out about five minutes—when I came back, the prisoner and the watch and shawl were gone.
HENRY PETER PIGE , pawnbroker, Cambridge-row, Bethnal-green. This watch was pawned at my shop on the 30th of March, by the prisoner;—I am quite sure she is the person.

THOMAS BAILEY (police-constable H 74.) I took the prisoner in the Pavilion-theatre, Whitechapel. I told her it was for stealing a watch and shawl from her mistress—she admitted the theft immediately—I asked her if she had got any money—she gave me up 6s. 7d. and said she had bought a pair of shoes and stockings, and the other money she had made away with.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Judgment Respited.

1244.
GEORGE BIRCH was indicted
for stealing 3 planes, value 6s., and 2 saws, 4s.; the goods of
Thomas Downes, his master; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS DOWNES , bedstead-maker, Flower and Dean-street, Spital-fields. On the 5th of Feb. I missed three planes and two saws from my workshop—I bad seen them safe the day before—the prisoner was at work at my place that morning—I accused him of taking them—he beckoned one of his shop
mates out—I did not see him again for two months—I have not seen the tools again.

JOSEPH READER . I work for the prosecutor. On the morning of the 5th of Feb., he complained of missing his tools, and accused the prisoner of taking them—the prisoner beckoned me out, and confessed to me that he had taken them for drink, and he wanted me to go to his lodging to show me the tickets of his tools—I would not go—he went away, and did not come back.

JOHN SHEARING . I work for the prosecutor. On Monday, 1st of April, I went to the Globe, in the Borough-road, and found the prisoner—he said, "Jack, you are going to take me"—I said, "Yes," and told him to come borne with me to my master—he said, "Yes, I will;" and in coming along, he owned that he took the tools for drink, and he was willing to pay for them, provided his master would take him back to his employ—I gave him in charge on Tower-hill.
GEORGE HYDE (City police-constable, No. 516.) The prisoner was given to me—he said it was all through drink, or it would not have happened.
GEORGE TEAKLE (police-sergeant H 8.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1245.
PETER WINCEY was indicted
for stealing three sheets, value 7s.; the goods of
Mark Hammond.

HANNAH HAMMOND . I am the wife of Mark Hammond, and live in Chapman-street, Commercial-road, East. The prisoner lodged at my house for three weeks and three days—he occupied a furnished room, with his wife and two children—he left on the 23rd of March—I missed three sheets and a table-cloth from the room—I afterwards saw the prisoner—I charged him with having taken them—he said he had taken them and pledged them, and said I should have them returned—I said, "It is impossible I can take your word, I have waited nine days, in consequence of a note you sent me"—he did not let me know where he had gone to—these are the sheets.

Prisoner. Q. On the Saturday before I left, did you not tell me if I was in want of money, I might pledge one of these articles? A. Certainly not—you did not say if I would lend you 1s. till the following day, you would not part with them—I did not send word if you wanted a loaf of bread you might have it—I found this note down by the door, on the evening they sent me the key—they did not send me any address—note read—"Mrs. Ham
mond, I am sorry to leave you, but as it was your wish for us to do so, we have done so. I am again disappointed in receiving my money, and shall not have it till April. Your sheets and table-cover are at wash; and on Monday evening you shall have them. I will send you the rent with them."

WILLIAM STARR (policeman.) I went with Mrs. Hammond to No. 13, Baker's-row, and found the prisoner—she gave him in charge—I asked where the sheets were—he said they were in the wash, and then be told me they were in pledge—I received some duplicates from his wife.

HENRY EDWARD STREET , shopman to Messrs, Walker and Brown, pawn
brokers.

p.hi: I have two sheets, pawned by a female—these are the two tickets I gave her.

div1.p: WILLIAM COLE , shopman to Mr. Savage, pawnbroker, Whitechapel. I have a sheet, pawned by a woman—I gave her this duplicate.

Prisoner's Defence. I was there three weeks; the last twelve days I was in rather distressing circumstances; I was going out on the Saturday morn
ing, and, when in the street, she called me and told me as I was going to re
ceive money I might make use of a blanket or sheet; I told her I would not do so if it was not requisite, but if I was disappointed I should feel obliged if she would allow me to do so.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1246.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing 1 truck, value 10s., the goods of
Joseph Lake; to which be pleaded

GUILTY . Aped 82.—
Confined One Year.

1247.
THOMAS TYRRELL was indicted
for embezzling 20l., the money of
William Oakley, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Months ,

1248.
WILLIAM BROWN was indicted
for feloniously receiving 7 knives, value 3s.; 13 forks, 6s.; and 2 printed books, value 15s.; the goods of
Joseph Singleton, clerk; well knowing them to have been stolen.

REV. JOSEPH SINGLETON . I live at Bay Braham, in Cambridgeshire. On the 14th of Dec. my house was broken into—the persons got in through a larder window—I lost, among other property, a considerable quantity of plate, two dozen knives, two dozen forks, and a number of books—since the 26th of Feb., two books, seven knives, and thirteen forks have been produced by the officer—they formed part of the property stolen from my house that night—the books are a copy of "Milton," and the "Life of Christ."

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I believe the parties you sus
pect have been prosecuted? A. No—these are London knives, and have "Alderman, Barbican," on them—they are not of a very recent purchase—here is one of another description, and of another maker—I lost two knives of this sort—there was some writing in this "Life of Christ," but the leaf has been taken out.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe the persons have been prosecuted, but not for this charge? A. I am not certain whether they were in this robbery; it was proved that they had my property in their possession—their names were Cuttriss, Hall, and Bennett—I am firmly persuaded that these knives and forks are mine—I had some of the same description and the same maker.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G 20.) I know the prisoner—I was a witness against Cuttriss and Bennett at the last Chelmsford assizes—I have never seen them with the prisoner—on the 26th of February I went to the prisoner's house, Nelson-street, Hackney-road, with Mr. Clark, the superin
tendent of the Essex constabulary—the prisoner opened the door—I said, "I want you"—he said, "What for?"—I said, "I will tell you"—I went in—I saw a female take a key off the mantel-piece and go up stairs in a hurried manner—I follower her—she came down, and when I came down after her the prisoner was gone—Clark went in pursuit of him—I waited there some time—when Clark came back we searched, and I found these knives and forks

in a woollen stocking, in a drawer in a chest of drawers in the front parlour—I placed them on the top of the drawers, and whether the female took them away or not I cannot say, but I came away without them—I might have for
gotten them, but, to the best of my belief, they were removed—I went back for them on the following Monday, and they were gone—there was more pro
perty there, which is not here, I could not find owners for it—I afterwards found the knives and forks in possession of Jane Squires—I believe they are the game I found in the drawer in the parlour—I took away the books, and have had them ever since.

Cross-examined. Q. When you came back you spoke to the prisoner's wife, and she directed you to Squires, who gave you the knives and forks? A. She did after some considerable time—the prisoner's is a private house—he has one lodger, from what I have understood—it is a four-roomed house.

JOHN TIMEWELL CLARK . I am superintendent of the Essex constabulary. I accompanied Brannan to the prisoner's house on the 26th of Feb.—Brannan went up stairs with the woman—I remained down, and was watching another person who was there—I heard the front window go, and the prisoner went out at the front door—these two books were found in the bureau in the front parlour.

JANE SQUIRES . I am single, and live next door to the prisoner, in Nelson-street, Hackney-road. On Friday, the 1st of March, I was going by the prisoner's window, which was shut—his wife tapped at the window, and I went in as far as the parlour door, and she gave me these knives and forks—I kept them till the following Monday, and then gave them to the officer.

EMMA DEAN . I am in the service of the Honourable Algernon Herbert, at Eggleton, in the county of Cambridge. There was a robbery at my mas
ter's on the 18th of Jan., and this work-box, bag, and writing-desk, are part of the property lost on that occasion.
Cross-examined. Q. How much property was lost altogether? A. About 20l. worth.
JOHN PARTRIDGE . I am coachman to Mr. Hill. This box-coat is mine—my master's coach-house was broken open, and I lost this coat.

SALLY GIBLIN . I live with my uncle, Mr. Scott, at Wendon, near Saf
fron Walden. On the 25th of Jan. my uncle's house was broken open—this carving-knife and candlestick are my uncle's, and were stolen—the fork be
longing to this knife was found close by our gate—I was a witness at Chelms
ford against Cuttriss and the other.

GEORGE TOWNSEND . I am constable at Fordham, in Cambridgeshire. I know the prisoner—a woman, who went as his sister, lives housekeeper with me—this great-coat was brought to my house—I did not see the prisoner—his sister showed it to me on Thursday, the 8th of Feb., before the prisoner was taken—I took possession of it.

JAMES BRANNAN
re-examined. There was another man lodging in the pri
soner's house, in the one-pair back room—these articles were not found in the room he lodged in—the books, knives and forks were in the parlour, down stairs, where there was no sleeping at all—Hayward brought the pri
soner to the station next morning.
JAMES HAYWARD (police-constable G 212.) The prisoner was brought to the Police-court at Worship-street by his own attorney, and I took him.
NOT GUILTY .

1249.
WILLIAM BROWN was again indicted
> for feloniously receiving 1 carving-knife, value 8s.; 1 taper-stand, 2s.; and 1 extinguisher, 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Scott; well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

SALLY GIBLIN . I am niece of Thomas Scott, and live at Wendon, in Essex, about forty miles from London. On the night of the 25th of Jan. my uncle's house was broken open and robbed—I saw the thieves—there was a carving-knife, a taper-stand, and a toast-rack taken—these are them—I bought the knife myself—it was bruised at one end—I was obliged to give evidence at Chelmsford, when two of the thieves were convicted—my uncle is very aged.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G 20.) I went to the prisoner's house, in Nelson-street, on the 26th of Feb.—there was a lodger there—I spoke to him in his back room up stairs—he was called as a witness for the prisoner before the Magistrate, and made a statement—I found this carving-knife and taper-stand in a box under some clothes in the front room up stairs, and the toast-rack in a little box in the same room—the prisoner went away on that occasion—I saw him next day at the station—when he saw me come in, he held out his hand, and said, "Do you want me?"—I said, "You know we do, or else you would not run away"—he said, "I did not run away, I walked away; now what do you want me for?"—I said, "For being concerned, with others, in breaking and entering several houses in the borders of Cambridge
shire and Essex"—he said, "Lord bless you, I never broke into anybody's house in my life"—I said, "We took a deal of property from your place"—he said, "I can account for that, it is all mine, don't alarm yourself"—I am sure he said that—Clark was close to him—there were several examinations on the separate cases before the Magistrate.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you been in the police? A. Nearly fourteen years—I did not state in the last case that the prisoner said that all the property was his, because I was ordered to stand down—Harbour was called by the prisoner—he is outside—we took away from the prisoner's house, besides these things, some plated candlesticks and some bridle-bits.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1250.
CHARLOTTE SINCLAIR was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of gloves, value 1s. the goods of
George Clark.

GEORGE CLARK , linen-draper, Upper Whitecross-street. On Saturday afternoon, the 9th of March, the prisoner came into my shop and asked for black kid gloves, white kid gloves, and gauntlet gloves—I showed her some black kid gloves at 1s. a pair—she asked for some better, and as I walked to the top of the shop I looked round very short, and saw her take a pair of kid gloves out of the paper which was opened, and put them down into her lap—I returned and opened the other kid gloves—she then asked for various others—I said, "I have no others"—she said, "You have nothing good enough or large enough"—she then went away without purchasing any thing—I followed her—she turned to the right out of my shop, and then to the left down Old-street—mine is the last house in the street, except Mr. Ham
mond's—I returned into the shop and rang the shop bell—my wife came down—I then went to the kid gloves and counted them over, which I had done previously—I found one pair missing—there had been nine pair, and there were only eight—I followed the prisoner—as I crossed the road I met her—she said, "I presume you are the gentleman whose shop I was in"—I said, "Yes"—she said, "I have left my umbrella"—I said, "I have not

noticed it, walk back"—the took the umbrella and left—a young man two shops off said something to me—I then followed the prisoner—I saw a policeman coming—I overtook her near Mr. Sinclair's in Old-street, and said "I want you"—she said "What for?"—I said "For stealing a pair of gloves"—she said "I have no gloves of yours"—I said "No, you have thrown them away"—I took her back—the policeman was with me—she was very desirous of having some conversation with me—I said I would not—I saw her fumbling about her arm, and said, "What have you got there?"—she said, "Nothing of yours"—it was a little basket with a pair of black kid gloves in it, which I thought were mine, but they were not—she said she was very respectable, and should not be guilty of any thing of the kind—I ulti
mately gave her into custody—a man named Parks was brought into my shop while the prisoner was there—he produced a pair of black kid gloves—they were mine—he said in the prisoner's presence that he saw her distinctly throw them away in the area close by my door—I swear that no other person was in the shop while I was showing her the gloves—these are my gloves, and those I missed that day—a neighbour named Brown was there when the pri
soner was there, and said something to me.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Brown beard every thing that occurred on the prisoner being brought back? A. Yes, he attended before the Magistrate, his deposition was taken in writing, and read over to him—he did not sign it, because the Magistrate said he would not be required—I only showed one packet of gloves at first to the prisoner—she did not try any on—we do not allow ladies to try gloves on unless they are expensive ones—she was sitting—I do not know whether she pulled her own gloves off—I do not think she did—I Should think I was twenty-three feet from her when I turned and saw her take the gloves—I do not remember that I said, before I was examined before the Magistrate, that I turned and saw her take something from the packet of gloves on the counter—I think I can swear that was not my expression—there was nothing to take but gloves—she had no purse or reticule that I saw—she had a muff and a little basket—I did not see a purse at all, unless it was at the station—the searcher had something, but really I did not notice it—the packets of gloves are not ticketed—we have them by the dozen, unless they are good gloves—I thought by seeing a person of her appearance take a pair of gloves I should do right to follow her into the street and give her in charge—I went out and met her coming back to the shop—when she first went out she walked backwards and forwards a little confused, and then crossed diagonally into Old-street—a young man, a young lady, myself and my wife, attend to my shop—there is a pork-shop next door—she did not go near that shop—before she came back for the umbrella she walked backwards and forwards, as if she did not know which way to go—I am sure she did not go near the pork-shop after she returned for the um
brella—she threw her muff on to the counter when she saw I looked at her—it had been in her lap previously—I saw nothing of the basket at the time—we do not sell many kid gloves—we buy them at wholesale houses in the City—she was remanded in the first instance for the depositions to be taken on the Wednesday, then remanded till Saturday, and then finally admitted to bail—I am certain there was no other person in the shop—I never said I really could not recollect whether there was or not—it was not after I bad heard a person examined by the Magistrate that I said there was no one—my answer to the Magistrate was taken down—the officer went into the shop with me, and after that the carter came—Mr. Mountcastle's lad brought him in—the carter offered to show where he picked up the gloves—he said, "Who is to pay me my expenses—I am a poor man—I cannot lose the time"—I said

his expenses would be paid—the officer did not ask if I was going to give her in charge—I did not say "Decidedly not; I did not see her take them"—the carter said something about throwing the gloves down the grating or area—the officer did not whisper any thing to me at that time—there is an open
ing under the window at Mr. Hammond's shop, and an iron grating drops down inside; and as you enter my shop door this little opening is just at the left, hardly a yard off.

MR. JONES. Q. Have you ever expressed any doubt as to what you saw the prisoner take up? A. No—I did not give anything to Parks for attend
ing but what I asked the Magistrate if I might give him, merely to pay his expenses.

JOHN PARKS . I am carter to Mr. Maskin, of Maidstone—I was going up White Cross-street on the afternoon of the 9th of March, and saw the prisoner near the corner of White Cross-street—she stooped and hurled a pair of black gloves away—she was going towards Mr. Clark's shop—he was walking in front of her—I got out of my cart and picked up the gloves at the side of Mr. Hammond's, the ironmonger's, window just by the grating—his shop is the corner, and Mr. Clark's is the next door—some one came after me, and brought me back to Mr. Clark's shop—I gave the gloves to him.

Cross-examined. Q. How far had you got with the gloves? A. About three or four rods—I thought as the lady was dressed in a respectable way, she did not want them; in fact, I did not know what they were, till I got up into the van again—I did not know who was the owner, and whether the lady wanted them or not—I was driving off down White Cross-street—I must have gone by the pork-shop—I do not know whether there is a grating under the pork-shop window—it was two or three minutes after I took the gloves that I was brought back—there were some persons in the street.

JAMES MARLEY . I am in the employ of Mr. Britton, of Upper White Cross-street—there is only one shop between ours and Mr. Clark's—in the afternoon of the 9th of March I saw Parks go past, and my attention was drawn to him—he got out of his cart and picked up the gloves at the other side of Mr. Clark's door, towards Old-street, just by the grating of Mr. Hammond's shop—I have measured the distance from Mr. Hammond's grating to the pork-shop, and it is 10 yards—I told Mr. Clark what I had seen—I attended at the police-office, and was not called.

----BROWN. I keep a manufactory in Upper White Cross-street—I was near Mr. Clark's shop on the afternoon of the 9th of March—I saw Parks leave his cart, stoop down, and pick up a small black parcel near Mr. Clark's door—I think it was near Mr. Hammond's—I would not swear positively on which side he picked it up—he went on down White Cross-street—I told Mr. Clark what I had seen, and Parks was fetched back—I saw the prisoner at Mr. Clark's, under charge—Mr. Clark said she had stolen a pair of gloves—she said no she had not, she was too respectable to do anything of the sort; and from her respectable appearance, I called Mr. Clark to the end of the shop, and asked if he was certain—he said he was positive he saw her take them off the counter—she wanted to speak to him in private—he said, "I have nothing to say to you"—I went to the station-house.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you standing at your own door? A. No—I was crossing from Old-street into White Cross-street—I noticed Mr. Clark when he came out—I went into the shop after the things were picked up.
WALTER WHITE (police-constable G 168.) I received the prisoner in charge with these gloves from Mr. Clark—I saw him receive them from Parks.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear every word that was said between Mr. Clark and the prisoner? A. No—I heard Mr. Clark say he charged her

with stealing a pair of gloves—I heard what was said—I did not bear Parks say, "Who is to pay me for my trouble"—Mr. Clark said be should be paid his expenses—I do not remember my asking whether he was going to give the prisoner into custody—he said he should give her into custody for steal­ing the gloves—I do not recollect whispering to Mr. Clark—nothing of the sort occurred.

HARRIET HAYWARD . I am searcher at the station at Featherstone-street. The prisoner was brought there—I searched her, and found in the pocket of her dress, half a pound of soap and a new pair of mittens; and while I was taking the soap out, she took the mittens out of her pocket, tore the ticket off them, and threw it under the cell—I examined her basket, and found a new pair of black gloves, a new pair of mittens, an orange, seven samples of loaf-sugar, five pieces of cheese, a bottle of ink, and 4s.
Cross-examined. Q. These lumps and pieces were all wrapped up sepa­rately? A. Yes—two lumps in each paper—she said they were samples—one of them was marked 7 1/2 d.
MR. JONES. Q. Was the 4s. in a purse? A. Yes.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Six Months.

1251.
WILLIAM BURGESS was indicted
for stealing 6 handkerchiefs, value 15s.; and 30 yards of ribbon, value 10s.; the goods of
George Stagg, and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

1252.
MARY ANN WINGATE was indicted
for stealing 31 yards of satin, value 27l.; 15 yards of velvet, 15l.; 1 scent-bottle, 1l. 1s.; 1 neck
lace, 5s.; and 5 yards of linen-cloth, 10s.; also 1 shawl, 1l. 1s.; 3 sheets, 12s.; 2 table-cloths, 10s.; and 6 table-napkins, 10s.; the goods of Geor
giana Charlotte Theobald, her mistress; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined One Year.

1253.
FREDERICK RADFORD,
FREDERICK SHAW , and
JAMES SHAW were indicted for
a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Jacob Worster, about the hour of one in the night of the 2nd of Feb., with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 36 shells, value 1l. 1s.; 230 brushes. 3l. 10s.; 3000 leaves of gold, 7l. 10s.; 25 packets of metal, 1l.; and loz. weight of gold-dust, 4l.; the goods of
Jacob Worster, in his dwelling-house.

JACOB WORSTER . I am an oil and colourman, and live in New Compton-st., in the parish of St. Giles-in-the-Fields; it is my dwelling-house. At nine in the evening of 2nd Feb., I locked the premises up with a padlock—I have a side door into the private passage—there is a shop door and a private door, both into the street—the outside private door was fastened, as usual, with a latch—it could be opened from the outside with a key, not without—there was an inner door to the shop from the passage—it was fastened with a pad
lock—I came down next morning a little after seven, and it was wide open—the padlock was on the ground—I got into the shop, and found a great number of the drawers taken out of the nest, and left on the counter empty—I missed all the gold, a great quantity of brushes, some gold-dust, and other things—some of the brushes I had had in the evening before—what I lost was above 20l. worth—the prisoners Shaws have come to my house for gold-books—I buy gold-books, and sell them—this is part of the property I lost that night—here is one of the brushes that 1 had the same evening—I marked it as I had it in, with my own private mark.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. I believe when you sell brushes you

do not rob off the private marks? A. No—these brushes came in between seven and eight in the evening—they were perfectly safe in my premises at nine, when I closed, and had not been undone—there were three dozen of these; one dozen were gone, and two left—that was in another drawer, which they had not opened—I cannot say exactly how many brushes were pro
duced by Weston—I gave information, and on the 1st of March I was fetched to the station, and a great quantity of brushes were produced—these gilt shells were produced by West—they are worth 7s. a dozen, and the brushes about 1l.

JAMES ADDAMS . I am an artist's brush-maker—I make brushes for the prosecutor—these brushes are particular, and are made for gilders alone—they are different to what I make for artists—I have no other customer but the prosecutor, that deals with gilders—I sold him three dozen the evening before—these are two of them—I am positive.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you know them by? A. Being bound with finer thread than usually, and made on shorter and more taper handles than in general—I made only three down, and Mr. Worster had them all—these seven other brushes are of my make.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Of those that were produced by Weal, do you see any there that you made for Mr. Worster? A. Here is only one that I can speak positively to.

GEORGE WESTON (police-sergeant Z 3.) On the 1st of March I searched Radford's premises, and found twenty gold shells and forty-eight brushes is his box—he gave Pocock the key of it—when I went in I charged him with another offence—he made no answer.

WILLIAM WEST (police-constable F 106.) On the 1st of March I accom
panied another officer to a house in Mercer-street, Long-acre—I there saw Frederick Shaw's wife—I found twenty brushes in the drawer—Frederick Shaw was not present when we went, which was about eight o'clock in the morning—he came in about nine—Pocock said he must consider himself in custody—I do not know what his reply was.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How many examinations were there? A. Two—James Shaw was not in custody at first—I saw him in the Court when the other prisoners were charged—I do not know that he was there to give evidence for his brother—I did not hear him, nor any one on his behalf say so—I saw him standing outside while I was inside, on the 1st of March—he was taken, I think, about a week ago, about the 6th of April—the second examination was about a week after the first—I saw James Shaw in the street then—I saw him in the Court on the first occasion, but I was inside, beyond the door, and he was outside—he was not called as a witness on either side.

WILLIAM POCOCK (police-constable F 81.) On the 1st of March I went with Weston, and assisted in searching the room—in a drawer under the bed I found 112 brushes, and in removing the bed, a paper parcel fell down on the floor between the bed and the wall, which contained twenty-eight more brushes, and two balls of string—they appeared close between the bed and the wall—the drawers were not locked—James Shaw came in while we were in the room—I asked him if he knew Frederick and Edward Radford—he said he did—I told him they were in custody for robbery, and he was charged with being concerned—he asked what robbery I meant—I said, Mr. Ward, of Compton-street, and Mr. Smith, bookbinder, Long-acre.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Were you present during both exa
minations? A. Yes—I did not hear the gentleman tell the Magistrate that

James Shaw was there—I heard it stated that then were respectable wit
nesses to be called for Frederick.

JOHN HOLT . oil and colourman, East-street, Manchester-square. About eleven o'clock on Saturday evening, the 3rd of Feb., James Shaw came into my shop as we were about closing business—he said, "I have a job, or rare lot of Dutch metal, will you have it of me?"—I said, "This is a very late time to offer goods, or to tease me about them, I would rather not be troubled with them now"—he pressed me to take them—I asked what he wanted for it—he said 16s.—I said I did not want it, but said, "I will take it of you, I suppose I shall sell it some time, I will give you 14s. for it which I did—this is the metal—he said he had a quantity of brushes to dis
pose of, and some gold shells—I did not purchase them—on the, following Monday he brought some brushes—I believe this to be the parcel—they were found in Frederick Shaw's bedroom—I opened the parcel and looked at them—this particular one, bound with copper, attracted my attention—I had not seen any like it before.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You had been a customer of his father's? A. Yes—I knew him well—the brushes, were similar to these—I am quite positive be spoke about gold shells.

WILLIAM CORN . I am foreman to Messrs. Kelsey, of Falcon-square. In, the early part of Feb. last, James Shaw brought a quantity of brushes to sell;—I said I had not time to look at them—he said he took them for a debt—he called again and I had not then time to look at them—he called again and took them away, and said the party had come to an arrangement, and he would take them back—in a few days he brought them again, and I refused to have them—they were a similar sort to these, and bad the name of John Addams on several of them—I swear that this camera hairbrush was one of the parcel—there is a mark on it.

JACOB WORSTSER
re-examined. I know this camel's hair brush—it was made for a particular customer which I have—it was safe on the 2nd of Feb., and gone on the 3rd—out of the forty-eight found I identify these two that came from Bedford's box, and these other seven that I speak to, came from Frederick Shaw's—I believe the gold shells to be mine—they have no mark on them—they were tied in a brown paper when they were taken—I have not seen that paper again.

MART ANN MOORE . I am servant to Mr. Frederick Shaw, the pri
soner's father—he lives in Denmark-street—on the 27th of February, Radford came there with a blue bag—he asked if Mr. Shaw was at home—I said No, James was at home—he said "James, I can't sell these brushes, will you buy them?"—James Shaw said, "Let us look at them," and there were a great many brushes turned out of the bag on to the parlour table—James said, "How much do you want for them?"—I did not hear what Radford said, but James said, "I will give you 25s. for them"—Wil
liam, the apprentice, was cleaning the window, and Mr. Osborn was there—I cannot say whether any bargain was made, but two hours after I saw the brushes there—James took them away either into his bed-room or into the, shop—I think I should know the bag again—it was a small bag lined with bed-tick.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. I believe you are married? A. Yes—I live with the elder Shaw merely as a servant—I swear I do not live with him. at his wife—I am separated from my husband.
HENRY DOWELL . I am a carpenter, and live in Denmark-street, next door to Shaw's. On the 28th of (I forget the name of the month)—it was

this year, and two days before Frederick Shaw was taken—I was standing at my door—James Shaw came to me—he said, "I have had a few words with my father," and asked me if I would come and help him carry some things—he took me up into his bed-room—took out some gas pipes, a brass lamp, and a blue bag, and we took them to Mercer-street, Long-acre—we came out—had a drop of drink, and I left him—it was between twelve and one o'clock in the day.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you never been in the service of Mr. Shaw? A. No—I know him by occasionally seeing his sons now and then—I have called on his sons—I am not on intimate terms with him—I have been told by several persons that old Shaw has been taken up, but I do not know it of my own knowledge—I was never taken up myself nor charged with any
thing.

COURT. Q. Did you see what you carried? A. Yes—he took a blue bag out of his box containing brushes—I cannot say how many—there was a string to the bag—the mouth was open and I saw a great many brushes—I dare say I saw fifty—I am not sure.

MART ANN MOORE
re-examined. I am servant to Shaw's father—Radford first came on the 3rd of February to Mr. Shaw's with a bundle under his arm—I do not know what was in it—he went into the shop—James Shaw was there—I did not go into the shop—Mr. Woodford was in the shop, and the apprentice, who is always there.

GEORGE WOODFIELD .
