wards of six months; when I had it the back had grown out as large as an egg; I used to wash it, and attend it in a proper manner, and it became as fine a baby as ever was known, and if I had been a bad mother to my child, they would not have let me have that child; I did not jump into the water, but fell over a plank; if my baby had been taken from me, I know how it would have been served, and that trouble was greater than I could bear.

GUILTY , Aged 36.—
Death.

1280.
HENRY WILLIAM ALBERT was indicted
for forging and utter
ing an indorsement on a foreign bill of exchange, with intent to defraud
James Butler M'Rae.

JAMES BUTLER M'RAE . I carry on business as a wholesale warehouse-man in Ave-Maria-lane, Ludgate-street, in partnership with my brother John. I know the prisoner; he calls himself a wine-merchant, and does a sort of agency business—he was indebted to us—he came, on the 20th of Dec., and offered me this bill of exchange—(looking at it)—he said he would take part goods and part cash for it—I told him if he would leave the bill, and call again, we would make inquiries about it—he said it was a very good bill, a bill as good as Rothschild's, as good as the Bank of England's—I saw him again on the 22nd of Dec—we had then made inquiries, and said we would take it—we gave him part goods, and a cheque for the remainder, which was 34l. 5s. 11d.—I saw him put his name on the back of the cheque when he received it.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You have known him some years? A. About three years—we had bad dealings with him before—there is an old account standing now—I always understood him to be a German; he did not speak English very perfectly—after we were in possession of the bill, Mr. Wil
kinson came to us—the prisoner brought a friend with him to talk about the bill, and I refered him to our solicitor—his friend promised to go to our solicitor the following morning—he said he could explain the matter—I accompanied Mr. Wilkinson to the prisoner's lodging, in Watling-street, one morning—I did not hear where he had removed to—I saw a servant, who said he had been gone out some minutes.

JOHANNA ROSING . I am a merchant, and have lived at the Due de Orleans, at Paris, for two years; I am a native of Bremen, and did live there; I do business in Paris for the house of Bolte and Co., at Bremen. On the 1 1th of Nov. last I bought four bills of exchange, on Hamburg, for them—on the next day I enclosed those bills in a letter, which I sealed with my seal, and addressed it to Messrs. Bolte and Co., Bremen, and, being indisposed, I sent my boy with the letter to the post-office—this was on Sunday, the 12th of Nov.—I have had communications since from Bremen on the subject of these bills—this is one of the bills (looking at it) that I enclosed in the letter—I am very well acquainted with the houses of business in Paris, and

I have inquired; there is no such firm as Bolte and Co., at Paris—this bill is not in the same state as when I sent it; a false indorsement has been added to it, which follows my indorsement to "Bolte and Co., Bremen"—"Pay to the order of Mr. H. W. Albert, value in account. Paris, 30 Nov. 1843. Bolte and Co."—I indorsed it "In account," because I had an ac
count with Bolte and Co.; and now this false indorsement is "Value in ac
count," as if Bolte and Co. had some account with Mr. Albert; that is very wrong—these other two bills (looking at them) are part of the same purchase, and have my indorsement the same as the other—here is on one of them, "H. W. Albert," and on the other, "J. H. Albert."

Cross-examined. Q. Are you agent of Bolte and Co. at Paris? A. Yes, and am well known as their agent there—I heard something of a person named Frederick—I said I should be glad to meet with him, because his named was mentioned, and I heard that the prisoner said he had received the bills from Frederick—I do not know whether Frederick is in custody in Paris.
FERDINAND ROSINO . On a Sunday in Nov. my father gave me a letter directed to Bolte and Co., Bremen—I put it into the post in the same state as when my father gave it me.

AUGUSTS THEODOR PLUMP . I am a merchant, of the firm of Bolte and Co., living at Bremen, and carrying on business there—they have no house of business or establishment at Paris, or anywhere except at Bremen—Jo
hanna Rosing is their agent at Paris—we expected a remittance of some bills from him in Nov. last—the bills did not arrive, and, not receiving them, we drew on him on account, on the 1st of Dec., for part of the sum—this bill would have been worth about 65l. in English money last Nov.—this indorse
ment of "Bolte and Co." on it is not my writing, nor the writing of either of my partners—no person has any authority to draw or to indorse bills of ex
change for the firm but my two partners and myself—this indorsement of Mr. Rosing to us, "Value in account," means that he stands in account with us, and so he makes us remittances for it—it is a transaction of account, not a cash transaction—that is always the way of doing business amongst mer
chants—these other two bills were never received by our house, nor is there any indorsement of ours, or by authority from us, upon them—the name of "H. W. Albert" was never known to us—we never had any transaction with him—we know nothing of "J. W. Albert," which is on the other bill.

FERDINAND DAVIS BLUM . I live in St. John's Wood-road, and am clerk to Konigswater Brothers, of London. We bought this bill of exchange of the prisoner about the 12th of Dec. last—it is worth about 63l. in English money—he asked if we would buy it of him—we had previously refused to buy a bill of him, as he was a stranger; and when he brought this be brought a person to introduce him, whom we had known in business—here is on this bill the supposed indorsement of "Bolte and Co., pay to order of H. W. Albert, value in account"—that imports that there had been transactions between the house of Bolte and Co. and the indorsee—a person in the prisoner's situation would know enough of the language and practice of bills, to be aware of what it meant—when the bill was at maturity it was not paid.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you speaking of-what the prisoner said to you, or did he speak to anybody else in the firm? A. He spoke to Mr. Konigswater—I can undertake to say that I heard all that passed—I had no other employ
ment at that moment, and was listening to what was spoken—the name of Frederick was not mentioned to us by the prisoner when we bought this bill—I cannot say whether we saw the prisoner at any other time about this bill; but in speaking of another bill he named Frederick, and gave his address in Paris.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. He produced another bill? A. Yes, at the end of Nov., previous to the 28th, for 1616 marck 2 schillings banco—it was drawn by the same party as this bill is, and appeared to have been indorsed first to Rosini, and then by him to Bolte and Co., and by Bolte and Co. to Albert—we refused to buy that bill, because the prisoner was unknown to us—he called several times, and mentioned parties as references whom we did not know, and we refused to buy.

JOSIAH WILKINSON . I am one of the attornies for this prosecution. I am concerned for Mr. M'Rae, and also for Bolte and Co.—in consequence of what was learnt on the subject of this bill, I went several times to the prisoner's lodg
ings—I at last saw him the day before he was taken up—he spoke English—I told him that this bill was returned to my clients, with the statement that the indorsement, "Bolte and Co.," was a forgery—he said it was perfectly right, and he could refer me to Mr. Johnson, of Cecil-street, Strand, who would tell me it was all right, and would be paid—I went immediately to Mr. Johnson, who told me he knew nothing at all about it—I communicated that to the prisoner on the following day, and took him into custody.

Cross-examined. Q. You say he spoke English; does he not speak it very imperfectly? A. He spoke it as well as either of the witnesses we have heard to-day, in my opinion—he spoke English fluently for a foreigner—he came to my office, and I spoke to him about this bill—he referred me to Mr. Johnson, and then he left, and the next day the officer took him, near my office—he lodged near my office—I went to endeavour to see him on the day he was taken—I did not expect to see him—I did not understand, when I parted with him the day before, that I was to meet him again the next day—my belief is that I was not to meet him—he gave me a card; but I think if he had said he would meet me again I should have recollected it—I put down the name and address of Mr. Johnson—I gave directions to take the prisoner—I had been several times to his lodging, and was told he was not at home—I then went another time, and as I was knocking at the private door he ran out of the shop—I believe he ran out to avoid me—I followed, and begged him to go to my office, and when there he referred me to Mr. Johnson—I knew then that this indorsement was forged, but I thought it better to see Johnson before I gave the prisoner into custody.
Indorsements read.—"Payez a l'ordre de Monsieur H. W. Albert, valeur en compte, Paris, le 30 Novembre, 1843. BOLTE & Co, H. W. ALBERT. J. M'RAE. "

JAMES BUTLER M'RAE
re-examined. My brother put his name on this bill—this is his writing. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Confined Two Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1281.
WILLIAM WATTS and
STEPHEN DANIELS were indicted for
ripping and cutting 198lbs. weight of lead, the goods of
Joseph Hoppe, with intent to steal it.—2nd COUNT, for stealing the same lead, being fixed.

THOMAS BONE . I live in Adam and Eve-court, Whitecross-street. I went to the top of the house at eight o'clock in the evening, and saw the prisoner Watts on the roof—he ran along—I saw the lead of the gutter all doubled up—there were four cuts in it, but it was not wholly cut off—it was doubled up from the coping—it was Mr. Joseph Hoppe's house.
Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK Q. It was not your house? A. No,
I live at No. 9, and this was next door—it is an old house—it was dark, but I had a candle in my hand.

WILLIAM HOOKER . I live at No. 13, Adam and Eve-court. At half-past eight o'clock that night I went through my trap door to the top of my house—I saw Daniels in the corner of the gutter, and asked what he did there—he said, "Pray forgive me this time, I will never come here any more"—I took him to the trap door to take him down—he insisted on going down first, and when he got down he took away the ladder and left me there—I found the lead was cut and rolled up from the coping and the tiles.

Cross-examined. Q. How many months before had you been up there? A. I may have been there about six weeks ago—I do not know whether Daniels removed the ladder by accident—he did move it, and I dropped down—the lead was entirely separated from the other.

JAMES HAYWARD (policeman.) I saw Watts drop from a shed about seven houses from Bones' in Adam and Eve-court—he was endeavouring to conceal this knife, and dropped it behind him—I asked him where he fell from—he said, "From the top here," pointing up—he was stunned.
HENRY LEE (policeman.) I saw the lead—it was cut off so that it could have been carried away without using a knife again—the cutting appeared to be quite fresh.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you swear whether it was cut a week or ten days before? A. It was quite fresh—to the best of my belief it was cut at that very time—it was cut away, and the coping of the wall was taken off—the lead was rolled up and entirely cut off from the other. (Watts received a good character.)

WATTS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Two Months.

DANIELS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

1282.
MARGARET MINTON was indicted
for stealing 4 sovereigns the monies of
Thomas Brown, her master.

SELINA BROWN . I am the wife of Thomas Brown, of North-street, Red Lion-square. The prisoner was in my service for six days—I put fourteen sovereigns, and two 5l. notes into the cash-box on the 1st of April, and took it up stairs—I brought it down to the parlour with me the next morning—I did not leave the parlour till about three o'clock in the afternoon, when I left the prisoner to sweep the room—I went to the parlour at four o'clock and missed four sovereigns from the box—the prisoner was out then—when she returned I accused her, and she denied it—I gave her in charge, and four sovereigns were found in her hair—I had left the key of the box in the parlour.
HARRIET FOWLER . I searched the prisoner and found four sovereigns in the back of her hair.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

1283.
DAVID SMITH was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 4l., the goods of
John Pensam; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1284.
EDWARD OLIVER was indicted
for stealing 1 firkin, value 2s.; and 275lbs. weight of white lead, value 3l. 15s.; the goods of
Thomas Wilshire Gurney.

JOSEFH GORDON . I am carman to Mr. Thomas Wilshire Gurney. On the 4th of April I saw the prisoner come into my master's shop, in the Edg
ware-road—he rolled a firkin of white lead away from the door against two

large gates in the road, and sat upon it—I went for a policeman, and when I came back he was gone—I looked round and saw him at the corner of Bell-street, rolling the firkin along the pavement—it was my master's firkin of lead.
JAMES M'CANN (policeman.) I saw the prisoner in Bell-street rolling the firkin—I took him.
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to help him toll it to Great James-street, and he would give me some beer.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined One Year.

1285.
JAMES JACKSON was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; the goods of
Job Matthews.

JOB MATTHEWS . I live in Frederiok-place. Go the 30th of March, be
tween eight and nine o'clock, I was is the parlour behind my shop, and saw a man in the act of stooping—I went into the shop, and the prisoner ran out—I ran and took him—he said he would pay for them—I was not then aware that he had taken any thing—these are my boots.
THOMAS BISHOP . I live at Brewer's-green, I saw the prisoner throw away these boots—Mr. Matthews picked them up.
Prisoner's Defence. Two more lads stood there; a woman said, "There he goes," and I ran.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Month.

1286.
WALTER WILLIAM SILVER WOOD was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, 2 half-crowns, 6 shillings, and 6 sixpences, the monies of
William Walter, his master.

WILLIAM WALTER, JUN . I am the son of William Walter, a cork-cutter, in Drury-lane. The prisoner was his shop-boy—on the 13th of Sept., at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, I gave him the key to open the shop, and sweep it—I afterwards found he was gone—I went to his lodging, and he was not there—I came back in about ten minutes, and I round the till in the front shop was broken open, and missed one sovereign, one half-sove
reign, two half-crowns, six shillings, and six sixpences—no one was in the shop from the time I went out till I came back—I did not lock the shop.
Prisoner. I was not in the shop that morning—I was up in the top shop. Witness. I am sure I saw him there—Sherrard had opened the shop when I returned.
JAMES SHERRARD . I came to the shop at half-past eight—I found the till broken open, and about 2l. 4s. taken out—I did not open the shop—it was open when I came—I do not know who opened it.
NOT GUILTY .

1287.
JOHN WHITE was indicted
for stealing 9 shillings, and 1 groat, the monies of
William Golding.

JOHN ROBINSON . I am errand-boy to Mr. William Golding, a chemist, in Upper Albany-street, Regent's Park—about half-past ten o'clock in the morn
ing on the 5th of April, the prisoner came and desired my master to send a black draught and a pill, and asked how long—it would be before he sent it—my master said half an hour—the prisoner said, "Before that"—my master said he would send it as soon as he could, and he told him to send change for a half sovereign—my master gave me the draught and pill, and 9s. 4d.—I met the prisoner—he took the things and the change, and gave me what I supposed was a half-sovereign, but I looked and saw the feathers on the re
verse side—I ran after him, and called "Stop thief"—the policeman caught
him—I have not been to No. 4, Augusta-square, where the prisoner ordered the things to go to.
Prisoner. Q. Are you sure I came to the shop and ordered them? A. Yes—I know you by your dress—I lost sight of you, but got sight of you again in Hampstead-road.

ALFRED JOSEPH JOLLEY . I am clerk to Mr. Mortlock in Oxford-street. I was in Hampstead-road on Good Friday—the prisoner passed me, and as he passed he threw a white paper over a garden wall—I got over and got it—there was nine shillings and a 4s. piece in it—I am sure he threw it.
GEORGE CLARK (policeman.) I took the prisoner, and have this medal from Robinson—I have been to No. 4, Augusta-square—the prisoner it not known there.
Prisoner's Defence. I gave the boy a good half-sovereign, and he was showing it about to several persons before he gave it to the officer.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.

1288.
JOHN BROCKLEY was indicted
for stealing 3/4 lb. of soap, value 3d., the goods of
John Matthews.

VOLTAIRE WHITE . I am sixteen yean old, and am in the service of Mr. John Matthews—he keeps a tallow-chandler's shop in King-street, Hammer
smith. On the evening of the 18th of March I went on an errand, and on my return, I stopped for a minute at my master's window—I saw the prisoner in the shop—I saw him take a piece of soap from the box, and put it into his right-hand coat-pocket—I went into the shop, and stood as a customer—my mistress came in, and the prisoner told her to serve me first—she said, "He does not want serving—he is my own boy."—I said, "He has taken a piece of soap"—he took it from hit pocket, and said, "Weigh it, I meant to pay for it."

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not he go out of the shop after you went for the policeman? A. Yes, and went over the Suspension-bridge—we went round to his house—he was not taken at his house, but on the other side of the bridge—the scale is very near the box of soap—I swear that it was not out of the scale that he took the soap—I don't know that my master had a quarrel with the prisoner, about a man be had turned out—I have not noticed him to deal at the shop before—I have been there five months—he made an attempt to get away—I believe he was coming towards the policeman, and he has been on bail ever since.

COURT. Q. Could you tell whether, when the prisoner had the soap in his hand, before he put it in his pocket, he could see you, or was aware that he Was observed? A. He did not notice me till I was about to enter the shop—he had put it partly into his pocket before I entered, and when I entered, he pushed it in in a more flurried manner—I did not examine the pocket—I do not know whether it would require any. force to get it in.

AMY MATTHEWS . I am wife of John Matthews. I left the shop on the 18th of March, for a short time, and on my return I saw the prisoner and my lad in the shop—the prisoner said, "Serve him first"—I said, "He does not require serving, he is my own boy"—my boy then said, "Take that piece of soap out of your pocket directly, sir "—the prisoner took it out, and said,

"Weigh it, I intend to pay for it"—I am rare he took it out of hit right-hand coat-pocket, and he handed it to me—I said, "If you intended to pay for it, why did you put it in your pocket?"—he said" Don't make a fuss about it, weigh it, and I will pay you for it"—I placed it on one side—I told the boy to fetch a policeman, and the prisoner followed the boy shortly after—this is the piece of soap—it is common white soap—I know it by these holes in it, which I had noticed.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you a good many pieces of soap in that box? A. Yes—it is an inferior kind, but there was no better in that box.

WILLIAM GRAY (police-constable T 195.) I found the prisoner, over Hammersmith Suspension-bridge, at near seven o'clock that evening—I told him he must go with me to the station—he said, "For what?"—I said, "Con
cerning stealing a piece of soap"—he said, "I suppose it is concerning the soap the man gave me"—I found nothing but 7 3/4 d. on him.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did he live? A. In Queen-street, Hammer-smith—he was coining towards his own house, from the opposite side of the water—he surrendered here on Saturday.
NOT GUILTY .

1289.
ELIZABETH BEST was indicted
for stealing 1 parasol, value 3s. 9d., the goods of
Frederick Tomkins.

FREDERICK TOMKINS , linendraper, Charles-street, Middlesex Hospital. On the 11th of April, between twelve and one o'clock, the prisoner came and asked for a gentleman's hat-band—I referred her to Cole—in about three minutes Cole came to me, and stated something—I went round the counter, and saw a parasol under the prisoner's shawl—I said, "I must detain you, you have some of my property"—she made no reply—she was standing near the door—in a minute the parasol slid down on the floor—she said, "Oh dear me, it has hung to my shawl"—I replied, "That Is impossible, because you have got it underneath your shawl"—it had stood between five and six yards from where the prisoner stood.

JOSEPH COLE . I am shopman to Mr. Tomkins. The prisoner came and asked for a hat-band—I served her—it came to 6 3/4 d.—she gave me half-a-crown—we were proceeding to the other end of the shop to fold up the hat-band and give her change, and about half way down the shop I observed her halt—I instantly turned round, and saw her hand on a parasol—there were a great many lying together on a paper on the counter, about half way down, the shop—they might project an inch or two, so that a person going by might brush them if they went near enough to the counter—she would not have to pass the spot close to where they were lying—there was a thoroughfare of about four feet—there was a counter on one side, and rolls of flannel the other side, and four feet space to walk—I observed her halt and put the parasol under her shawl on her left side—I did not make any observation to her—she continued her walk to the end of the shop—I communicated what I had seen to Mr. Tomkins—the prisoner bad then arrived opposite him—he went round to her, and said, "I must detain you, you have some of my pro
perty on your person "—Mr. Tomkins requested me to go after a policeman—I did so—I observed the parasol fall on the floor—I saw her place the shawl quickly over it—she had not time given her to apply for the purchase of it—she was immediately charged with taking it—she was charged with stealing it about fourteen feet from where it was lying—she stood still a minute with it under her shawl, to give time to Mr. Tomkins to come round the counter—she observed him coming, and instantly turned her head the other way—he charged her with having it—he did not say "Have you got it?"

MR. TOMKINS re-examined. She made no remark about purchasing it—she had not got her change, nor the article she purchased—the value of the parasol is 3s. 9d.—the counter is thirty-seven inche high, nearly an inch higher than ordinary counters.

GEORGE PIPER (police-constable E 1.) I took the prisoner—she denied having stolen the parasol, but said it hung, to her shawl—a small inch-mea
sure was found on her, but no money.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not steal it; in passing the counter it hung to the shawl I have on.

GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor,—
Confined Three Weeks.

1290.
THOMAS RIDLEY , was indicted
for stealing 2 tin-pots, value 2d.; 2 cups, 1d.; a tin slice, 1d.; and a shell, 1l.; the goods of
Mary Crawley.

GEORGE JAMES . I live in Henry-street, White-horse-lane, Stepney. On the morning of the 9th of April, at half-past ten o'clock, I was in Stepney fair, looking at Clarke's show—the prisoner came by, and took up a bundle—his blouse was buttoned up—he put it under his left arm, and walked away—I told the prosecutrix, and then the policeman—he took the prisoner, who had got 100 yards.
Prisoner. Q. You said at the office yon saw me pick it up half-a-yard from the stall? A. The stall had just been moved, and the bundle was put under the table.
COURT. Q. Where did he put it? A. Under his coat—I found it there.

HENRY BARNES (police-constable K 256.) The prisoner was pointed out to me by James—I took him into custody—I found this bundle under his coat—he was dressed as he is now—it contains two tin pots, two cups, three pewter spoons, a tin slice, and a shell.
MART CRAWLEY . I had a stand at the fair—these are my things—I had put them under the stall quite close to me, and told the girl to take care of them.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not steal them; I was half-a-yard away from the stall, and picked them up in the pathway; I stood looking at the show.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Weeks.

1291.
HENRY WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 2d., 1 shil
ling; 1 sixpence; 5 pence and 1 halfpenny, the property of
Sarah Mary Taylor, from her person.

SARAH MARY TAYLOR . I am 14 years old. On the 10th of April I was at Stepney fair—I have parents—my money and my purse were my own—I went to see my aunt at Stepney—I had a cousin with me—we were looking at one of the shows—my purse was in my hand, with one shilling, sixpence, and fivepence halfpenny in it—the prisoner snatched it out of my hand, and passed in to another boy—I took hold of his collar and called a policeman.

Prisoner. I was about four yards off; she said, "A boy has taken my purse," and she collared me; I had nothing on me. Witness. He had not moved from the spot, I turned round directly it was taken—I am certain he it the person—I did not lose sight of him.

THOMAS BARTLETT (police-constable K 286.) When I came up the little girl had got the boy by the collar—he said, "Indeed, I did not take it, it was not me"—I found a knife on him—he gave his address Turk-street, Bethnal
green, that is about a mile and a half from Stepney.

GUILTY .* Aged 11.—
Confined Six Months ,

1292.
WILLIAM GREENHIEL was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 3d. the property of
Andrew Hogarth, from his person.

ANDREW HOGARTH (green-grocer, Charles-street, Stepney.) On the afternoon of 7th of April I was passing by a booth in Stepney fair with my child—I felt something at my pocket, turned, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand, gathering it up, and making his way into the crowd—I took him by the arm—he dropped it, I picked it up—I had it just before to wipe the child's face with—I took the prisoner nearly to the station, and met a policeman.

HENRY STAMMER (police-constable K 315.) At the station, I said to the prisoner, "Have you got anything about you?"—he said, "No"—I felt be
tween his shirt and his back, and pulled out this handkerchief—it is partly silk and partly cotton—he said he did not steal it, a boy gave it him outside—there was a mob of two or three hundred persons outside.
Prisoner's Defence. The boy told me to mind it for him, and he would give me 1d. when I came back. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Confined Fourteen Day.

1293.
SELINA SEARCH was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Joseph William Clark.

EMMA SHEPLEY . I am sixteen years old, and live in Villiers-street, Strand. On the 9th of April I was in Mr. Clark's, the pawnbroker's shop, in Long-acre, in one of the tide boxes—the prisoner was behind me—there was a looking-glass opposite—I saw the prisoner get on a box, take a pair of boots, and place them under her shawl—I told Simons—she dropped the boots, I believe—I saw him take them—there was twenty minutes between her taking them down and her being taken into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you standing? A. in the box—the glass is on a chimney-piece—I went to pawn something—I did not see the things drop—I heard them—I went into the shop to call the young man—I did not know the prisoner before.

JOHN FREDERICK SIMONS . I am in the service of Joseph William Clark. From information I received from Shepley, I called a constable—I told the prisoner she had stolen a pair of boots—she dropped them on the floor, from under her shawl—I picked them up, and gave them to the constable—when she was given into custody, she said, "You must be mistaken, young man"—they had hung on a line, about eight feet from the ground—the box on which it is represented she must have stepped is two feet high, and then they would be within her reach.

Cross-examined. Q. How do yon know them? A. By our private mark—(looking at them)—they were fastened to the line, swung over by a string—Shepley was about a yard and a half from the boots—a short person could see in the glass what passed—a tall person could not—there was no
thing to prevent a person in the shop from seeing the woman on the box.
WILLIAM BOYCE (police-constable F 71.) I went to the shop, and saw Simons stoop down and pick up a pair of boots—I took the prisoner into custody—she said Simons was quite mistaken.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you swear you saw the boots drop? A. I am quite certain—they could not have dropped from the string, they would not have fallen on that spot, but a yard and a half from it. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—
Confined Three Weeks.

1294.
CHARLES ROURKE and
JOHN SAUNDERS were indicted for
stealing 1 coat, value 1l.; 1 pair of gloves, 6d.; 1 watch, 1l.; and 1 watch
stand stand, 3s. 6d.; the goods of
John Dimock Aspland; and that Rourke had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES DUGARD . I am a livery stable-keeper at Dalston. On the 3rd of April, about a quarter to eleven o'clock in the forenoon, I was standing at the corner of a public-house near my premises—I went to a window, which commanded a view of Mr. Aspland's place—I saw Rourke go to the side gate—Saunders stood outside—I fetched the man who had given me the information, and went back with him to mv own house—in a few minutes Rourke came out again, with a coat on, buttoned up to the top—Saunders came up to him, pulled up the collar, and smoothed down the back—I went out and met the prisoners—Rourke's hands were in his great-coat pockets—I seized him—he tried to get away, and fell—I fell with him—I held him—my companion seized Saunders—they were given into custody, and searched—while Rourke was being searched, I saw a watch drop from him—the constable took the coat off his back directly he came—this is it—(produced.)

ELIZA ALLEN . I am in the service of John Dimock Aspland, of Rich
mond-row, Dalston. This watch, the watch-stand and coat are my master's property—I had seen the coat in the passage, and the watch on the man
tel-piece about a quarter of an hour before—they could get to the room by climbing over the wall and getting in at the kitchen door—I did not hear the kitchen door shut—it was shut after the prisoners—they came into the kitchen and through the passage.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-constable N 69.) On the 3rd of April, I saw the prisoners together in the Kingsland-road close to the prosecutor's house—I afterwards went to Richmond-road—the prisoners were given in my charge—Rourke had then a different coat—I took it from his back—the prisoners were searched in the public-house—I saw Rourke drop a watch—I picked it up—this latch-key was found under the sleeve of Saunders's coat—the gloves were in the pocket of the coat.

Rourke's Defence. I was passing the house, and wanted to go to the water-closet; I saw the gate open, went in, and saw the coat there doubled up; I came and told the young man; he told me to put it on; 1 found the watch too.
Saunders's Defence. Rourke went down the turning and came and told me there was a coat lying there; he went back and put it on; it was all over dust and ashes.
MICHAEL COMBY (police-constable H 138.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner Rourke's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present at the trial—he is the person described.
(Miles Costello, of No. 5, Green-bank, Tooley-street, and Mrs.——, gave Rourke a good character.)

ROURKE—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

SAUNDERS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined for Six Months.

1295.
THOMAS BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 kettle, value 4s., and 1 copper, value 14s.; the goods of
William Gardner, and fixed to a certain building.

WILLIAM GARDNER . I am a broker, and live in Rose and Crown-court, Moorfields. On Sunday the 7th of April, between three and four o'clock, I saw my copper fixed in my washhouse—my copper tea-kettle was there safe—next morning I found the copper had been pulled down and taken away, and the kettle was missing—these are them—(produced.)

WILLIAM TILLIER (police-constable G 28.) On Monday morning at half-past six o'clock, I was on duty in Old-street, St. Luke's, and saw the prisoner carrying a kettle—another lad was with him carrying a copper. I asked the

prisoner where he was going—he Said to No. 9, Goswell-street—I said that will not do—I took him to Bunhill-row—the prisoner threw down the copper, and the other the kettle—I pursued and took the prisoner, but the other escaped.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was not what the prisoner said that he was going to Goswell-street? A. Yes—I asked him where—he said, No. 9—I swear I said that before the Magistrate—this is my writing—(looking at his deposition)—it is not here—he said the other met him and asked him to carry it for him into Gosling-street, and he would give him 3d.—he afterwards said he met him in the Haymarket, Whitechapel.

HENRY PECK . I am employed in a wholesale Berlin warehouse in Cheap
side, and carry on business for myself at Kingsland—the prisoner was in my employ, up to the time he was taken into custody, eighteen months altogether—I had given him a holiday on Easter Monday—to the best of my belief Old-street is a quarter of a mile from where the copper was taken from—he was on his way to me to ask for another day's holiday.
WILLIAM TILLIER , re-examined. I knew the other lad to be associated with thieves—he has kept out of the way—I know the prisoner by sight—I know no wrong of him.
NOT GUILTY .

1296.
JOHN DRURY was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 6d. the goods of
James Stocken.

JAMES STOCKEN . I am potman at the Craven Arms, Queen's-road, Bays
water. I missed a pair of blucher boots from the top of a beer-tray in the yard—they were safe a little before ten o'clock—I saw the prisoner in the tap-room that day after three o'clock—about six o'clock I taw the prisoner and John King together—King had got the boots—I asked the prisoner how he came by them—he said, "A man gave them to me crossing the fields."

JOHN KING . I am a potman at the Oraren Arms. I saw the prisoner in the tap-room—he had a flag basket with him—he went out—I afterwards beard Stocken had lost his boots—I met the prisoner in Queen's-road with the boots concealed under his jacket—I asked what he had got—he said, nothing belonging to me—I asked him to give me the boots—he said, "I have got no boots"—I said, "Let me look"—he unbuttoned his jacket, and took the boots out—I said, "They are not mine, they are my fellow-servant's"—he said, "B—your eyes, if you don't let go of me I will smash you"—I let go, but being surrounded with a mob of people he could not go—he was 100 or 200 yards from the Craven Arms—the boots were ten or twelve yards from the tap-room close to the bar parlour window.
Prisoner. I said if you came with me I would show you who gave them me. Witness. No, you said you would show me the man that gave you the handkerchief.

JOHN LODDER (police-constable D 207.) I took the prisoner into custody—he was not much the worse for liquor—King delivered the boots to me—the prisoner tried to get away, but tome people came to my assistance—he tried to kick my legs.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner 11 Defence. A man in the Craven Arms bought half a gallon of beer; after I drank, I went to sleep, and never awoke till ten minutes after five o'clock; the men were then all gone out; just outside the door, I met one of them, named Peter Ashburn; he said, "Jack, if you go across the field you will find an old pair of boots in the hedge, and we will have some more beer," which I did.

JAMES STOCKEN
re-examined. There were some more men in the tap-room—he was not in the tap-room after four o'clock.

JOHN KING
re-examined. He told me nothing about the boots being in the ditch—he was coming away from the field, going away from the public-house.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Month ,

1297.
THOMAS KERR,
SARAH ROSE , and
SARAH LAMB were indicted for
stealing 1 bonnet, 1s.; 1 cap, 3d.; 1 pair of boots, 3d.; and 1 book, 1s.; the goods of
Henry Kerr: and 1 pair of shoes, 6d.; the goods of
Ellen Kerr; and that Lamb had been previously convicted of felony.

JAMES WOOD (police-constable M 227.) On the 8th of April I saw the three prisoners in East-street, Hoxton, coming from the City-road—the females had no cap or bonnet on their heads—they went to No. 13, East-road together—Kerr knocked at the door—the female prisoners then left him, and waited six or seven yards off—he was let in immediately after—I watched the women—after he had been in about a minute he came to the door, and let them in—when they had been in six or seven minutes Rose came out, and looked round to see if she could see any one—not seeing any one she went to the door again, and the other two came out, joined her, and all came away together—Lamb had a bonnet and cap on—I took another constable with me, followed, took them into custody sixty or seventy yards off, and brought them to the station—on Rose I found this bonnet, pair of boots, book, and collar, and a book, cap, and pair of shoes on Lamb—I said, "What are you going to do with the boots?"—she said she brought them from home, and was going to take them to pawn—she said she had them given her in St. Luke's workhouse, and the collar was her brother's, that she had brought from home—No. 13 is the house of Kerr's father.
Rose. The collar belonged to me; I did not mention my brother; I have do brother; he has said several times he will get me transported.

ELLEN KERR . I am the prisoner's sister. I live with my father, Henry Kerr, at No. 13, East-row, Hoxton—I do not know the female prisoners—this bonnet, cap, pair of boots, and book are my sister's—she is not here—I do not know why—on the day this happened I and my sister were gone to a tea party in the City—I returned home about ten o'clock—the persons up stairs were at home to let in my brother—all the family were out that evening—the collar belongs to my youngest brother—my brother always lives with my father—the family do not allow him to take any thing to pawn that I know of.

Kerr. Q. What do you swear to the boots by? A. Because there are no tags on them—there is no mark on them—they only appear like—I know the bonnet to be my sister's—I can confidently swear to it—my own is the same pattern—I never knew my sister allow you to pledge things.

Prisoner Kerr. This case is not prosecuted with my father's consent; she has come here to try to get me transported, if possible. My mother said, if I promised not to do any thing of the sort again, she would not do anything.

Rose's Defence. I met Kerr at the end of Pitfield-street. He asked us to go home with him: we would not: he said, "I don't care about your coming, to long as Lamb comes." I followed him. He said, "Wait at the corner till I see if any one is at home." He took us down in the kitchen, and said, "Don't make such a noise;" the bonnet was hanging up; he gave it to Lamb; he gave me the boots from under the table; he said, "My sister will not wear them." He took Lamb into the parlour, and wanted her to take the table-cloths out of the drawers; he said, he wanted to serve the old rogue out;—I ran out of the passage; he might have called a policeman if he did not want us in; he said, "Don't go out till we all go out together;" he said, "I can't get any money."

THOMAS BROWN (City police-constable, No. 215.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner Lamb's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present at the trial—she is the person.

KERR—
GUILTY .* Aged 17.

ROSE—
GUILTY .* Aged 17.

LAMB—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

1298.
ELLEN LEARY was indicted
for stealing 2 half-crowns, 1 shil
ling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
William Verron, from his person.

WILLIAM VERRON , smith, Jubilee-place, Stepney. On the night of the 8th of April, between twelve and one, I was in a cook's shop in Whitechapel-road, and bad a basin of soup and potatoes—the prisoner was there, and asked me for one—I said she might take the whole—she followed me out, laid hold of my arm, and wanted me to give her something—she said I could go with her for 4d.—I was there three or four minutes—she followed me out again, and put her hands inside my trowsers—she kept putting her hand in—when she had taken all she wanted, she said, "Good night," or, "Good morning," and walked off—I missed my money, followed her, saw a police
man, and told him—the money was two new half-crowns, one shilling, and a sixpence; but whether they were new or not I could not say—I said, "That is the woman"—she said, "Don't take me," then took out a bit of rag, threw out two half-crowns, and the policeman took them up—I was sober.

JANE SCOTT . I am the wife of William Scott, a police-serjeant—the pri
soner was brought to Stepney station—I went to search her—she said she had nothing belonging to the man at all—I found two fourpenny pieces in her pocket—she said, "That is all I have, belonging to the man."

ROBERT BACKHOUSE (police-constable K 37.) I went with Verron to Nel
son-court, Whitechapel-road, between one and two o'clock, and found the pri
soner there—the prosecutor charged her with stealing two half-crowns, one shilling, and a sixpence—she put her hand into her bosom, pulled out a white handkerchief, threw two half-crowns on the table, and said, "So help me God, that is all I took from him"—the prosecutor bad told me, they were new half-crowns—these are apparently fresh.

Prisoner's Defence. He went with me to the house, and wanted to take impro
per liberties with me; he gave me two half-crowns; he looked about, said he was a married man, and he was afraid his wife would find it out; he wanted the money back; I would not give it him; he went with me to the house where I first met with him, and sat by the fire; came back and gave me in charge before I could have spent the rest of the money; I never said, "So help me God, that is all I took from him."

ROBERT BACKHOUSE
re-examined. I am sure she used the expression, "took from him."

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Six Months.

1299.
JOHN HARRIS was indicted
for stealing 1 carpenter's tool, called a mortise-gauge, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
John Wells.

THOMAS JOLLIFFE . I am shopman to John Wells, pawnbroker, Adam's-row, Hampstead-road. On the 9th of April I saw the prisoner, and ano
ther, in front of the shop—in consequence of something a woman told me, I went after them, and came up to them in Adam's-row—they were still together I saw the person the prisoner was with, give him this mortise-gauge—I fol
lowed the prisoner—he ran—when I was close behind him, he threw the gauge under a cart—a sweep picked it up, and gave it me—I caught him in Crescent-street, Euston-square—he said, "Pray, forgive me this once"—he
was taken to the station—this is Mr. Wells's property—it was placed on a tray in front of the shop—my attention was drawn off by another party, and that enabled a person to take it.
JOHN FIELDER COOK (police-constable S 65.) I took the prisoner—he said, "Mr. Wells, I hope you will forgive me."

GUILTY . Aped 20.—
Confined One Month.

1300.
CHARLES JONES and
EDWARD KELLY were indicted for
stealing 1 eye-glass, value 10s., the goods of
William Wood, from the person of
Sarah Wood.

SARAH WOOD . I am the wife of William Wood, who is in the Excise. We live in Lucas-street—on Monday, the 8th of April, I was in Stepney fair—I had a geld eye-glass round my neck suspended by a ribbon—I felt a tug at my ribbon, and a crash of the ribbon cutting—I turned and said to Jones, "You have got my glass"—he said, "No, I have not"—I said, "You have given it to somebody"—he said, "No"—I told the policeman—he took hold of them—Kelly said, "Here is the glass; I was just going to give it to the lady."

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. There were other persons by at the time? A. Yes—it was in a crowd—I did not observe any body push Kelly away at the time he said he was going to give it me—there was a com
motion in the crowd—I did not turn round—he was in front of me—I took, hold of him—I did not see him take it.
COURT. Q. Did you hear his hand on your ribbon? A. Yes, and saw his hand moving—that was Jones—Kelly handed up the glass.

HENRY HUTTON (police-constable K 60.) I was passing through the fair, and saw the prisoners and a third party—I saw the prosecutrix have hold of Jones by the arm—she said, "You have got my glass; give it me"—he said he had not—the prosecutrix said, "That other boy is with him"—I caught hold of Kelly—he said "Here is the glass; I was just going to give it to the lady; I have just picked it up"—I took them to the station—I found on Kelly 1s. a box, and the glass, and a knife, and on Jones 3s. and 1s. 11 1/4 d. in copper, a box, tobacco-stopper, and a handkerchief—Jones said he knew nothing about it, he had just come out of a swing—the ribbon was cut—it was a stout ribbon—the knife I found was shut.
Cross-examined. Q. This was all the work of a minute? A. Yes—the third boy got away.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

KELLY—
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Confined Three Months.

1301.
JAMES ADAMS and
FRANCIS COLSELL were indicted for
stealing 1 bag, value 1s.; half a bushel of oats, 1s. 6d.; and half a peck of beans, 8d.; the goods of
Robert Gamman and another, the masters of
James Adams.

GEOROE MURRAY (police-constable K 68.) On the 29th of March I ob
served the prisoner Colsell and a wagon in the Commercial-road—he had this bag, containing another bag with oats—he walked in a direction from the wagon—I said, "What have you got there?"—he said, "Ducks'food"—I asked where he got it from—he said, "That man driving the wagon gave it me to take home to Exmouth-street"—he called out to the prisoner Adams to stop—I went across the way with him—I said, "Do you know this man, have you given him this bag?"—he said, "Yes, I have"—I said, "You ought to know better, an old man like you robbing your employers"—he said he found the food in the loft, and was going to send it home—I asked if he had got any rabbits—he said he had not, he had ducks—I took them into

custody, and took Adams to hit master's wharf—he then said he found the food with oats in the loft—the bag that Colsell was carrying contained 28lbs. weight of oats and one nose-bag—I took a sample of oats from a bin on the premises of Messrs. Gamman, and compared them—in my judgment they are exactly alike—Mr. Gamman's name was on the wagon—I searched a place in Exmouth-court, where Adams said he lived, and found some split-beans—there was a pig and some ducks there—it was the place Colsell said he was going to carry them to.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I believe Adams said he found the bag in the loft and took it away? A. Yes—the oats are here—I looked out the oats that I have produced as a sample.

ROBERT GAMMAN . I am in partnership with my father, Robert Gamman, coal merchant, Wapping-wall. The prisoner Adams was carman to the firm—he was sent out early in the morning before I was there—Colsell was em
ployed by Adams to assist him—we allow him to employ who be likes to help him—the nose-bag produced is one of ours—we never allow our servants to take raw oats—I have compared these with the bulk, and believe them to be the same—I have been in the business eight years, and have been con
stantly in the habit of looking at these sort of things—I cannot say whether when our carman has his helper if he comes to the wharf, he might tell the other man to meet him—it generally requires two to go with the cart.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to swear positively to these oats being your property? A. No—I have compared them—I believe them to be the same quality—I do not say they are the best oats—he had no business with five nose-bags full) of oats—he had four horses.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

ADAMS—
GUILTY .
Confined Six Weeks ,

COLSELL—
NOT GUILTY .

1302.
ALEXANDER CAMPBELL was indicted
for feloniously re
ceiving of a certain evil disposed person, 4 pieces of leather, value 4s.: the goods of
William Henry Palmer, well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM HENRY PALMER , boot-maker, Henry-street, Manchester-square. On 1st March I cut four pieces of leather, to make a pair of boots—I missed them—I questioned my son about them—he said he had given them to the prisoner—I have since seen the leather.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had you promised to forgive your son, if he told you? A. Yes.

JOHN QUINLAN PALMER . I am fourteen years old. On the evening of the 1st March I was at Mrs. White's cookshop, Henrietta-street, St. James's—the prisoner was there—he asked me if I could get anything to sell—I said I could go and get four pieces of leather out of my father's drawer—he said, "Go, and get them," and he would sell them—I got them, and asked him to get as much as he could—he said the man would only give him 6d.—he gave me the sixpence, and I gave him 2d. out—he said he sold it to Mr. Bolls—I went to a coffee-shop, and bought a roll, a cup of coffee, and a penny
worth of butter—I did not get it at home, because ray mother would not give me any—she said there was only enough for the little children—my father said he would for
give me, if I told him the truth.

Cross-examined. Q. 1 think you have been before the Magis
trate? A. That was through other boys leading me away—I had a month's imprison
ment—I should not have taken the leather if I had not been hungry—I did

not know I was doing wrong—the leather was not taken out of the drawer before I met the prisoner—he was with me when I spent the money—he did not have any of the coffee—I gave him 2d.,—I did not offer to tell my father till he spoke to me.

JOHN VORLEY . I live in John's-court. The prisoner came to me with some leather—I do not recollect when—it was a wet night—he wanted to know "whether I would buy it—I said, "No," they were of no use to me—they were not worth more than 9d.—he took them away, came again in about ten minutes, and said, "I suppose I must have it, for they have been in the box long enough, and we want something for supper"—I went to my leather-cutter, Mr. Penton, and sold them for 1s.—I got 3d. on them—I considered the pri
soner an honest young man—I knew him as a customer—in fact, if he had come to me, I would have given him employment—they are what they call cuttings, the fragments that are cut off chairs—you can buy it at 20d. per lb., and I had given after the rate of 2s.

SAMUEL CHESTER (police-constable D 103.) I found the prisoner at the corner of Henrietta-street, St. James's-street—I told him Mr. Palmer gave him into custody—I said, "I suppose you know all about it?"—he said, "Yes, his father spoke to me about it yesterday"—I took him to the station—Mr. Vorley came to me with the leather.

WILLIAM HENRY PALMER
re-examined. I saw the prisoner about this—I said, "You have been going on again with my young gentleman, I have caught you at last"—he said, "How the devil was I to know that he stole it from you? go to h—ll, and be b——."
Prisoner's Defence. It is my leather; it was all one piece before I put the knife to it; it is worth 3s. 6d. or 4s. now.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq,

1303.
MARY KEENE was indicted
for stealing 25 yards of linen cloth, value 15s. 7d. the goods of
William Devas and others.
MR. HORRY conducted the Prosecution,

RICHARD SILLETT . I am porter to William Devas and Sons, warehouse
men, Lawrence-lane, Cheapside. On the 22nd of March I delivered this parcel to George Garratt—the address on it is "Mr. T. Naylor, High-street, Mary le bone."

GEORGE GARRATT . I am in the service of Mr. Taylor, of Carlile-street, 3 Paddington—I drive an omnibus. On the 22nd of March I received a parcel from Sillett—this is the paper that was round it—the parcel has been untied since—I gave it to my conductor to keep it from getting wet.

WILLIAM SIOSTON . I was the conductor—I received a parcel from Gar
ratt on the 22nd of March—I believe this to be it—I recollect the prisoner getting into the omnibus, about five minutes past eleven o'clock in the fore
noon, at John-street, Oxford-street—she desired to be set down at Berkley
place, or Berkley-street, Edgware-road—she went there, and then she went on to Burwood-place, which is a little further—she was she last passenger—I Jet her out, and as soon as I got on the omnibus again, and looked inside, I missed this parcel—I had left it inside, near the door, on the cushion—there had been persons in the omnibus when I put it in—I followed the prisoner, and found it under her arm—it was under her shawl—I saw one end of it—I said to her, "I am surprised that a person of your respectable appearance should be guilty of taking a parcel out of an omnibus"—she gave it up imme
diately, and told me she took it in mistake for a parcel of her own—she had
a parcel of her own when she got in, and the said the took that for her own—I said a great many robberies had taken place in omnibuses, and I felt it my duty to give her in charge.

Cross-examined by MB. CLARK SON. Q. Was it tied up as it is now? A. It has been opened, but the same paper is on it—I should judge it to be linen—she told me she had bought three dresses in Vine-street, Oxford-street, and it turned out that she had done so.

MICHAEL BRIGHT (police-constable D 106.) I was called to take the pri
soner—she said she had bought a parcel of three merino dresses in Oxford street, but she could not tell the shop—that she had a parcel when she went into the omnibus, and this parcel she must have taken in mistake—Knowles brought me this other parcel.

EPHRAIM KNOWLES . I am in the service of Burrell and Co., in Vine-street—they are drapers—the prisoner has been a customer of my master's ever since I have been there, which is nearly five years—I remember the morning on which she was taken into custody, as she had come to our shop and bought three dresses—they were put up in this parcel—I was examined before the Magistrate on this prosecution—a person named Leland was ex
amined and bound over, but he has not attended.
JURY. Q. Did she give any direction? A. She merely said if she did not call, we were to send the parcel, as she was going further.
NOT GUILTY .

1304.
JOHN SPENCE was indicted
for stealing 3 shillings, 5 sixpences, and 1 groat; the monies of
Richard Reynolds, from his person.

RICHARD REYNOLDS . I live in the Commercial-road. On the 10th of April I was employed as waiter at the Prince of Wales public-house at Stepney fair—the prisoner and two or three others came around me, and pushed me about—the prisoner put his hand into my right waistcoat-pocket, and took 4s. 10d. in silver, which I had counted not five minutes before—I saw his hand come out of my pocket, and he passed it to somebody else—I put my hand to my pocket, and the money was gone—I immediately caught hold of him, and said, "You have robbed me "—I held him till the policeman came.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Were there not a number of persons scuffling about? A. Not all of them—there were some pushing about—the prisoner had been drinking—I am certain I was sober—the prisoner came and spoke some nonsense first, and then he and two or three others pushed me about—there were forty or fifty persons present, but not more than three or four standing up about me.
WILLIAM MARCHING (police-constable K 379.) I took the prisoner—I found nothing on him but a knife.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

1305.
HENRY BURGESS was indicted for
stealing 1 gun, value 10l.; 2 gun-cases, 1l. 10s.; 1 shot-belt, 3s.; 1 flask, 3s.; 1 punch, 1s. 6d.; 1 cleaning-rod, 3s.; 2 screw-drivers, 1s. 6d.; 2 brushes, 1s.; 1 wrench,1s. 6d.; and 1 gun-stock, 3l.; the goods of
Charles Eggand another: and
THOMAS OLDHAM and
THOMAS CONNER
for feloniously receiving the same, well know
ing them to have been stolen.

CHARLES EGG . I am partner with my brother Henry; we are gun
makers, and live in Piccadilly. On the 1st of April, about ten o'clock in the morning I missed a gun, and case, and part of another gun—the gun-case had been on the rack in my. shop—I had seen them safe on Saturday the 30th of March.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARK SON. Q. Had you looked at the gun on the 30th of March? A. No, I saw the case there—I cannot rightly say when I had seen the gun in the case—perhaps ten days before.

WILLIAM JOHN BIRD . I am a broker, and live in Exmouth-street, Spa
fields. On the night of the 2nd of April, I saw all the prisoners—Burgess came first to my shop about half-past eight o'clock—I knew him before—he said, there was a double gun, and part of another gun to be sold—I asked whose they were, and where they were to be seen—he said, "Never mind that; if you will come with me I will shew you them "—I said I had not bad my tea, I could not go then, and said, "I don't like to go out after these things; can't you bring them to my house?"—he said, No, the land
lord of the place where they were, had advanced 2l. on them, and therefore he could not bring them to my house—I agreed to meet him opposite Day and Martin's, in Holborn, and I met him about nine o'clock—he told me to follow him—he took me to the Archers public-house, in Newton-street, Holborn, which, I believe, is kept by Oldham—I saw him behind the bar, serving—I saw Conner there, and two other persons, who have escaped—Burgess intro
duced me, and said I was, the person about the guns—after waiting some time, I went to the front of the bar, and stood there about two minutes—the other two men spoke to Oldham about showing me the gun—he said, "Presently, presently "—I waited about, and at last Burgess and the two men not in cus
tody asked me to go into the tap-room—I sat there some time—at last one of the other two men told Connor to get a light—Connor got a light, pulled the tap-room door to after him, and shut me in the tap-room with Burgess and the other two men—I felt rather uneasy, and I opened the tap-room door, as if I was going out—I then saw a gun-case wrapped in a bit of serge come up through a trap-door in the passage—Conner took it up stairs—Burgess and I and the other two went up stairs to the back-room on the first floor—the gas had just been lighted—Conner brought the gun, and put it on the table—he then went and waited outside the door—I remained in the room with Burgess and the other two men—I examined the gun, and said that would do—this is it—(looking at it)—it was then wrapped up in the same piece of serge, and given to Conner—I and Burgess and the other two men walked downstairs—Burgess said, "Come on "—he and I and the other two men went to Parker-street, Drury-lane—one of the other two men tapped at the window of a room there—he said his mother was out, but he would go and get the key—he went to another house, next door but one, and brought down a key-bugle—we went into the room, and there they showed me part of a double gun in a mahogany gun-case, a gun-stock, and part of a lock—we then all went back again—Burgess wished me to purchase the things that night—I said I could not that night—I was to give twelve guineas for the key-bugle and the two guns—next morning, at nine o'clock Burgess came to me and I appointed to meet him again at Day and Martin's, which I did—he asked me what was the most I would give for them—I said I should not give more than 10l. or ten guineas—he said he would go and see—he then went to the Archers—the other two men came out, and were walking up and down for some time—Burgess then came and told me it was finally agreed; they were all ready, and I was to give these other two men 9l.—I said, "What about the 2l. that Oldham has lent on the guns? I am not going to pay that "—he said, "You must, or you won't have them"—I then agreed to give the other two men 9l., and Burgess was to ride home in a cab with me, and take the difference of the ten guineas—I was to give him 5s. for his trouble—he then went to the house, and came and told me every thing was ready—I said, "Well, I had got the money"—he said, "Come up stairs"—I and he and the

other two men went up stain to the same room—I looked at the guns, and saw they were the same, and while I was looking at them, the policemen, to whom I had given information, came in—they fought desperately, and the other two men run away—Oldham came running up, and said, "What is the matter?" and Archer seized him.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had yon ever been out with Bur
gess before? A. I do not think I ever had—I do not like to be certain—he was to have the difference between 9l., and ten guineas, and 5s. for help
ing to close the bargain—which would be 35s.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was not Connor the pot-man at the public-house? A. I think he was—he was sitting in the tap-room, looking me in the face—I made no bargain to give him anything—they did not lock the tap-room door on me—they did the door up stairs.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you ever been in that pub
lic-house before? A. I never had—all I saw of Oldham was at the bar, except on the morning of the affray.

WILLIAM BARTON (police-inspector.) On Tuesday night, the 2nd of April, Bird gave me information—next morning I went with two officers to the Archers', in Newton-street, Holborn—I saw Oldham in the house—I told him I was an inspector of police, and that there was something wrong up stairs—I ordered one man to stand at the door, and let no one out—I went up stairs and found Burgess and two other men, two gun cases, a gun and a stock—there was a general rush—I secured Burgess—one of the other men jumped out of window, and the other ran down stairs—I ran out and met Oldham on the stairs—he asked me what was the matter—I told him he knew very well.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you known Bird before? A. Yes, for ten or twelve years, as a respectable tradesman.

Cross-examined by MB. PAYNE. Q. Connor was not taken at that time? A. No—he was taken on the Tuesday following—he was allowed to go on his own recognizance—we took Oldham as soon as we could get from Bow-street.

JOHN ARCHER (police-sergeant E 8.) On the morning of the 3rd of April I went with inspector Barton to the house in Newton-street—I went up stairs—we found the back-room door fastened—we knocked, and it was opened—I took Burgess and another by the collar—one of the others got out of the window, and the other ran down stairs—I called on Oldham to assist, but he did not.

JOHN FINK (police-constable E 47.) I went to Oldham's house, and was placed at the door—after some time Mr. Barton came down—I saw Archer with two prisoners—I went to his assistance, and was knocked down by one of the persons who made his escape.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant,

div1.p:
1306.
JOHN KEBBLE and
JAMES PEBBLE were indicted for
steal
ing 9 scarfs, value 4l., the goods of
William Higgins and another; and that they had been previously convicted of felony.

WILLIAM OWEN . I am shopman to William and Thomas Higgins, of Bond-street—we sell scarfs, &c. Both prisoners have been in the habit of coming to the shop—I saw them early in Feb., and after they bad been there I missed some scarfs—I believe all these produced to be my master's—this one I know by a cut—I believe alt the others to be theirs.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did not one of the prisoners buy the one that you know by sight? A. No, he did buy one—I know this most particularly by the cut—I had seen the men on the premises before Feb.—these scarfs were taken at different times—they might have been taken at one time without my knowing it, but I should think not.
ARTHUR NORTH . I produce a scarf pawned by James Keppel on the 10th of Feb.

WILLIAM BOWN , assistant to Mr. Rochford, pawnbroker, Brewer-street, Golden-square. I produce nine scarfs, one pledged by James, on the 22nd of March—the others were taken by our young man—I am certain he is the person.

JAMES HARMAN , pawnbroker. I produce three scarfs. The prisoner James pledged one by himself on the 12th of Feb.—the second time, the 15th of Feb., they were both in company, and pledged two scarfs, but which took the money I cannot say.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you recollect the two coming together? A. Yes I do, on more occasions than this.

JOHN FREDERICK SIMMONDS . I produce two scarfs pledged by the pri
soner James on the 22nd of Feb.
(property produced and sworn to.) GEORGE GATIER (police-constable F 23.) I produce a certificate of both the prisoners former conviction—(read)—they are the persons.

JOHN KEBBLE—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

JAMES KEBBLE—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

1307.
EDWARD PROCTER and
JOHN MELLSON were indicted for
stealing 1 mare, price 12l., the property of
James Barford.

JAMES BARFORD , straw-plait dealer, Wilderness-row, Clerkenwell. I had a mare pony for sale at Robinson's depository, Little Britain. On the 31st of August, about four o'clock in the afternoon, it was brought into the yard—the prisoner Mellson came to me—he said, "Is that your pony?"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "It appears to be a very nice one; what do you want for it?"—I said, 14l.—he said, "Is it quiet and sound?"—I said, "Yes"—he said, would I go along with him to his friend; and I accordingly went with him to the Red Lion, King Edward-street—he introduced me to Procter—Procter said, "I understand you have got a mare pony to sell"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "I should like to see it"—I returned to Robinson's depository, and fetched it—it was trotted up and down—Procter came out, and offered me 12l.—I would not take it—he offered me 12l. 10s., and I closed for it—we went into the Red Lion—the pony was in the street at the time with a person who held it—Procter said he did not intend to buy a horse that day, and had not got cash enough; in fact, he bad not got any with him—I said I should not take anything but money—he said, if I would go with him to Newington Causeway, to his lodging, I should find he had money—Mellson said, "Don't let that binder you, 1 will give you the money for a note of hand"—he took out of his pocket a load of Bank of England notes, as I believed they were—I agreed to go to Newington for the money—I never agreed to take a bill or note of hand—we went to Procter's lodging—just before we got there, they both wanted to put the mare into a stable—Procter said it was his stable—they pulled a bell—a person came—I said, "I will not have the mare put in here, I will have the money first"—it

was taken and set right before Procter's lodgings, at the parlour window—we went into the house—the same man was with it—Mellson said, "I must go and get a stop"—I did not know what that was—Procter drew it up—he said, "I am very short of cash, I shall draw this note of hand for 12l., if it don't make any difference to you"—I said, "I shan't part with the mare without the money"—in the mean time Proctor was drawing the bill—Mellson took a saddle and bridle down, and put it on the mare—Procter gave me a note of hand and half-a-sovereign—we all left the lodging—Mellson said, "Come along to the George, and I will give you the money for the note of hand"—I said, "Very well"—I bad not parted with the property at that time—I left the mare with Procter, standing in front of the window—I never intended to part with it without the money—Mellson went on just before me—the man sung out, "Who is going to pay me for taking care of the mare?"—Procter gave him 1s.—I left Procter and him together, while I went with Mellson—he went in at the door of the George, and directly opposite there is another door leading into another street—he popped out there—I said to the landlord, "Is not there a gentleman resembling a horse-dealer here?"—he said, "He is just gone out at the other door"—'I did not find Procter or the mare—I looked out of the door Mellson had popped out of, and could see nothing of him—he must have gone very quick—I was not gone a minute and a half—Procter had gallopped off with the mare.

Crest-examined by MR. BALLANTINI. Q. Did yon give a receipt for the 10s.? A. No—I put my name on this paper—this is my name—I did not read it—I am no scholar—I supposed I was signing a receipt for the 10s.—I said I did not give a receipt, because I cannot write a receipt—I do not know that it was read to me—I believe it was—I have no doubt about it—I have told you the fact—Mellson got the stamp for this note of hand, not by my desire—it is a bill of exchange—it was read over to me—I signed it—I signed the bill at seven days, when I expected to be paid immediately, for security for Mellson—I have seen bills of exchange—I cannot read them—I have had them in my possession—I believe this is ac
cepted by Edward Procter—I saw him draw it, and accept it—the amount is 12l., and the date August 31st, 1843—I have been looking for the prisoners ever since—I could never get sight of them—I found them in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Had you ever sold a pony before? A. No—I have sold forty or fifty horses—I saw Procter very shortly after seeing Mellson—I saw him draw the bill—I took it for security for Mellson—I took it on the day it was due, I think on the Saturday following, to No. 36, Market-street, Newington Causeway—it was not paid—I have set after them to give them into custody ever since—I have spent more than 50l. about it.
GEORGB TEAKLB (police-sergeant.) I produce this note—I took Edward Procter into custody on another charge, at Cheyne-walk, Chelsea.

WILLIAM WYATT . I keep a beer-shop in Market-street, Borough. I re
member seeing Barford there seven or eight months back—I did not see either of the prisoners there.

PROCTER—
GUILTY . Aged 26.

MELLSON—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

1308.
JOHN PURDY was indicted
for a conspiracy.

AMELIA CHARLOTE LLOYD . I live in Henry-street, St. George's. On the 11th of Jan. I had a covered cart for sale—Purdy came to me and said he was desired by his master to look for a covered cart of that sort—he thought that would exactly suit him—he would go and bring another gentle-man—he

said his master was a woollen merchant—he did not say where—I told him the price was 15l.—in about an hour and a half he brought Procter, the pri
soner in the last case—I inquired whether that was the clerk to the woollen mer
chant—he said yes—Procter said his master was out of town—he asked to look at the cart—I showed it him—they examined it—Procter told the prisoner to try it—he asked if he thought it was strong enough—he said yes—they did not bring a horse—he took hold of the two shafts—I borrowed a horse, and they tried the cart—he said it would suit, but his master was out of town, and would not be in town till the Tuesday following, he was a very particular gentleman and liked to do business with the proprietor—he asked if I was the pro
prietor—I said yes—he asked if I would have any objection to take the cart to the gentleman's residence—I agreed to do so when he came in town—he said he would let me know when the gentleman did come—on the Wednes
day Purdy and Procter came again and asked me if I would bring it the following day—I agreed—Purday came at eleven o'clock next morning—he was to take me to the gentleman—he took me to St. Thomas's-street in the Borough—he got out of the cart and brought Procter to me—he began to scold me about detaining him so long, as it was one o'clock—I told him I bad had to run about to borrow the horse—he said "These things will happen in business "—he supposed he must excuse me to his master—he told me to follow him to his master—I turned to do so—he (Procter) said, "If you do not intend to take less than 15l. you had better ask a little more "—I said I was much obliged—he said, "It will make no difference to me, he bought a horse yesterday that will exactly suit your cart"—I said I would ask 16l.—he took me to his master, John Mellson, he knocked at the door, and Mellson opened it—he began to scold about being detained so long, as be had particular business in the City—he came out, looked at the cart, and asked Purdy if he thought it would suit, he examined the wheel and found some fault with it—I told him I had not brought him a new cart—he asked the price—I said 16l.—he went towards the cart and saw some iron on one of the shafts—he examined it—Purdy said it made it all the stronger—Mellson turned round to Procter and asked if it would suit—he said exceedingly well—I agreed to take 15l.—Procter said to Purdy, "John, you take the cart to the wheeler's"—I turned round to follow Procter to his residence, and left the cart—he said "Have you got a stamp receipt?"—I said, "Sir, I am provided with a receipt"—he said, "This is a common one, it is a sixpenny one "—" But it will do for 20l" said I—he said, "I want an eighteenpenny one, I will get one"—we knocked at the door—he ordered me to sit down, turned to the servant and told him to go out for something—I suppose for the receipt—I said he was a long time gone—he said, "He will be here presently "—there was a little passage to go down, and I heard him say, "14l. 10s., how foolish"—I said "I will not take less than 15l."—he said, "I will soon settle that, I will give you 10s."—I said, "Excuse me, but I understood you to say 14l. 10s."—he gave me a small bit of paper, which was lying on the table, and said, "I will get you to write a receipt for the 10s."—just as I was about to rise he put a bill on the table and said, "I will get you to write on this your name and residence"—I wrote it, and got up, I held my hand out for the money, and he put the bill into my hand—I said, "Sir, I expected the money"—he said, "This is the same as money, read it"—I said, "If I was to read it I don't understand anything about it"—I was very much confused and fright
ened—he said "This is as good as Bank of England money, he had just had a gentleman from the city there who owed him 200l.," and if I did not under
stand it to pay it away—I came out with my note in my hand—as we were coming out Purdy met us about the spot where I had left the cart—his master

desired him to see me to the bridge—the cart was gone at that time—I had sold it for money—I had no intention to take a bill whatever—I saw no more of them—I have been searching for them ever since—I traced my cart to Mr. Dowsett's—it was sold, I understand.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You were to agree to give some
thing to Purdy? A. Yes, at the time this was going on about the bill he was not present—when it was over he was coming up—he came and asked me if it was to sell—throughout the whole he appeared to be acting under the direction of Procter and Mellson.
COURT. Q. The contract was made before you want into the house, and you thought it was for ready money? A. Yes.

MART DICKENS . I am single and lire with my brother John in St. Tho
mas's-street. On the 10th of January I had a bill in my window for lodgings—Mellson and another man cane and took a bed-room, and asked for the use of a parlour—they told me they were engaged in the City the whole of the day, till about five o'clock in the evening—I do not know who the other man was—I have not seen him since—H was not Purdy—they came on Friday evening, and said, they had a letter requesting their immediate attendance in the country as a relation bad died and left them some money, they must go off by the first train, and would be there the following night—he did not return to pay me.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not the person that came with Mellson the per
son that you have since seen at Procter? A. I have not seen him—I did not tee him before the Magistrate.

CHRISTOPHER HOBMAN . I am a horse-dealer, and live in John-street Har
per-street, New Kent-road. On the 12th of January, about four o'clock in the afternoon, there was a cart in the street opposite my door—Mellson was with it—I have seen him before at fairs and markets—fee called on me, and asked if I would change with him for a lighter one—I said I could not—I bought it for 16l.—I do not know Procter at all—I sent it down to Mr. Dowsett's yard—I left word there that I had such a thing to part with—Mrs. Lloyd's foreman, Joseph Buck came and saw it—I did not know Mellton a a wool
len-draper—I think I should have known if he had been so—I alway con
sidered him to be dabbling about telling horses—I never saw any woollen goods with him.
JOHN DOWSETT . I am a wheelwright. On Saturday morning, the 11th or 12th of January, Mr. Hobman brought the cart to me—Mrs. Lloyd's fore-man came and identified it.

GEOROI TEAKLE (police-sergeant H 8.) On the 26th of Jan, Purdy. came to me, by appointment, on another charge not connected with this—I said I wanted him about a cart—he said, "What I did was on commission" I said, "I have no alternative but to take you before the Magistrate—he said, "I received 1s. in the pound, 13s. wat all that I had"—I know Mellson; but not as a woollen-merchant—I always considered him as a horse-dealer—I have seen him at Smithfield-market, and at fairs, in company with horse
dealers.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you called at hit lodging the night before and and saw his wife? A. She spoke to me—he asked me to let him go, and he would come to the office—I did not do to.

JOSEPH GLISSON BUCK . I am foreman to Mrs. Lloyd. On Sunday morn
ing I saw the cart at Dowsett's—it is Mrs. Lloyd's cart, I am quite sure.

JAMES ALLISTON . On the 10th of Dec. last I saw Mellson—he repre
sented

himself to be a wine-merchant, not a woollen-merchant—Purdy re
presented himself as the servant, and took me to Mellson as a wine-merchant.

WILLIAM ATKINSON . On the 28th of April last I saw Mellson—he repre
sented himself to be Thomas Buckmaster's servant.
THOMAS WARMINOTON . In Oct. last I knew a person of the name of Edward Procter—he represented himself to be a wine-merchant.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1309.
NORMAN BUCKMASTER PROCTER was indicted
for a con
spiracy.

JOHN WRIGHT . I live at Thames Bank, Westminster. In July I had a bone and cart to dispose of—the prisoner came and asked if I had got it to sell—I said I had—he said he was sent by his master, a wine-merchant, in the Mile-end-road, he wanted a horse, cart, and harness—I drove it that way—he ordered me to pull up, and said if I would drive down there he thought his master would buy it—I said if he thought his master would give a fair value for it I would drive it there—I agreed to give him 10s. if his master bought it—I went to No. 9, Percival-buildings—his master was not in—he said he would fetch him from the wine-vaults—presently a young gentleman, who I supposed to be his master, came up—it turned out to be Edward Proc
