ter—he said, "You are the gentleman that has got the' horse and cart to dis-pose of?"—he looked at it, and we agreed for twelve guineas—I expected to receive money and nothing else—neither bill nor money were mentioned—when we were at the stable he said, "If you will walk up to my residence I will settle with you"—I made several objections, because he wanted me to take a bill—the bargain was for guineas—I took the bill after some persua
sion—I sold the cart for this bill (produced) and 12s.—the money was never paid—the horse and cart was all I got my living by—I should never have on any terms accepted the bill but for the representation of his master being a wine-merchant and a gentleman.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. The person you were introduced to was an older person than the prisoner? A. No—he appeared to me to be about twenty-four or twenty-five—I think the prisoner appears a little older than seventeen—the person who was introduced as the master did not appear to be several years older than the servant—I will swear that Edward Procter, who was introduced as the master, did not appear to be five or six and twenty, and this person seventeen—I will not swear they both appeared of an age—it was very near St. Martin's-lane that the prisoner told me his master was a wine
merchant—I do not know the name of the street—I was first examined at Lambeth-street—it might be about the middle of July—I gave evidence against the prisoner on the 9th of Feb. last—I did not sign any depositions then—I was there several times—I first said the prisoner told me his master was a wine-merchant on the 9th of Feb—I was at Lambeth-street six times—I will swear positively I said something about his having told me his master was a wine-merchant on the first day.

GEORGE TEAKLE (police-sergeant H 8.) I know Edward Procter—I do not know that he is a wine-merchant—I always considered him as a horse
dealer—I have seen him frequenting the repositories, and Smithfield—he said he was a cattle-dealer—I have seen Norman Procter with him in or before July last—they were not taken before Feb., because I was not aware there was a case against them—the prisoner is the brother of the others.
Cross-examined. Q. Edward Procter is five or six and twenty? A. He
may be as much as three or four and twenty—the prisoner is not above seventeen.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Six Months.

1310.
THOMAS BUCKMASTER PROCTER was indicted
for a con
spiracy.

WILLIAM ATKINSON . I live in Little Warner-street, Clerken
well. On the 8th of April the prisoner, a man named Joe, and Mellson, came to my shed—Joe said he had brought two friends that were just going to begin the cow-keeping line—the prisoner looked at the cow, and asked the price—I said, 18l.—We went over the way, and had a pot of stout together—Mellson said he was the prisoner Thomas Buck master Procter's servant—he bid me 17l. 10s., for the cow—I agreed to let him have it—Joe said, "Come to my house at three o'clock, and take it to this cow-keeper's yard in the Mile-end-road"—we drove it to Mile-end—Mellson met us on the road, and we drove it into a cow-yard—we went to No. 9, Percival-buildings, Percivel-street, to take the money—the prisoner, Mellson, and Joe were there—we all went into the room together—the prisoner said he was disappointed in getting the money, but he would give me a bill—I said I was not in the habit of buying cows for bills, I paid ready money for my cows—Joe said, "It is right for 100l.," meaning Mr. Procter was worth 100l.—in consequence of that representation I agreed to take it—I should not have done so if Joe had not assured me he was worth so much money—he said Mellson was the servant—I had 2l. 10s. put down to me in gold—Mellson said he would get the bill cashed directly, he would go to a house in the Mile-end-road—Joe took me there—there was no cash there—I showed Teakle the cow-yard.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You got 2l. 10s., did not you? A. Yes—I signed a bill and a receipt for 15l., not for 17l. 10s.—this receipt is my writing—I got 2l. 10s. and this bill for the remainder—I am sure Mellson was there—it was as far back as April last—I have a distinct recollection that it was Mellson and not some other man, who said he was this man's servant—I had never seen him before—I have seen him since at Lambeth-street, and am sure he is the person—I have always been sure about it—I thought the bill was not right, and went to the house that night to see the parties—I did not go to the place where the bill was made payable, at the time it was due, nor after.
COURT. Q. For aught you know this may be a good bill, and will be paid to-morrow morning? A. I never presented it after it was due—I have made no inquiries about it since it was due.

WILLIAM PURKIS . On the 4th of July last I saw Mellson—he stated him
self to be a wine-merchant—the prisoner was with him—he said he was his servant—I had a horse—Mellson asked me whether I would sell it—he left Procter with me to take the horse up to No. 9—he went along with me—as he was going along he said he was the servant, and persuaded me to sell the horse to his master—I cannot tell whether I should have sold it if I had not believed him to be the servant—they both over persuaded me—I believed Mellson was the master, and was a wine-merchant—I got 5s. and a bit of paper for the horse—I went the day the bill was due—there was no money.

Cross-examined. Q. When and where was it the prisoner told you his master was a wine-merchant? A. When we were going along with the horse and cart—I am sure of that—I was questioned about it at Lambeth-street about twice—I did not say it at the first time—I cannot say how long afterwards I stated that he told me his master was a wine-merchant—it was about the

third time—I was had up about two months from the first examination, before the parties were committed—it was more than a month after—Mellson never told me he was the servant—Procter said so going along with the horse and cart, and also when I had the bill—Procter brought the bill, and put it on the table already written—I presented it at the same house I received it at on the day it was due—I did not understand that the bills are not payable till three days after date—I took it three or four times afterwards—I went a week after, and saw the landlady—they said he was out every time I went.

GEORGE TEAKLE (police-sergeant.) I know Procter and Mellson—Mell
son was not likely to keep a servant—he is a horse-jobber, and so is Procter—I have seen them together, acting as equals, not as wine-merchant and servant—I have made inquiries at each place—they left directly after.
Cross-examined. Q. Have yon known him several years as a cattle-dealer? A. Yes—I never had him in custody—I saw him frequently after I had been first employed, but I had forgotten he was concerned.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1311.
JOHN PAYNE was indicted
for a conspiracy.
NOT GUILTY .

1312.
WILLIAM PERRY was indicted for
stealing 12 boxes of patent medicine, called Dr. Freeman's Ointment, value 9s. 6d.; and 12 other boxes of ointment, 9s. 6d.; the goods of
William Henry Sutton and another, his masters: and
BENJAMIN EGLINTON and
PETER JORDAN
for feloniously receiving part of the same, knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

CHARLES THAIN (City police-constable, No. 19.) At ten minutes or a quarter past nine o'clock on the morning of the 21st of March, I saw the prisoner Jordan at the Eastern Counties Railway—I followed him to Eglinton's house, 1, Blossom-street—I observed that he had nothing in his hands, nor anything of a bulky appearance about his person—he went into Eglinton's house—a few minutes afterwards I saw Eglinton come through the passage from the direction of Shoreditch, or from Norton-Falgate, with a bundle tied up in a blue handkerchief under his left arm—he went round hit counter, untied the handkerchief, and handed a brown paper parcel to Jordan, who took the parcel, put it behind the skirts of his coat, came out of Eglinton's house, and went to Mr. Sharwood's, 55, Bishopsgate-street—a considerable distance before be reached the shop he withdrew one hand from the parcel, and about 50 yards before he reached the shop he withdrew the parcel, and went with it into Mr. Sharwood's shop, at exactly twenty-five minutes past nine o'clock—he remained there a few minutes, came out, and went towards Eglinton's house—on his way I observed him counting some money—I passed by him—I saw him go to Eglinton's house, and saw no more of him at that time—I have seen Perry and Eglinton together two or three times—I have never seen them near the prosecutor's house—I have seen them at Mr. Field's, the Black Dog, many times—I am not aware what Eglinton is by rade—he keeps a sort of grocer's and chandler's shop.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What was the charge on the other indictment that has been tried? A. Perry was charged with stealing—I cannot say on what day—I did not indict them—I gave evidence on the 11th, 19th, and 20th of March—I only proved the connexion—I mentioned Mon
day, the 11th of March last, as the day the theft was committed—Eglinton's warehouse is rather better than a mile from Bow Church-yard, where the things were stolen from. (See paye 945.)
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You did not interfere with Jordan

at all? A. No—I did not examine his coat to see if he had an inside-pocket—I do not believe be had—I have been a policeman nine or ten years—I can
not say whether you have a pocket in your coat-tail inside—the parcel was placed right up his back.
SAMUEL COOMBS (policeman.) On the 19th of March I sow Jordan and Eglinton together—I took Perry into custody.

JAMBS ALLAN SHARWOOD , druggist, 58, Bishopsgate-st. I have known the prisoner Jordan many years by name—I have bought things of him—I have bought patent medicines of him—on the 20th of March last I gave him orders for a dozen of each ointment—on Friday the 21st of March, at half-past nine in the morning, he brought me this dozen of patent-medicine—he asked me 8s. for it, which I paid—that was under the usual price—I had a reason for pur
chasing at a reduced price, as I had communicated with Messrs. Sutton, and I bought them—9s. 6d., was the proper price—I had bought another dozen of him the day previous—I had also purchased half-a-dozen on the 19th—I had refused that half-dozen on the Saturday previous—there is a mark on it—I marked it at half-past nine on the 21st of March—I received these from Jordan in the month of January—it was the last of the patent ointment that he could supply—he stated that he could sell them at less than the regular price.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you give evidence on a pre
vious charge of receiving stolen property? A. Yes—I had no reason to doubt that he was carrying on a respectable business in the chemist and drug-gist line—I know that he has been acting as a seller of patent medicine on commission—I never saw him at a sale—I have purchased things of him, ac
cording to his representation, just after a sale—patent medicines are not gene-rally sold—there are spurious patent medicines—you do not always get the right article—there was no concealment about Jordan in any of the transac-tions—I never heard any thing against his character—the difference between the price Messrs. Sutton sell it at, and what I paid was 18d., on the twelve boxes.

WILLIAM COLLINS . In March last, I was in the employ of William Henry Sutton and Son—I remember marking some medicines on Sunday the 17th of March—they were kept in a box in the cellar—at ten minutes past eight o'clock, on Thursday, the 21st of March, I saw them in the cellar—I saw Perry there that morning—he is a porter in their employ—the latest time I saw him come out of the cellar was about twenty-five minutes past eight—I cannot speak positively—he left altogether at twenty minutes to nine—all the men went out to breakfast—I saw him go out—I did not look outside the door—directly after he left I went down into the cellar, and missed one dozen—I know this ointment by these marks—I know Eglinton by tight—I had never seen him at our house—I have seen him in the neighbourhood, in Bow-lane—I did not see him on my master's premises on the morning of the 21st—I can
not say whether we have any real patent for these medicines—I do not know of any.

COURT. Q. You saw Perry come out of the cellar, had any body else been in the cellar that morning? A. Yes, James Jarman, one of the young men—I cannot be positive whether it was before or after—he is not here—he went down when I saw the things safe.

JAMES GELLATLY (City policeman.) I know Eglinton and Perry—I have seen them together at the Plough, Plough-yard. Shoreditch—I saw them there on Wednesday the 20th of March, at half-past eight o'clock in the evening—Perry came to the door and looked in—the pot-boy said. "He is not here yet"—he then went away, returned in three or four minutes, sat down and called for a pint of beer and a pipe—Eglinton came in, and said to Perry, "I have a dozen more ordered; it is strange, it is not, that they should

be wanted, for last week the parties would not look at them, much more buy"—Perry said, "Between this and Saturday"—Eglinton said, "The parties are in a hurry for them"—they soon after left—I heard nothing more that night—I was there on the next evening, Thursday the 21st, the day in ques
tion, in plain clothes—I saw them both sitting there—I heard Eglinton say to Perry, "Anything to-night?"—Perry said, "No"—they were soon after joined by a man and lad, and all four left—on Saturday, the 23rd of March, I apprehended Jordan coming from Eglinton's house—I said, "I am one of the City police, I take you into custody charged with receiving stolen goods knowing them to be stolen, belonging to Messrs. Sutton and Co."—he said, "You must be mistaken; I know Sutton and Dicey well, and have laid out hundreds of pounds with them; I will give you my address, Nicholas-street, Hoxton, and No. 9, Star-alley, Fenchurch-street, where I sleep"—he said he might be found when wanted—I told him he must come with me—he said, "Young man, listen to me, and I will be a father to you"—I told him I had no desire to hear any thing he had to say—he said he had a relation in a dying state who he wished to see, and if I wanted 5l. at any time I could have it—I told him I could not listen to any such proposal, he must come to Moor-lane station—he said, "Very well"—on our road he said he had known Eglin
ton for years—I had not mentioned Eglinton to him—I said, "I have not mentioned any name"—he said, "No, I thought you saw me come out of his house"—he said, Saturday being a busy day it would inconvenience him a good deal, but he would go to Sutton's if I liked.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you been a police constable? A. Since the 16th of February—I am twenty-two years old—before I went into the police I was servant to Mr. Stevens, a solicitor, in Queen-street, Cheapside—I get 17s. a week—if my conduct is approved of I shall get a higher salary—I shall be promoted in the event of giving satis
faction—I do not expect to get up after this, not for six months—I took a memorandum of the conversation the same evening, about half an hour after
wards—I have it here—I was not desired to bring it with me—I was asked for it the last time—I took it down from recollection—I have referred to it pretty often since—I do not know that it is put down in the order that it passed—I do not know that the words exactly follow each other in the order I have told you to-day—I was put there to watch—I did not take the memorandum the first day, because I did not think of it—I did not put it down for the purpose of reference, but to refresh my memory—the pot-boy was here this morning.

Cross-examined by MB. PAYNE. Q. Did not Jordan say, being in his work-day dress, he should like to change it? A. Yes. I said he could not—he said, "I have known Eglinton for years, and have sold drugs for him on commission"—he might have seen me when he came out of the shop—I saw him come out of the shop at half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, and I took him—two of the prisoners had a hearing on Monday—Jordan was examined on Monday morning—it was in the street he said he would go to Sutton's if I liked—he appeared very indignant at the charge—he talked very fast and loud—I have not discovered that he told me a single falsehood—I have never inquired whether the places of residence are correct—he did not make any attempt to escape—he was going the contrary way till I turned him round—he did not fight me—he talked so fast I cannot re
member all he said—I never heard any body say that he had a relative in a dying state—he said so himself before the Alderman—I will not swear he did not say he thought it strange Messrs. Sutton had not ascertained the loss instead of taking him prisoner—he spoke about the 5l. directly after saying he had a relative in a dying state.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you ever shown this paper to any body? A. No—I did not mention the conversation to any body except the Magis
strate.
Jordan. It was my own daughter that was dying; that was the reason I offered him 5l.

GEORGE JONES . I am manager to Messrs. Sutton. I never saw Jordan before—if he had been in the habit of buying patent medicines at our place I must have known him—patent medicines are never sold at a reduction.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Do you know Mr. Jordan who for
merly carried on a large business in Whitechapel? A. No.—I cannot swear he has not done business with our house twenty-five years ago—I never heard till the last week or two that he was a large chemist and druggist in White
chapel—I have been in the business eighteen years, and can only speak to that time—I will not swear he did not carry on business in Whitechapel.
(Joseph Low, goldsmith and jeweller; Francis King, tavern-keeper; Alfred; and Richard Divine, chemist and druggist, No. 76, Aldersgate-street; gave Eglinton a good character.)

(Thomas Williams, tobacconist, No. 87, Blackman-street, Borough; Samuel Cheshire, chemist and druggist, No. 144, Whitechapel; Samuel James Stokes, New North-road; and Henry Cook, cook and confectioner, No. 9, Star-street, Fenchurch-street; gave Jordan a good character.)

PERRY—
GUILTY . Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutors.

EGLINTON—
GUILTY . Aged 45

JORDAN—
GUILTY . Aged 49.

1313.
FRANCES RANN was indicted
for stealing 1 stool, value 5s., the goods of
George Carpenter; 2 finger-glasses, 2s., the goods of
William Ellis; 1 clothes-horse, 1s. 6d., and 1 chair, 5s., the goods of
James Hubbard; 2 chairs, 5s., and 1 dust-pan, 5d., the goods of
Joseph David Banks; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined One Year.

1314.
ARTHUR CLARK was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, and 2 sixpences; the property of
Henry Anthony, from the person of
Ann Anthony.

ANN ANTHONY . I am the wife of Henry Anthony. I was at a ship-launch at Woolwich, on the 3rd of April—somebody took my purse from my pocket, containing a half-crown, two shillings, and two sixpences—this is it—the money is still in it.
JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 130.) I was on duty at Woolwich on the 3rd of April—I saw the prisoner put his hand into Mrs. Anthony's pocket, and take out this purse—I took it out of his hand.
Prisoner. I did not put my hand into her pocket, I picked it up. Witness. I saw him open her dress and take it.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

1315.
CHARLES M'DERMOTT was indicted
for stealing 1 half-crown, 4 shillings, and 4 sixpences; the monies of
Augustus Benjamin Tomlins, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Three Months.

1316.
ELIZABETH NICHOLLS was indicted
for stealing 2 handker
chiefs, value 9s. 6d.; the goods of
Richard Wade and others.

RICHARD WADE . I am a linendraper, and live in High-street, Deptford, in partnership with my brothers. The prisoner was in our shop on the 30th of March, and I received information—I told the young man to go on serving her and let her go—after he had served her she was attracted to the other tide of the shop by a young man who was folding some shawls—I got into conversation with her, and invited her to come out and look at our window, which she did—I said there was one article I should like her to see—I took her again into the shop to another part—I then jumped over the counter, and said my young man told me she had got some handkerchiefs, and asked if she had any objection to be searched—she said "No"—I said to my young man, "Are you sure she has got the handkerchiefs?"—he said, "Yes, I will show you the same pattern in another colour "—these handkerchiefs were then lying at the prisoner's feet—I am sure they had not been there before—that part was three or four yards from where she stood at first—they are mine.

Cross-examined by MR. WILKINS. Q. Is yours a large shop? A. Yes—there was another women with the prisoner—they sat at a counter, and White was showing them handkerchiefs—they would be taken out of the box to be shewn—there were other customers in the shop—there were not less than four young men in the shop—it was supper time—the other shopmen were on the opposite side of the shop, but they were in view—I do not know how the handkerchiefs got at her feet, but they were not there when I took her to the place—the other woman was standing by her side when I asked to be allowed to search them.

STEPHEN WHITE . I am shopman to Mr. Wade. On the 14th of March, a little after ten o'clock in the evening, the prisoner and another woman came to look at some handkerchiefs—while I was showing them some, my attention was aroused by seeing the prisoner try to draw the handkerchiefs from the counter—she then asked for some lighter ones, and while I was going to fetch them I communicated it to my employer, who told me to go on and serve her—I returned with the light handkerchief?, and the prisoner left the other woman, to decide on the handkerchief—I then saw the prisoner draw the handkerchiefs off the counter—shortly after she stooped, and I sup
posed picked them up, she made a wry face, as if she had a pain in her leg—after that she had some ribbon, which she gave to the other woman—Mr. John Smith was at the desk, and took the cash—he asked if I was certain about the matter, and I looked behind the counter and missed the handkerchiefs—these are the handkerchiefs I saw her draw from the counter—I swear to them—she was then invited by a young man on the opposite side to see some shawls, and then Mr. Wade took her outside—I looked at the place where she had been, and nothing was there—I looked at her dress, and nothing was clinging to it—she was brought back, and a place was cleared for her to go to—Mr. Wade said, "My young man has missed some handkerchiefs, will you allow me to search you?"—they said "Yes "—he searched the other woman first—I then saw the handkerchiefs on the ground in a crumpled state.
Cross-examined. Q. How many young gentlemen were serving in the shop? A. I did not notice—there might have been four.
NOT GUILTY .

1317.
JOHN FEWKES was indicted
for stealing 2 spoons, value 18s., the goods of
William M'Niel, his master.

JANE STEVENSON . I am in the service of Mr. M'Niel, of Charlton; the prisoner came into his service on the 17th of March; he had been a week or ten days before working in the garden. On the 17th the plate was given to him to lay on the table, and after that I said I would wash it—he said, "Never mind, I will"—he washed it and took it up stairs—on wednes
day, the 20th of March, my master left home, leaving my young master, the the prisoner and me in the house—I went to bed about a quarter-past nine o'clock, and about two next morning I was awoke by a call of "Murder and thieves"—I heard the prisoner say, "For God's sake, come and help me"—I got a light, alarmed my young master, and went down—I found the pri
soner in the kitchen—he had his trowsers and his stockings on, but no shoes, coat, or waistcoat—I was so frightened, I do not well remember what he said—I saw no thieves—the prisoner was taken into custody the same morning—I missed these two spoons—they are my master's.

CHRISTIAN WILLIAM M'NIEL . I am the prosecutor's son. I was disturbed that morning—I went down, and found the prisoner is the kitchen—he slept in a room opposite the stable, which is one staircase above the kitchen—he said that three men had entered his bed-room window, that he had followed them down into the kitchen, and, as he entered, he was knocked down; that he rose up, and was knocked down again, and, on his calling for help, they ran away—I saw the poker, which he attracted my notice to, lying on the floor, nearly bent double—he said one of the men struck at him with it, but had missed him—I did not observe any marks of violence on him, as if he had been knocked down—I went down the moment I heard the cry—be
tween my hearing it, and going down, he had not time to go up stairs and put on his stockings and trowsers.

THOMAS PINKCOMBE . I am the prosecutor's gardener. The prisoner was taken on Thursday morning, the 21st of March, and from that time I assisted my master in the stable till Fleming came on the 25th—from the time the prisoner was taken, till Fleming came, my master kept the key of the stable door, and no one could have access to it—I never went to the stable but when ray master was there—there had been a ladder in the green-house on the Wednesday night, and on the Thursday morning I found it under the pri-soner's window.

JOHN FLEMING . I was engaged by the prosecutor, as groom—on the 25th of March, I went into the stable, and under some fitter I found a silver desert-spoon, which I gave to Stevenson; and about the centre of the stall I found a silver table-spoon, which I took to my master.

WILLIAM M'NIEL . I received a spoon from Fleming—I had left home, but was informed of this robbery, and I returned on the Thursday—I gave the prisoner into custody—I let nobody go into the stable after that till Fleming came—no one could have access to the stable.

Prisoner. There were plenty of people employed about his premises be
sides myself. Witness. No one could have got the key but from my pocket, or from the key-basket in the parlour.

CHRISTIAN WILLIAM M'NIEL
re-examined. I did not take the key from the basket—I did not put the spoons in the stable—the prisoner told the policeman four men attacked him, but he told me three.

JANE STEVENSON
re-examined. I did not take the key from the basket, nor put the spoons in the stable.—no one could have taken the key without my knowing it.
JAMES PARRY (police-sergeant R 8.) I examined the prisoner on the 21st March, to see if there were any marks of violence on him, and then were

none—there were no marks of violence on the house—there was some fresh putty on the window of the room which the prisoner said the thieves entered—they would have left marks on it, but there were none—he said there were four thieves; that one man came out of the room opposite, and attacked him, and when he went down some more men were there; that he was struck on the back, head, and knee—I asked him to let me see the marks, but there were none—there were some crumbs of bread, and meat, and salt in his room—he said he had had none, and no one else had had any in his room.

Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about the spoons; I was remanded, and they were not found till I came back from Maidstone. It might have been a plot, or something. I waited at table on Sunday, and I took the plate, and gave it to the mistress, in the dining-room, that night. I heard the thieves go through the room; I got up and dressed myself, and went down; the men were in the kitchen, and they knocked me down.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

1318.
JAMES BOX and
HENRY ADAMS were indicted for
stealing 1 sixpence, 2 pence, and 1 halfpenny, the monies of
George Sandiford; from the person of
Frances Sandiford.

FRANCES SANDIFORD . I am the wife of George Sandiford, we live in Marsh-lane, Greenwich. On the 3rd of April I was at the Dockyard-gate at Woolwich—a ship was to be launched, and there was a crowd there—I did not feel anything, but I lost a sixpence, two pence, and a halfpenny, out of my pocket.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) I saw the two prisoners at the Dockyard-gate on 3rd April—I watched, and saw them attempt several gen
tlemen's pockets—I saw them go behind Mrs. Sandiford—Adams went close to her, and Box was behind him—I saw Adams put his hand into her pocket, and take something out—he was in the act of passing it to Box, when I seized him—some money dropped on the ground I picked it up, and with the assistance of Gladwin took both the prisoners.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable R 122.) I saw Adams put his hand into the woman's pocket, and take out something, which he banded to Box—I seized Box, and he dropped a sixpence, two pence, and a halfpenny.
Adams's Defence. The constable took me; he took another lad, let him go, then seized Box, and said he was with me; I saw some money on the ground, and they took it up.

BOX—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

ADAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

1319.
ELIZABETH PERRY was indicted
for stealing 1 gown, value 7s. 6d.; the goods of
Edward Charles Carpenter Nash.

RICHARD MASON CLARK . I am shopman to Edward Charles Carpenter Nash, of London-street, Greenwich—I hung a gown on his door-post on the 1st of April—I did not miss it till the policeman came—this is it.
JOHN BOVIS (police-constable R 139.) I watched the prisoner in the prosecutor's shop, on 1st April—I saw her come out, and took this gown from her, about 300 yards from the shop.

Prisoner. It was not me that stole it. Witness. There were three per
sons—I did not see her take it, but she brought it out, and she drew it from under her clothes.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 13.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Ten Days.

1320.
SOPHIA HARMER was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, the monies of
Edward Britcher; from his person.

EDWARD BRITCHER . I am organ-blower of Lewisham-church. On the evening of 21st March, Mr. Southorn, the churchwarden, paid me 1l. 1s. 6d.,—he put it into a piece of paper—I put it into my side breeches pocket—I went to the Plongh, and called for a pint of beer—I was sitting outside the house—the prisoner came by, and asked me to give her a drink of beer—I let her have a drink, and she sat close by my side—I had my money safe in my pocket when I sat down, and while she was there I looked, and missed the paper all at once—she went into Mr. Griggs, then came and sat down by me again, gave me the paper, and said she did not like to rob me—she went away, and when I was going home, I looked in the paper, and there was only one farthing there—no one else had been sitting by me who could have taken it.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you speak to her about having lost your money? A. No—she was with me when I missed it—I had not accused another young woman before the prisoner was taken.

SIMON SOUTHORN . I am the churchwarden of Lewisham—I paid Britcher a sovereign, a shilling—a sixpence, and the sovereign being dull, I went to my cash-box, and took out a bright one—I put it into a paper, gave it to him, and he went away.

JANS GRIGG . I am the daughter of the landlord of the Plough, at Lewisham—Britcher was having a pint of beer—he took it outside, and in a short time after the prisoner came in for two farthings for a halfpenny, which my sister gave her—a short time afterwards Britcher came in, appa-rently, looking at something in his hand—he went out again in a very great hurry—I am certain it was the prisoner came in, I knew her before.

STEPHEN BROOKS (police-constable R 50.) I took the prisoner in Mill-lane, on the morning after the robbery—I said to her, "Soph., do you recollect how many pints of beer you had with this man at the Plough?"—she said, "Only one"—I said, "Do you recollect how he paid for it?"—she said, "No"—he had described her dress to me—he said she had a light dress, a dark shawl, and a velvet bonnet; and that was the dress she had on—there was another young woman shown to him—I asked him if the girl had a black eye, because there was another young woman used to dress like the prisoner, but she had a black eye—he did not express any doubt about the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not accuse another woman? A. He accused two—he said, "It was them, or somebody like them"—I called them out of an oyster-shop, and then he said that he could not swear to them—but when he saw the prisoner he swore to her.
NOT GUILTY .

1321.
JOHN FORD was indicted
for stealing 1 pocket-book, value 6d. the goods of Peter Turn bull, from his person.

ROBERT SUTTLE (police-constable R 97.) About five o'clock on the even
ing of the 8th of April, I was on duty at Greenwich-fair—I saw the prisoner and two others in company—I saw the prisoner take this pocket-book, out of the prosecutor's pocket—I laid hold of him directly, and he dropped it—I took it up.

PETER TURNBULL . I live at Greenwich, and am an engineer. I was look
ing
at a stall in Greenwich-fair—Suttle came to me, and asked if this was my book—I said it was—it bad been in my coat pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1322.
JOHN JACKSON and
DANIEL GLANVILLE were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 6d. the goods of a certain woman, unknown, from her person.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) On the 9th of April I was at Greenwich-fair—I saw Jackson put his hand into a woman's pocket, take something, and pass it to Glanville—I took them, and found this handker
chief crumpled up in Glanville's pocket.

JOHN SEAGER . I am a labourer, and live at Deptford. I have been in the police, but am superannuated—I was with White, and saw the prisoners go down the fair in company, about 150 yards—I saw Jackson take some
thing from a woman's pocket, which appeared to be a handkerchief, and pass it to Glanville—I seized Jackson—he tried to get from me—I tried to get the woman, but the crowd was so great I could not get at her—I have been getting my living the last six months by attending at the police-court, and going on messages for Mr. Finch or the Magistrate.
Jackson's Defence. A boy took the handkerchief from a young woman, and threw it to me; Glanville was not there.
(Glanville received a good character.)

JACKSON—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

GLANVILLE—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Ten Days, and
Whipped.

1323.
JOHN COOK,
JAMES GRACE , and
JAMES WILSON , were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of a certain man, unknown, from his person.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) I was at Greenwich-fair on the 8th of April—I saw Wilson go behind a gentleman, and take this hand
kerchief out of his pocket, and pass it to Cook, under his arm—Cook took it, and put it into his hat, and at I was seizing him, he had hold of another gen
tleman's pocket—I called to the first gentleman, but could not get at him—Grace was covering the other two—I had sees them all three together for an hour and a half.

GEORGE MARTIN (police-constable R 93.) I saw the prisoners attempt the pockets of twenty different persons during an hour and a half—Grace was covering the others, but Carpenter was before me, so I did not see them take the handkerchief.
Grace's Defence. I know nothing of these two persons.
Cook's Defence. We had not been down in the fair about twenty minutes.

COOK—
GUILTY .

GRACE—
GUILTY .

WILSON—
GUILTY .

1324.
GEORGE HYDE and
ELIZA CLARK were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of a certain man, unknown, from his person.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable R 122.) On the 3rd of April I was at the Dock-gate, Woolwich. I saw Hyde put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and take out a handkerchief—I had been watching him and Clark for five or ten minutes—I tried to seize Hyde, but lost him and the pro
secutor—in the course of a quarter of an hour I took Hyde, and the hand-kerchief was found on Clark—I have not had any other cases where the

owner was not known—I took Hyde immediately I saw him, after he had picked the pocket, and Clark was with him then—in coming up the dock-yard they were alone, by themselves, and were talking—I had seen Hyde attempting pockets, and Clark covering him—they were remanded from Wednesday till Tuesday, to see if we could find an owner.

Hyde. I was charged at the station with attempting to pick a pocket, not with stealing. Witness. He was charged with stealing before the Magis-trate; I did not state that we both tumbled down—I said I was shoved down by the crowd—there was a score down at the time—I did not see Hyde five or six times afterwards—if I had I should have taken him.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) I saw Hyde before the gates were thrown open, attempt to pick several gentlemen's pockets, and at the time the rush was made, Gladwin told me he had taken a handkerchief—Clark was with him when he was trying the pockets.
ANN THOROGOOD . I searched Clark, and found this handkerchief in her bosom.

JURY to W. GLADWIN. Q. Can you swear that the handkerchief found on Clark was the one Hyde took? A. No, it was a light-coloured one—be-fore Clark was searched, she said she had no property—this handkerchief is marked with initials very different to the prisoner's names—Clark said it had been washed several times, and this has never been washed.

Hyde's Defence. As we were coming out, they shoved and this woman, and four more young men into the Dock-yard, and charged us with attempt
ing to pick pockets; he did not take me for an hour and a half.
Clark's Defence. This is ay own handkerchief; I gave 3s. for it; I took it off and put it down my bosom.
NOT GUILTY .

1325.
MICHAEL BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6l., the goods of
William Watkins, from his person.

WILLIAM WATKINS , baker. At half-past ten o'clock in the evening of the 10th of April I was standing at a beer-shop—the prisoner snatched a hand-kerchief out of my hand—I seized him directly, and he passed it behind him to another one—I am sure he is the man—the other went down stairs—I have been out of work since last Saturday week.
Prisoner. Q. What did you tell me it was? A. I said, "Give me that handkerchief;" you said, "What handkerchief?" and that you would "break my b—y neck" if I asked for it.
Prisoner. He would not let my two witnesses come up stairs with me; when he came up he said "Where is Brown;" I said "Here I am," and he took me.
JOHN EWINS (policeman.) There were two other persons going behind the prisoner to the station, but they would not come inside.
NOT GUILTY .

1326.
THOMAS EVANS was indicted
for a rape on Sarah Glister.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 29.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1327.
GEORGE MOORE was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Jane Arnold, and cutting and wounding her on the neck, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

JANE ARNOLD . I live in Rope-yard-rail, Woolwich, and am nearly eigh
teen years old. I have been keeping company with the prisoner nearly two years—on the 3rd of April, about half-past nine o'clock, he came to my mo
ther's house and stopped till half-past ten o'clock—when he left I followed him to close the door—he said he was going home to his mother's at Poplar on Thursday, and asked if I would write to him—I said I would by Mon
day or Tuesday—he wanted one before then, and asked if I had picked up with any body else while he was away—I said, "No"—he said was I going to give him up?—I said I was—he wished me good night and went away—he came again almost directly after, and knocked at the door—my mother opened it, and asked him to come in—he said no, he wanted to speak to Jane—I went out to him, and he said "You are going to leave me?"—I said, "Yes, George"—he said, "Oh you are, are you?" and he up and hit me with a knife across the neck—it was not a deep cut, it only just went through the skin—I was not much hurt—Mr. Downs attended me—I was going to give the prisoner up because he had got into bad company.

Prisoner. I had my arm on her shoulder; I was cutting my finger nails with a knife, and in putting my arm out to prevent her falling it scratched her neck. Witness. He would not have done it, only he was in liquor; I believe it was not done intentionally, only to frighten me.

CATHERINE ARNOLD . Last Wednesday night my daughter, who is a servant, came home about eight o'clock—the prisoner came about half-past nine o'clock, and stopped an hour or so—he was in liquor—I said, "George, we want to go to bed"—my husband had gone to bed—he jumped up and went out, and my daughter also—they had some words outside, and my daughter seemed very agitated when she came in—in two or three minutes he knocked at the door, and said he wanted to speak to Jane—he was very agitated, and looked very wild—I said, "George, come in"—he said, "No, I want to speak to Jane"—my daughter went out—in a few minutes I heard a scuffle, and heard her say, "Oh!" or "Oh mother!"—I jumped out of my chair, and saw her throat was cut and bleeding—I ran to the door and said, "Oh George, what have you done!"—I rushed in doors, bolted the door, ran up stairs and told my husband—he ran down in his shirt, and went to look for a policeman—a doctor was sent for—the prisoner had always be
haved very kindly before, and she is still very fond of him.

GEORGE DOWNS , surgeon. I was called in to examine the prosecutrix's throat—there was a cut on the left side of the neck about two and a half inches long, merely through the skin—it was quite superficial.

AMY HOOPER . I am single, and live in Rope-yard-rail. Between ten and eleven o'clock at night the prisoner applied to me to lend him a knife, which I did—he was intoxicated—I did not know what he wanted it for—it was a small dinner-knife—I knew him before.

WILLIAM WATSON , labourer. I met the prisoner just at the dock-yard gate about half-past eleven o'clock the morning after this, and asked what he had been doing—he said he did not know—I asked what made him do it—he said he did not know—then he said he meant to do it to himself, but the knife turned.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman.) I apprehended the prisoner on Satur
day, the 6th, two days after it happened—I told him it was on suspicion of cutting a young girl's throat—he said it was done accidentally, he was stand
ing at the door with her paring his nails with the knife, that he had his arm round her neck, and hearing somebody coming he went to save her from fall
ing and cut her neck.

JANE ARNOLD
re-examined. The first time be had his arm round my waist, but not at the time he cut me—I did not observe the knife till he cut me.

GUILTYof an Assault. Aged 20.—
Confined Six Weeks.

1325.
RICHARD BYE was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a man unknown, from his person; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1326.
GEORGE BAKER,
GEORGE BASSETT , and
JOHN GRANT were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Lindsey, about one in the night of the 19th of Feb., at Lewis-ham, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 2 pairs of spectacles, value 1l. 10s.; 2 milk-pots, 1l.; 2 ladles, 1l.; 8 spoons, 4l.; 3 handkerchiefs, 6s.; 3/4 of a yard of silk, 10s.; 30 sovereigns, 8 half-crowns, 40 shillings, 30 six
pences, 6 groats, 30 pence, 40 halfpence, 60 farthings; and 1 30l., 1 10l., and 3 5l. Bank-notes; his property; to which

BAKER pleaded
GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

JAMES LINDSEY . I am a grocer, and live in the parish of Lewisham. On the night of the 19th of Feb. I was the last person up in the house—I went to bed about eleven o'clock—everything was then safe and fast—the skylight of the washhouse was quite safe—I came down about seven o'clock in the morn-ing—Dodd, my servant, gave me information—I keep the post-office—I found the post-bag opened, the letters taken out, opened, and torn; all my drawers open, and the things in them all out—I went to the washhouse, and found the lead-work and frame of the skylight completely removed—they had got in that way—the hinges were broken open, and the skylight entirely removed off—I know Bassett by his coming for dust occasionally—he had an opportunity of seeing the premises—he has been there several times.

ELIZA DODD . I am servant to the prosecutor. On the morning of the 20th Feb., about a quarter past seven o'clock, I came down stairs—I was the first that came down—I went into the shop, and found everything in confu
sion, the doors open, and things lying about—I went up, and told my mas
ter—I had 4s. in my work-box, in the kitchen—that was taken, and the things all turned out on the floor.

REBECCA LINDSEY . I am the prosecutor's wife. I take care of my hus-band's money—on the morning of the 20th of Feb. I missed from the desk in the parlour a 30l. Bank-note, a 10l., and three 5l. Bank-notes; and, among other money, I lost between two and three shillings' worth of farthings, in a little tin box in the till—I lost a great deal of other property, which was all safe before—I had occasion to look at the farthings to give change shortly before, and there were two very old-looking ones and a counterfeit shilling—those two farthings were left on the table in the kitchen—the shilling has been found by the officer—this is it—I know it well—I took it of an old man, who said he would change it for me again, but he had no other.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you take it for a shilling? A. No, for a farthing—I know it—I have no private mark on it.

WILLIAM PERRING . I am a carpenter, and live next door to Mr. Lindsey. I was awoke out of my sleep on this night by my dog barking I heard a noise, which appeared to be in Mr. Lindsey's warehouse or washhouse, where the

skylight is—I fell asleep again—it was about two o'clock—I am quite posi
tive it was before six—it was dark.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure you were not dreaming? A. Yes, I was awake for three quarters of an hour—I thought it was Mr. Lindsey up, going to market.

SARAH HOGG . My husband keeps the Lord Nelson, in Dock-street, Deptford, about two miles from Lewisham. On the morning of the 20th of Feb. the three prisoners were at our house—Bassettand Baker were there about a quar
ter after six o'clock, and Grant came about seven—I knew them before, and have no doubt of them—they used my house—I served them with some gin
hot—Baker called for it, and paid 4 1/2 d. for it, all in farthings, except this coin, which is a counterfeit shilling—I made a mark on it—this is it—I took it as a farthing—I put the farthings on a shelf where there was no other money—Grant had not come then—when Grant came he drank with them—I gave the farthings to the policeman, and the bad shilling.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you put the farthings? A. On the shelf at the back of the bar and the shilling with them—I put them there about a quarter past six o'clock in the morning—the policeman did not have them for two days, but he came and inquired about them the same day—I am positive they are the same—I took them off the shelf and marked them when the policeman came, which, I believe, was the same evening—I served in the bar that day—I do not know that anybody else did—my husband was in and out—nobody else serves—we do not admit people into the bar—we do not keep a maid—the potman was in the hospital at the time—from the time the farth
ings were paid to me till the policeman came, nobody but myself and husband were in the bar—I was there all day, and must have seen if anybody came—if I left the bar my husband was there—the policeman came about seven o'clock the same evening, and requested me to take care of them—I marked them then, and locked them up in the cupboard.

MR. DOANE. Q. Did it call your attention the men paying you entirely in farthings? A. Yes—I did not observe the counterfeit shilling among them till the officer came—I had no farthings, or money in the place where I put the farthings—I had taken one farthing away to send out change—with that exception, they tallied.

MARGARET DUNN . I live in Dock-street, Deptford. I know all the pri
soners—Baker kept company with my sister—he came to me on the morning of the 20th of February, between seven and eight o'clock, and gave me 10s. to take to my sister—while he was talking to me, Bassett came and called him—I heard him, but did not see him—he stood on the step of the door, and said, "Come along, Baker, you know where we have got to go to; make haste, Baker, you know where we have got to go to "—Baker said, "I am coming "—he gave me 4d. to get something to drink for myself, and went away—he had got more money—I saw silver in his purse.

FREDERICK DOBSON . I am barman to Mr. Quarry, of Penny fields, Poplar. On the morning of the 20th of Feb., between seven and eight o'clock, three men came there—I believe Grant and Bassett to be two of them—they had a pint of porter, and drank together—it came to 2d., and they paid for it in eight farthings—they asked me if I would take six pennyworth of farthings of them, which I did—they afterwards said, "We have fourpennyworth more," and I gave them fourpence more for farthings—they then asked if I could give them change for a 5l. note—I do not know which of them it was—I can recognise Grant.
Cross-examined. Q. You had never seen Bassett before? A. No—I only think he is the man—I cannot tell which offered the farthings.

ROSE DAVIS . I am single, and live in Ship-yard, Temple-bar. On Tues
day,

the 20th of Feb., between two and three o'clock in the day, I met the three prisoners in the Strand—I knew them before—I remained in their company all the afternoon, and I went to the play with them all three—Bassett went home, and passed the night with me—next day I joined company with all three of them again, and went to the Grapes public-house—they gave me some gin there—Bassett gave me 10s. when at home—they treated me at the play, Baker paid for us all—I saw Baker with two or three 5l. notes on Wednesday the 21st, and five or six sovereigns—I did not see any with Grant—Baker was in my company all day long on Wednesday—on Wednes
day night Baker asked the other prisoners if they wanted any money—they said they did—he pulled out some gold and silver, and gave each of them some silver, but I do not know how much—Bassett said he had some silver spoons on board his ship, and if he could get them away, he would make me a present of one or two—Bassett paid 3s. for the bed we slept in, for each night—he slept with me two nights.

CHARLOTTE DUTTON . I live at the same house as Davis. On Tuesday, the 20th of Feb, I saw the three prisoners, and accompanied them to the Grapes public-house—I went with Grant, and passed the night with him, for which he gave me 10s., and 3s. for the room—he accused me of stealing a sovereign from him—I saw he had some sovereigns, but I did not notice how many—we were all together at the Grapes—Davis and several other girls were there in company—Baker treated all of us there—he treated pretty well every person that came—we remained there drinking at his expense till be
tween five and six o'clock, when we went to the theatre—Baker paid for the lady he was with—Grant paid for me—we had a cab—I heard Bassett say he had sent the cabman to get change for a 5l. note, and he had promised to give him 15s. if be returned quick—we went to the theatre without waiting for the cabman's return—Bassett said, "Never mind, perhaps some day I shall see him in Newgate "—Baker and Grant heard that—I saw Grant with a 5l. note, besides two or three sovereigns—he only staid with me one night.

Cross-examined. Q. You are an unfortunate girl, I suppose? A. Yes—it was in the Grapes that Bassett spoke about the cabman, just previous to our going to the theatre—I believe what he said was "We have sent the cab
man for change for a 5l. note, but never mind, we shall perhaps see him in Newgate before long"—it was not Bassett that said that, it was Grant—I was not there at the time it was sent—to the best of my knowledge it was Grant said it.
MR. DOANE. Q. Was it the man that slept with you? A. Yes, to the best of my knowledge.

SARAH DEN TON . I am an unfortunate girl, and live in Newcastle-court, Strand. On the night of the 20th Feb., about half-past one o'clock I went over to No. 15, and saw the three prisoners there, Dutton and Davis were with them—I went and slept with Baker at that place—in the morning I saw he had a great deal of money—I did not see Bassett or Grant with any.

EDWARD BROWN , I keep the Grapes, in the Strand, On Tuesday, the 20th Feb., between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, the three prisoners came to my house, and staid about an hour and a half or two hours—the three witnesses and several more girls were with them—they were treating them—the money was sent out by the waiter—I cannot say who paid—they went away—I saw them all again next day with the same three girls and several others—they staid at my house all that day enjoying themselves—they laid out altogether about 4l. with me—Grant changed a 5l. note previous to going to the play—I saw a cabman there, and he brought a 5l. note to me—I kept it—I have spent it—I gave him his change for it—I gave Bassett or

Baker 3l. previous to going to the play—I gave a sovereign to each—the note the cabman had, went on with the reckoning until it came to 3l.—I gave them a sovereign each, as I had 2l. left out of the 5l.,—I gave him 3l. pre
vious to going to the play, and next day the reckoning came to 3l. 10s.—I saw two 5l. notes, that is what I speak of.

Q. You have said you changed a 5l. note for Grant, and they went to the play? A. I meant to say I advanced him 3l.—I have not said I saw two 5l. notes together—5s. was to be given to the waiter—I paid the two 5l. notes to Mr. Webb, a wine-merchant, at London-bridge, one of which I received from the cabman—Baker put a name on the back of the 5l. notes—it is not here.
COURT. Q. Do you keep a house for thieves and prostitutes? A. I keep a house.

ELIZA DAVIS . I live at Deptford. On Sunday, the 18th of Feb., I saw Bassett—he gave me a Bible, and asked me to buy it for 1s.—I gave him 1s. for it—he said he had no money to pay for his night's lodging, and so he sold it.

BENJAMIN LOVELL (police-sergeant). On Tuesday, the 20th Feb., I went to Mr. Lindsey's—I found the sky-light removed—in consequence of informa
tion, I went after the prisoners—I had seen them all three on Monday night, the 19th, about half-past ten o'clock, at the Riding-circus, Greenwich, about half a mile from the prosecutor's. On Tuesday evening, about eight, I went to the Lord Nelson, in Dock-street, they were not there then—I saw Mrs. Hogg, she showed me sixteen farthings, and among them a counterfeit shilling—she marked them—I afterwards received them from her—they have been produced. On the 26th I found Grant at the station, and said to him, "Well, John, I was pretty close to you yesterday, in Whitechapel, here you are"—he said he knew I was, and said he had been to my house to give himself up to me, and that he had nothing to do with the robbery—I had not said anything to him about the robbery—I had said, "I understand you were all down at Lewisham on Saturday"—he said, "Yes, I was"—he said they came down after the silver spoons that were hid in the Roe
buck tea-gardens—that Baker got them out and sold them for 20s.—I asked what he had done with the notes—he said he never saw them—he had on a new cap and pair of shoes—he said Baker bought them for him in Rosemary-lane.

JAMES DOUGLAS (police-inspector.) On the 26th February I was at the station at Greenwich, when a man named Baxfield came with Grant—he said in Grant's presence that he had come to his house on purpose for him to go with him to Sergeant Lovell, to give himself up for the robbery at Lewis
ham, as he heard he was after him—he said he was not with him when the robbery was committed.

BASSETT†—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

GRANT†—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

1327.
GEORGE WHITE was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
William Holt, from his person.
WILLIAM HOLT . I live in Regent-square—I was at Greenwich fair on the 9th of April, and I lost my pocket handkerchief—this now produced is it.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket—I had been watching him for twenty minutes, attempting to pick people's pockets—I secured him concealing it under his coat, and found another silk handkerchief on him.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. How long have you been in the po
lice? A. Very nearly fifteen years—I know it is an offence to pick a

pocket—I have taken many scores for it—it did suit me to take the prisoner for the attempt—if I take a person for an attempt I take him before a Ma
gistrate and he is not brought here—I get no expenses before a Magistrate—I do not get much here—I shall get nothing for this—that was not my reason for not taking him, I considered it my duty to wait till it was done—I am allowed a discretion—that is my instructions from Mr. Molineux, my superior—we are told not to bring any attempts if we can help it, they do not like it—the Magistrates commit for an attempt if the party is a known thief—that was the reason I did not take the prisoner—I saw him attempt a dozen pockets.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY .
Confined Three Months.

1328.
JAMES WILLIAMS , was indicted
for stealing a handkerchief, the property of a man unknown, from his person.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) On the night of the 8th of April I was on duty in a booth at Greenwich fair, about eleven o'clock—I saw the pri
soner in company with another man—I saw them try several pockets—the mob was so great I could not get hold of them at the time—I saw them arm
in-arm—I saw the other man pick a gentleman's pocket of this white hand
kerckief—they were both together—the prisoner could see what he did—I saw the other give the handkerchief to the prisoner who put it into his pocket—I secured him, and took it out of his pocket—I found three pairs of gentlemen's gloves on him, two tobacco-boxes, two latch-keys, one door-key, and some money.

Prisoner. Q. Why not take the other man? A. I could not, the mob was so great—I could not get to the gentleman—it is a lawn handkerchief, marked "T. F."—I was obliged to have five or six policemen to keep the prisoner—there was about 500 people there, and 50 policemen clearing them out—we could hardly get them out at all—I had my stock torn off my neck.

Prisoner. I have come from Gloucester to look for work; the police
man thrust his hand into my pocket, and pulled out the handkerchief; who put it there I cannot say, I was not aware that it was there; almost every one in the booth were arm-in-arm, resisting the policemen clearing the booth.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1329.
ISAAC TURNER was indicted
for stealing 3 sheets, value 8s.; 4 table-cloths, 3l.; 3 pairs of trowsers, 1l.; and 1 ring, 30s.; the goods of
James Louttit Braimer, his master.

JAMES LOUTTIT BRAIMER . I am first-lieutenant in the Royal Marines, at Woolwich. The prisoner was in my service three months—I missed five table-cloths and a number of sheets, but three I can identify, also three pairs of trowsers, a gold ring, and other articles of wearing apparel—I have seen the four table-cloths, sheet, and gold ring, which are mine.

Prisoner. When I went into his service there were only three large table-cloths and two small ones. Witness. There were four—it was only about a week before I disembarked from the Camperdown—three large table-cloths were pawned by him, and I have one now in my chest.
WILLIAM TAYLOR . I am servant to Lieutenant Braimer. On the 25th of March I received these three duplicates from the milkman, and gave them to my master.

ANDREW DOUTHELL , milkman, Francis-street, Woolwich, The prosecutor is a customer of mine—the prisoner asked me to lend him 10s. about the 22nd or 23rd of Feb.—I refused, but he pressed so hard, and said he was in great trouble, and he wished to send it to his friends—I lent him 10s.—he said if I would he would fetch me some property, and he gave me these three duplicates which I gave to Taylor.

GEORGE STEVENS , shopman to Mr. Davit, pawnbroker, Woolwich. I pro
duce three table-cloths, and other articles, pawned I believe by the prisoner—he was not dressed in regimentals at the time—I gave two of these dupli
cates for them.

GEORGE JAMES ESCHMAN , shopman to Mr. Moore, pawnbroker, Woolwich. This table-cloth was pawned at our shop on the 7th of March, with a pair of trowsers, for 4s., by the prisoner, in the name of Braimer—he afterwards sold me a ring.
JAMES PARRY (police-sergeant.) I took the prisoner into custody on the 29th of March, for robbing his master—he said he knew nothing about it.
SAMPSON DARKIN CAMPBELL (police-inspector.) I know Mr. Jeremy's writing—I have no doubt this is his signature—(read)—" The prisoner says I bought the tickets but do not know of whom."
(property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not pawn the things; I bought the tickets; I cannot tell the person's name I bought them of.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Month.

1330.
DAVID TRUBY,
JOHN WRIGHT , and
BENJAMIN SMITH were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of a man un
known, from his person: and
ANN WILLY
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) On Tuesday afternoon, the 9th of April, about three o'clock, I was on duty at Greenwich fair, standing at the top of a show—I saw the three male prisoners in a crowd standing behind a gentleman—I saw Truby take a handkerchief from the gentleman's pocket, and pass it to Wright, and they all three went out of the crowd to Willy, who was a distance off—I saw them look at the handkerchief and give it to her—I got down from the show to go after them, and in doing so saw another man pick a pocket—I took that man to the station, and while there the three male prisoners were brought in for picking another man's pocket—when Willy took the handkerchief she put it under her clothes and into her pocket, where I found it when I took her—she said she had been out from her hus
band all night, sleeping with the men, and said, "See what it is to get into bad company, they brought the handkerchief to me "—I asked if she had any more about her—she said yes, put her hand in her bosom and pulled out two more—I cannot swear this is the handkerchief Truby took, but I be
lieve it is—I found it where I saw her put it.

Smith. The property is mine; I bought them at 2s. each, not knowing it was stolen; I have known Willy about five weeks by living in the same house; I met her about one o'clock, and asked her to take these handkerchiefs home for me; I was selling fruit.

Willy. When he took me he said, "You have got a handkerchief "I said, "Yes;" he said, "Who gave it you?" I said, "Those three young men;" I am innocent; I did not know it was stolen; I had been out with my husband at nine o'clock; I went into the fair about eleven; Smith said, "Will you take these handkerchiefs for me?" I said, "Yes."

GEORGE KEMP
re-examined. Smith was with the other two, covering them—they all three went to Willy and delivered the handkerchief to her.

Smith. It was only I went to her; we were there three hours after we handed her the handkerchiefs; I was selling fruit. Witness. It might he an hour—he was not selling fruit—the person robbed was a respectable looking man—I did not ask him any questions—I could not get near him—there it no initial on the handkerchief.

TRUBY—
GUILTY .

WILLY—
GUILTY .

WRIGHT—
GUILTY .

SMITH—
GUILTY .
Transported for ten years.
(There were two other indictments against the male prisoners.)

1331.
WILLIAM HENRY HATTER and
CHARLES THOMPSON were indicted for
unlawfully breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Samuel Brightley, with intent to steal.

ANN BRIGHTLEY . I am the wife of Samuel Brightley, a bricklayer, and live in Crossfield-lane, Deptford. He is the housekeeper—on the afternoon of the 8th of April (Easter Monday,) about three o'clock, I left my house leaving no one in it—I bolted the back door, locked the front, and shut the window and shutters—I came home at half-past seven, and found people round the house—the back door was broken open, and the staple out—I did not lose any thing.

HENRY BRIGHTLEY . I am the son of last witness—I live with my father—on Monday the 8th of April, about seven o'clock, I was with Taylor at the top of the lane, about thirty yards from home, and saw the two prisoners go into the house—they went quietly in at the door—I did not see how they got in—I directly went and knocked at the door which was shut—I heard one say to the other, "Don't open the door"—I called Taylor, and told him to get over the fence, and get in the back way which he did—I heard them come down stairs—I got over the fence myself and saw both of them in the back yard—I heard them run up stairs again, and Hatter opened the door, he made use of a very bad expression, and said he would knock my eye out—he knocked me down—I got up again—he ran down Crossfield-lane, and down a turning where there is no thoroughfare—I there caught him, and gave him into custody.

GEORGE RANDALL . I live in Crossfield-lane, Deptford. I saw the pri
soners come out of the prosecutor's house and run away—I did not know them before—I went after Thompson and took him—I did not say any thing—he offered me 5s. if I would let him go.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you lose sight of him at all? A. No—when I took him, he said, "I am done."

SAMUEL BRIGHTLEY . I came home between seven and eight o'clock—I found a bag under the range—I took it out, and found in it four skeleton keys and a small wrench bar about a foot long—I gave them to the officer.
Cross-examined. Q. Who lives in the house besides you? A. No one—I rent it.
FRANCIS TAYLOR . I was with Brightley, and saw the prisoners—I saw Hatter come out of the back of the house, and assisted in securing him.

HATTER—
GUILTY Aged 20

THOMPSON—
GUILTY Aged 27
Confined six months.

1332.
JAMES REGAN and
SAMUEL WILLIAMS were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
James Hautot, from his per
son; to which they both pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.
SURREY CASES.

1333.
WILLIAM GOODWIN and
JOHN BASHFORD were indicted for
stealing 1 bushel of a mixture of chaff, oats, and beans, value 18d.; the goods of
Harvey Combe and others, the masters of Goodwin; to which

GOODWIN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined One Month.

BASHFORD pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 63.—
Confined Two Months.

1334.
JOHN BRADLEY was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Neate, in the night of the 30th of March, at St. Mary, Newington, with intent to steal and stealing therein, 1 till, value 6d.; 32 cheroots, 3s.; 1 box, 2d.; 1 bag, 2d.; 1 clock weight, 2d.; 2 sixpences, and 12 pence, his property.

RICHARD NEAVE . I am a licensed retailer of beer, and live in Villier's-street, Walworth Common, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington. I keep the house—on Saturday, the 30th of March, I locked up my house—between two and three in the morning I was aroused by the police, I came down, and saw the prisoner in custody at the foot of the stairs near the bar—I found the tap room window facing the street, wide open, and my till on the table, which I had left underneath the bar counter over night—I missed two six
pences—a bag was taken from a cupboard in the bar, which was found in an adjoining room—the house had been entered by the tap room window which was shut down close over night, and the shutters were shut, but not fastened—I had seen the prisoner in the tap room the evening before—he was not in the tap room when I went to bed.

Prisoner. I was in the house playing at cards; I was intoxicated; I fell asleep, and got under the seat, and was locked in; I could not make any body hear; I pulled down the shutters, and the policeman was standing out
side. Witness. It is a very small tap room—alter all the customers were gone I went and took the glasses off the table—the gas was burning strong, and if he had been in the room I must have seen him.

HENRY PRIEST (police-constable P 243.) I was on duty on Walworth Common on the 30th of March, between two and three o'clock in the morning—I noticed the prosecutor's tap-room window open—I got in, and found the prisoner in the back kitchen, in one corner, without his shoes—they were in the tap-room.

HENRY BURR (police-constable P 175.) I know the prisoner—on the Saturday night, about a quarter or twenty minutes past twelve o'clock, I saw him and two others take a cab in East-street, and go in the direction of Villiers-street—about a quarter to two I met him again—I suspected, stop
ped, and searched him, and found on him a halfpenny, a tobacco-box, a lucifer-box, and a knife—he was not quite half a mile from Villiers-street—he was sober.

Prisoner. It was on Friday night, the 30th, I was going down East-lane, and met two young chaps and a cabman I knew; we asked him to give us a ride; we all three got in, and rode a little way; we then came back, and had some beer at the Bell; I saw the policeman about an hour and a half after, and he told me to go about my business.

RICHARD NEATE
re-examined. A box of cheroots was taken from a cup
board in the bar, and found on the floor: and the bag and money were all removed from where I had left them.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Confined One Year.

1335.
THOMAS FREEMAN,
ALFRED YOUNG , and
JOHN MUR
PHY , were indicted for
feloniously making and counterfeiting 3 penny pieces.

SAMUEL HARRIS (policeman.) On the 29th of March, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I went into No. 12, Norfolk-street, Southwark, to search for stolen property—the street door was open—Annett and Church went with me to the door of the back attic—we found the door fastened inside by a piece of wood put into a sort of iron dowell—we forced it open, and, on entering, found the three prisoners there—Freeman was sitting by the side of the fire—I saw him put his hand on this pipkin, which was on the fire—he took hold of it, turned it over, and spilled some of the contents into the fire—I could distinctly see it contained metal—I went and laid hold of it, then went buck to the door to prevent their going out, and picked up this file—the other officers secured the prisoners—as I entered the room I saw Young with his arm throw something out of the window, which was open, and which looked into the back yard—after taking them to the station, we all returned to the back yard—we had been absent about twenty minutes—I observed the window through which Young had thrown something, and in the back yard of No. 19, Pepper-street, which is the next yard, I found a counterfeit penny piece—I did not see Murphy do anything—I saw Young distinctly throw something through the window.

EDWIN JAMES ANNETT . I went with Harris on the 29th to this house—I saw Harris, on going into the room, take the pot off the fire, and take it to
wards the door—Freeman was sitting nearest to the door, close to the fire, and had a mould in his hand, which I produce—I took up a penny piece which dropped from the mould in his hand, with part of the get on it—it was very hot, I could scarcely hold it—the moment I took hold of him he broke the mould between his finger and thumb—I saw Young get up, and throw some pieces of metal, apparently about the size of penny pieces, from his right hand, through the window, which was open—I saw them fall into the yard of No. 20, Pepper-street, about five yards from the house—when I entered the room Murphy was sitting close to the window—they all sat close together—it is a very small room—when I went in Murphy got up—I secured the pri
soners, searched the room, and found these coloured penny pieces on the floor—I found this spoon on the window cill, and a bag containing blue—these pincers were on the floor, near where Murphy had sat—this bag was damp—I found this knife on the hob, with a piece of metal attached to it—I took the prisoners to the station, returned, and found four penny pieces, coloured like copper, in the yard of No. 20, Pepper-street, where I had seen Young throw them—Freeman was looking for something—I asked what he was looking for—he said, for the lock and key—I said, "Do you belong to the room?—he said, "Yes"—I saw a padlock in the room-Freeman showed me another padlock—he said that was not the one they locked the place with.
Young. Q. Where was I standing when I threw the things out? A. In the middle of the room, close to Murphy—I saw the penny pieces drop on the ground in the yard—Freeman was in his shirt sleeves.

SAMUEL CHURCH . I went with the other policemen to this house, and saw the prisoners there—I saw Young throw some pieces of coin out of window—I found a penny piece, and a bag of plaster of Paris, on the mantel-shelf over the fireplace.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. This pipkin contains metal similar to what the counterfeit coin is composed of—here is a small piece of a plaster of Paris mould, which has part of the impression of

the obverse side of a penny piece—here are six penny pieces, coloured, and finished for circulation; and two uncoloured, one as it comes from the mould, with the get, and another unfinished, but without the get—these must have been cast in a perfect mould—there is not sufficient left to enable me say it is the mould they were cast in, but they correspond with what is left of it—this blue is sulphate of copper, which will produce the colour of copper on the white metal, by dabbing it—here is an iron spoon, which appears to have been used to lade the metal into the pipkin—the moulds are usually made of plaster of Paris—the pincers would separate the get from the coin—these implements are all that would be required to make counterfeit penny pieces.
Freeman's Defence. None of these things belong to the room; a man named Adnam brought them, and asked me to take care of them; he put them into the fire; directly he was gone the policemen came up.
Murphy's Defence. I left my place, and went up to ask Freeman to let me leave my shirt and stockings there till I got a lodging; he asked me to sit down, and up came the policemen.

FREEMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

YOUNG—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

MURPHY—
NOT GUILTY .

1336.
ANN THOMAS was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly utter
ing counterfeit coin; having been before convicted of a like offence.

CALEB. EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant solicitor to her Majesty's Mint. I produce a copy of the record of conviction of Ann Thomas in Oct., 1841—I have compared it with the record—it is correct—(read,)
JOHN BURROWS (policeman.) I was present in this Court at the trial of Ann Thomas in 1841—the prisoner is that woman.

JOSEPH WILLIAM WHITAKER . I live at the Noah's Ark, Park-street, South
wark. About a week previous to the 28th of Feb., in the afternoon, the pri
soner came and had a quarters of gin, and gave me a bad shilling—I ex
amined it, and put it on the counter, saying, "This is a bad shilling"—she immediately took it up, and put it into her mouth—I do not know whether the swallowed it or not, but I could not get it from her—I detained her for an hour and a half, could not find a policeman, and let her go—I am certain she is the woman—there was an old woman with her.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How long was the shilling in your possession? A. Two or three minutes—the old woman went out, but I ran and prevented her—the prisoner did not offer to go—I think it was a week before the 28th of Feb.—I had a case here that day—I am satisfied of her being the person, and it was within a week of the time she was at Union-hall.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You happened to be at the Police-court? A. Yes, and recognized her.

SARAH PARTRIDGE . I am the wife of Samuel Partridge, of the White Hart. On the 28th of Feb. the prisoner came for half-a-quarters of gin with another woman—she gave me a bad shilling, which I bit, and said it was bad—the other woman gave me 2d. for the gin—she wanted the shilling back, and was abusive because I would not give it her—I kept it till the 11th of March in my pocket—she then came again, and my niece served her with gin, which she paid a bad shilling for—I said she was the woman who came the other day—she said, "I am certain you are mistaken, but I am positive of her—she went out directly, and my husband followed her.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you never see two persons exactly alike? A. No—I am certain of her-the other woman was not a bit like her.

JAMES SCROGGINS . I was at Mr. Partridge's on the 28th of Feb.—I am certain the prisoner is the woman who had the gin and offered the bad shil-ling on the 11th of March I was in the house, and heard of a bad shilling being taken—I went out and saw the prisoner, and recognised her as having been there on the 28th of Feb.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you live in the house? A. No—I know the first time was the 28th of Feb., as here was a funeral that day—the prisoner was in the house between six and eight minutes—I stood in front of the bat—the prisoner tendered the shilling which was refused, and the old woman paid the 2d.—I saw her for six or seven minutes—there were two or three men there.

SARAH NAILOR . On the 11th of March I was serving at my aunt's, Mrs. Partridge's, and saw the prisoner come there just before gas-light, for two-penny worth of gin—I served her—she put a bad shilling on the counter—I bit and bent it—my aunt said, "This is the same person who was here be-fore"—I went to my uncle, and he followed her.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not your aunt take charge of the shilling? A. No; I gave it to my uncle, not to my aunt at all—I showed it to her—I am sure she did not have it and give it to my uncle.

SAMUEL PARTRIDGE . On the 11th of March I received a shilling from my wife, and gave it to inspector Cowling—I received one the same day from my niece, and gave that to my wife—she put it into a glass behind the bar—I took it to the station—there was no other shilling in the glass—I followed the prisoner out about 100 yards, and gave her in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you receive the shilling from your niece? A. I suppose about six o'clock—I gave that shilling to my wife, and she returned it to me—I was at home on the 28th of Feb.—I got the shilling uttered on the 28th of Feb. first on the 11th of March—I took it from the glass behind the door—my wife did not keep it in her pocket till the 11th of March.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. When did you first see the shilling uttered on the 28th of Feb.? A. On the 28th—my wife bit it and put it into the glass, and there, to the best of my belief, it remained—I believe it was still there on the 11th, when the prisoner came, but I cannot say—I put the one my niece gave me, into my pocket, and followed the prisoner—I took the other, and aimed that in my band.
JOHN RICHARD COWLING . I received a shilling on the 11th of March from Mr. Partridge, which I produce.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you kept it ever since? A. Yes—I made a mark on it.
JOHN FROST . I received a shilling from Mr. Partridge on the 11th of March, and took the prisoner in charge.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These two shillings are counterfeit.
NOT GUILTY .

1337.
JOSEPH WHITE SIMMONS was indicted
for feloniously utter-ing a forged bill of exchange for 200l., with intent to defraud
Elisha Under
wood; and that he had been before convicted of felony.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution,
