ELISHA UNDERWOOD . I formerly kept a beer-shop, but am now out. of business. I have known the prisoner about two years—I served him at his lodgings with beer—I now live in Chorley-place, Kent-road-the prisoner

came to my place in Jan. last, and said he had a bill for 200l. on a very res
pectable man drawn by Shoppee, a builder, and the acceptor was a very res
pectable man, a wine and spirit merchant, named George Heron—he had known him some years—he asked me to take half of the bill, to discount half of it—I told him I never had any thing to do with bills, and he proposed taking me round to see two referees, one at Bankside, and one in Mark-lane, as to the respectability of Heron—I went round with him, and found Mr. Heron was a highly respectable man—I then proposed writing to Mr. Heron to know if it was his acceptance or not—he proposed to do so, and two days after produced this letter to me—I declined advancing any money till I went to Booth's, the distillers—the prisoner gave me this letter, and I went to Messrs. Booth, who confirmed Mr. Heron's being a respectable man—I re
turned to my house in Chorley-place, and then advanced him first 81l., and then 12l.—I was to have 100l. when the bill became due, on the 19th of April—the prisoner wrote his name on the back of the bill—I went down to Uxbridge on the 29th of March, and saw Mr. G. H. Heron, produced the bill and the letter, and at his request deposited the bill with Mr. Wood bridge, an attorney, of Uxbridge—the prisoner wrote a memorandum for me at the time I advanced the money, which was for him to receive half the money—I have not got that memorandum—I gave it to him—he wrote it, and I signed it—I did not know Heron till I went to Uxbridge.
Prisoner. Q. Have not I paid you a portion of that 12l.? A. You paid me 5l. 10s. back.

JOSEPH SHOPPEE . I am a builder, and live at Uxbridge. I know Mr. Heron, a wine and coal merchant, perfectly well—he is a very respectable man—this bill purports to be drawn by me—I never drew it, or authorised the prisoner or any body to put my name to it—I never saw it till it was produced before the Magistrate—(bill read.)

GEORGE WILLIAM HERON , wine and coal-merchant, Uxbridge. The pri
soner was in my employ in 1841—the acceptance to this bill is not my writ
ing—I never authorised the prisoner or any one to accept it for me, or knew of its existence—this letter was not written by me, or by my authority.
MR. WOODBRIDGE. I am clerk to the Justices. This bill and letter were deposited with me at Mr. Heron's request—I have had them ever since.
CHARLES OTWAY (police-inspector.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 31st of March at Hercules-buildings, Lambeth.

(Letter read.) "26th Jan. Sir,—I have to acknowledge the receipt of yours of yesterday, inclosing a bill of exchange for 200l., and requesting to know whether it is my acceptance, and will be duly honoured when presented. I return the bill, and beg to say it is my signature; I will take care it shall be provided for when due; I have been in business twenty years, and my father thirty years, and challenge any one to say either of our acceptances were ever returned. Messrs. Booth are my distillers, and for your satisfaction I refer you to them for my respectability; I trust you will then be satisfied, for when in town I was given to understand inquiries had already been made of two persons with whom I do business; I do not like so much inquiry about matters so trivial, and if I had not given Mr. Shoppee the bill, I would have made a different arrangement, paid cash, and taken a discount. G. H. HERON."

CHARLES OTWAY (police-inspector.) I produce a certificate of the con
viction of Joseph White Simmons, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the roan—(read.)
MR. HERON re-examined. The prisoner was at that time in my service, and prosecuted by me.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

1338.
ANN CARROLL was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Elizabeth Hobbs; and on the Coroner's inquisition with manslaughter.

WILLIAM HOBBS . I am a boiler-maker, and life in Holland-street, Borough. At the time this happened I lived at 2, Bird Cage-alley, where Carroll and his wife lived—there were several lodgers in the house—I and my wife occupied the front-room second floor—I had been there four or five weeks when this happened—Carroll was my landlord—on the 2nd of March I left my wife in the Black friars-road as I went to work—we had been at a public-house, and had half-a-quarters of rum together—she did not drink quite a quarter of it—I left her at five minutes before six in the morning—she was in good health—I never knew her in better health—when I came home at night I found her dead—her name was Elizabeth Hobbs.

SARAH BRAY . I lived at this time at No. 1, Bird Cage-alley, next door to this house. On the morning of the 2nd of March I heard cries of murder proceeding from the up-stairs window of Carroll's house—I heard people quarrelling very much—I went to the street-door, and demanded for the door to be opened—I did not see the prisoner at first, nor her husband—when I first saw the prisoner I said, "Mrs. Carroll, what have you got about? or what do you make this noise about? why don't you send for a policeman? if you cannot agree with this woman, have her taken up, don't ill use her like this"—Mrs. Carroll held two pair of boots in her hand, and said to the deceased, "When you pay me for my broken things I will give you your boots back, and not before "—the blood was then running down the left side of the deceased's neck from the back of the neck, and I saw a mark of a blow on her temple—it seemed a very heavy blow—the deceased had a fork in her hand—the prisoner's husband was standing by her side—the deceased beat the fork on the stairs, and called Mrs. Carroll very bad words indeed several times, and she said, "I wish it was one o'clock, for my husband to come home, I would have my revenge for beating me like this'—she addressed herself to Mr. and Mrs. Carroll—I did not see anything in Mr. Carroll's band—he might have had something, and I not see it—I went into my own room—I then heard the deceased woman repealing these bad words again, saying, "Don't strike me with a poker, I am not a man, I am a woman"—she addressed herself to Mr. Carroll—she said, "Mr. Carroll, don't strike me with a poker."

COURT. Q. Was the deceased in liquor? A. It is my opinion she had a little liquor; but I don't think she had more than to know what she was about—she stood correct on her feet—I saw nothing in the prisoner's hands, except the boots.

HARRIET MOSEA . I lived at this time in Carroll's house—the deceased came into my room—she was quite sober then—it was about seven o'clock in the morning when I saw her first—I saw her again about half-past seven—she seemed the worse for drink then—I heard her go into her own room, which was over mine—soon after, I heard two people go up stairs—I was in bed—they went into the deceased's room—I could hear the voices of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll in her room—I did not hear what was said; but I swear it was Mr. and Mrs. Carroll—I afterwards heard a smashing of crockery—a few mi
nutes after that, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll came into my room, followed by the deceased—Mr. Carroll brought a bed into my room, and said he would not have such work in his house, he would get rid of the lodgers if they would not be more sociable, he would not have drunken people in his place—the deceased said, she would have revenge—they afterwards went down stairs—she followed Mr. and Mrs. Carroll down—I saw the deceased again in about

five minutes—she came back again—I did not hear any cries of murder—when she came hack she seemed very much fatigued, and her neck was bleed
ing—she was sick—the prisoner sent for a doctor—I have not seen Mr. Carroll since—the doctor came, and said she was quite dead—I do not suppose that was more than half-an-hour after she came into my room—I observed a wound on her temple—I saw a fork in the deceased's hand when she came into my room, and when she was sitting on the bed—she did not do anything with it; but knocked it against the door, and the step, saying, she would have revenge—the prisoner came back to the house after she had been for the doctor—her husband went away immediately; I have not seen him since.
Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Mrs. Hobbs was tipsy, was she not? A. She appeared so—I did not know her before.

MARY BURNS . I live with my mother in Birdcage-alley, in Carroll's house—on this morning I was in bed when the deceased came home—I saw her about half past nine o'clock—she had been drinking—I saw the prisoner—they had words together—Mrs. Carroll was coming down stairs, and the de
ceased coming up—Mrs. Carroll said to her, "Betsey, instead of your making Mrs. Burns tipsy, you had better give her 6d. to get some breakfast"—my mother was very tipsy that morning and had been out with the deceased—Mrs. Hobbs said it was her own money, she had a right to do what she liked with it—Mrs. Carroll followed her up stairs to her own room—I heard a great deal of quarrelling between them, and crockery smashed—Mr. Carroll ran up stairs—I called out to know what it was all about—I heard him go into the room, and after that I heard a great deal of scuffling—I heard Mrs. Hobbs cry out, if her husband was at home, they would not ill-use her—I went up stairs once, and saw Mrs. Carroll standing on the landing, just by the room-door, with a cap in her hand, which was torn, and her hair hanging down her back, as if she had been in a scuffle—Mr. Carroll took the bed off deceased's bedstead, and brought it down stairs—he said, she should go out of the place—I did not see him put a hand on her—she called Mr. Carroll some very bad name, and threw something at him—at that time the deceased was bleeding behind her neck—I did not hear her say anything to Mr. Carroll about it—after Mr. Carroll went down stairs, the deceased followed him down to his own room door, and they were wrangling together there—I afterwards saw the deceased very sick, and she said, both Mr. and Mrs. Carroll had been beating her—that was the last word she spoke.
Cross-examined. Q. You never saw the prisoner strike her? A. No—I heard Mr. Carroll cry out, "Unloose me; leave go of me."

WILLIAM ALLEN . I lodged at this house—I first heard the noise a little after nine o'clock—I heard the deceased cry out "Murder"—my room is above hers—I came down stairs, and saw Mrs. Hobbs—she called Mr. Carroll very bad names several times—I interfered to take Mr. Carroll away, and advised him to go away—he said several times, "She has tried to job me with the fork several times," and said, "If I had the poker I would knock her head off." I went down stairs, and Mr. Carroll followed me—in about half an hour the deceased came down stairs—I heard a quarrel about the boots and crockery between the deceased and Mr. and Mrs. Carroll—Mr. Carroll told her if she would replace the things she had broken he would give her the boots—they were then on a box in the room—a few minutes after, he com
plained that she had run the fork into his lip—I did not see any sign of that—the deceased had a fork in her hand, and was trying to job it at him—I saw her do that upon the landing, but did not see it strike him—there was a piece of broken long below stairs in his room where we were at this time—Carroll

picked up the tongs and ran into the passage with it—the deceased was in the passage—I did not see the deceased again until she was dead—I saw her come on the landing, she appeared to have a severe blow on the temple—that was before Carroll went out with the broken tong—shortly before she died I heard Mrs. Carroll say to Mr. Carroll, "If it had not been for you there would have been no row at all, I could have settled it all myself with
out you"—Mr. Carroll then went away.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you aware whether Mrs. Hobbs had been out the whole night? A. I am not—she was tipsy when I saw her.

COURT. Q. Did you see any weapon in the prisoner's hands that morn
ing? A. No—I saw the wound on the temple when the deceased was on the landing before the man took up the broken tongs—I do not know how she got the wound—I heard a great noise up stairs, as if she was falling about—it might have been from her tumbling down or something—the landing is up two pair of stairs—it was on the ground floor that Carroll went into the passage.

SARAH SIMMERS . I lived at No. 1, Birdcage-alley, next door to Carroll's. I heard cries of murder this morning, about half-past ten or near eleven o'clock—I looked through a hole in the wainscoting of the landing-place, and saw Mr. and Mrs. Carroll and the deceased in he front room, second floor, quarrelling—I heard the deceased call Mrs. Carroll very ugly names, and on her doing that, Mrs. Carroll struck her with her hand in the face—she did not fall down from the blow—Mrs. Hobbs called the name again, and then Mr. Carroll struck her with his fist several times—they all left the room, and went out of my sight—I heard the deceased talking to Mr. Carroll—she had a German-silver fork in her hand, and was beating it up against the wall, and asking him if he wanted to make property of it—I heard her say to him, that she was no man, she was a woman, and not to hit her with a poker—I did not hear her say "You b——, don't hit me with the poker"—the next thing I heard was, that the deceased was dead—when Carroll went down, and I saw him, he had nothing in his hand.
Cross-examined. Q. How large is the crevice, have you to stoop down to look? A. No—I never spoke to Mrs. Hobbs in my life.
COURT. Q. When the prisoner struck her, was it with the fist or open hand? A. I cannot say—the deceased did nothing on being struck—she had nothing in her hand that I saw, nor had the prisoner.

WILLIAM RENDLE . I am the parish surgeon. About ten o'clock on Saturday morning, the 2nd of March, I was called in to see the deceased—both Mr. and Mrs. Carroll came to fetch me—they waited for me, and accom
panied me back—I examined the deceased, and observed she was bruised about the face—I did not observe that she had drank very much—I should think not—she was dead when I got there—I could not account for her death then—there were external bruises, but not sufficient—I opened her head on the Monday—externally there were marks of bruises over the left eye, and also a contused wound behind the right ear—on removing the scalp, there were large clots of blood effused, corresponding with the external marks—there was also evidence of blows being struck immediately behind the right ear—I should say that was not done with great violence—I saw the piece of tongs at the inquest—it may have been produced by that—a fist would not produce the wound behind the ear, it must have been something sharp—there was no wound on the temple, but three or four external bruises—in my judgment death was caused by concussion of the brain, produced by repeated blows—I should not think the blow behind the ear sufficient of itself, but, in combination with other circumstances, it would aid—it was the only wound—the other marks could be accounted for by blows from a fist or hand—if she
was excited it would increase the danger—she was in perfect health in every respect.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you on any previous occasion examined the head? A. Constantly—to a certain extent it is uncertain, from the appear
ance of the head, whether a person has died from apoplexy or external injury, but finding the woman in perfect health in other particulars, I do not consider it could be produced but from injury—she was not of a full habit of body—I considered her a well-formed woman, and in good condition—I examined the liver and all other parts—there was no disease of any kind—I did not smell any spirits at her mouth—I should imagine if a person had taken much spirits within an hour of death, I should find it by smelling the mouth—if a person died from drinking spirits, I consider I could perceive it all over the viscera—there were many marks of apoplexy about the head—I think I could take on myself to say she did not die from apoplexy—there was considerable congestion of the brain, but there was not apoplexy from the escape of blood—congestion of the brain would not produce death, considered alone, at that age and state of health—if she were in a great passion and under the influence of liquor, I should think it just possible—the bone was not injured, but death would be caused by concussion of the brain by a violent shaking of the brain, without anything else—I should say repeated blows would produce concussion of the brain—I was led to think she might have struck against a sharp edge of a partition—if a pail had been on the stairs, I think the injury would have been more extensive—the appearance of the brain led me to be
lieve the whole I saw was from excitement.

MR. DOANE. Q. You found considerable extravasation of blood corre
sponding with the external marks? A. Yes, and from that I infer there was repeated blows, which induces me to say that concussion was the imme
diate cause of death, and having heard she was sick, I infer it was a case of concussion; that is a usual symptom—in my judgment the blows would produce the effects I witnessed, and those effects would produce concussion of the brain—I consider she died from that—the congestion of the brain must have assisted; but that I consider was produced by excitement of the mind.

COURT. Q. The clotted blood had nothing to do with the death? A. No. that only indicated that there had been external violence—I should judge from the appearances, she must have received blows of great importance—I dare not say she died entirely from external violence—it was the chief cause—sickness does occur in apoplexy; but it is more especially a corroborative symptom of concussion—I consider that a person of her age and health would scarcely die of apoplexy—I consider external violence the chief cause of death—congestion of the brain taking place at the same time, would acce
lerate the death, chiefly caused by concussion—if no blow had been struck, and I had found none of the symptoms consequent upon a blow, I should not have seen cause enough to produce death.

ROBERT STURGEON (police-constable M 4.) I went to the house where the deceased lived, at half-past twelve o'clock, and found the dead body there—I accompanied the prisoner to the station with another constable—I re
ceived a piece of iron from the beadle of the parish, at the workhouse.

WILLIAM ALLEN
re-examined. This is the piece of iron which Carroll picked up—I saw some blood running down the deceased's neck on the landing—that was before I saw Carroll with the poker—that was before she came down stairs.
NOT GUILTY .

1339.
THOMAS HARRISON was indicted
for an indecent assault.

GUILTY .
Confined Fifteen Months.

1340.
JOHANNAH BURNS and
ELIZABETH BROWN were in
dicted for
stealing 1 brooch, value 2l. 10s.; part of a brooch, 1l. 10s. 1 dwt. of gold, 2s.; and 6 stones, 1l.; the goods of
George Jeffreyson, from his person; and that Burns had been previously convicted of felony.

GEORGE JEFFREYSON . I live in Druid's-place, Peck ham-rye. On the 22nd of March, at three o'clock in the afternoon, I was at the Duke's Head in the Mint—I went into the parlour in hopes to see a son of mine—I had a glass of ale—the prisoners came in—I had never seen them before—they followed me out—I went to see a person in the Excise-office—one of them followed me very closely—I looked back, and she asked me if I would give her 1d., which I did to get rid of her—Burns came up and asked me for another—I refused—she said, "I will take this," and made a dart at my brooch, and took it, the pin of it was left in my shirt—Brown addressed me—I said, "Will you resign what you have taken?"—Burns threw it down, and a third came up and carried it off—I called, "Stop thief," which caused them to be appre
hended—there were more than twenty people about me.

JOHN DIPPLE , of Nicholas-row, Bethnalgreen. I was at the factory-door at No. 17, Mint-street—I saw three girls rustling this old gentleman—Burns rushed into him, and took the brooch out of his breast, gave it to the other, and all three ran away together.

Burns. You said at first, that Brown took the brooch, and after this you said it was another female; the Magistrate said, "Are not you ashamed of your
self?" and you said you did not know which took it Witness. Brown picked it up, and all three ran down Kent-street together—the third one put it down her bosom.

COURT. Q. Is this your mark? A. Yet—I made it before it was read over to me—(deposition read)—"I looked out at the street-door about half-past three o'clock, and saw the prisoners and another female; Burns snatched the brooch from the prosecutor, dropped if, picked it up, and gate it to the female."

GEORGE BROOKS , of Broker's-row. High-street, Lambeth. I noticed the dis
turbance—I saw the girl strike the old gentleman—Burns took the brooch out of his breast—Brown picked it up, and gave it to the other one—I followed them down King-street—they offered me 6d. if I would not tell—I told a policeman—I have always given the same account—(deposition read)—"I saw the two prisoners struggling with the prosecutor—Burns took the brooch, chucked it towards the one not here, who picked it up, and ran down Kent-street."

HENRY ASSITER (police-constable M 30.) I found the prisoner Burns in the privy of a house in the neighbourhood, and Brown outside the door—no brooch was found—the prosecutor was quite sober—he had been drinking a little.

Burns. You said you took me out of the privy and you took me out of the passage. Witness. Burns was sitting on the privy—Brooks said, "That is one of them "—I said, "I shan't take you now, I know where to find you if I want you "—I found the prosecutor—he said he would give them both in charge—I took Burns—I saw Brown sitting at the door of a public-house, and locked her up.

Burns's Defence. I never saw the man; I was in Kent-street, Borough: two boys came into the house, and said I was the woman. They took me about five yards, and let me go, by St. George's-church. I went into the George, and while there he took me into custody; he dragged me more like a dog than a female; I did not have a bit of gown on my back.

GEORGE JEFFREYSON
re-examined. I am certain she is the same girl—she craved charity—I was perfectly sober—I was very much insulted.
Brown's Defence. I was sitting on the step of a door, and the policeman took me—I had just left my father's house.

JOHN CHANNELL (police-constable M 74.) I produce a certificate of Burns's former conviction from the clerk of the peace for Surrey—(read)—I was present at the trial—she was the person tried and convicted.

BURNS—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

BROWN—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1340.
ANN BOYENS was indicted
for stealing 1 neck-chain, value 2s.; 4 yards of ribbon. 1s. 4d.; and 1/4 of a yard of flannel, 4d.; the goods of
Henry Trendall, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Ten Days.

1341.
JAMES TRENCH and
HENRY CLARK were indicted for
stealing 92lbs. weight of coals, value 10l.; the goods of
Ann Emma Druce and another.

WILLIAM WHITE . I am lighterman to Ann Emma Druce and William Druce, coal-merchant. I left their barge, called the Jane, at Rotherhithe, on the 13th of March, with twenty-one tons of coals in it—next morning the po
liceman brought me some coals—I saw several places in the barge where the coals had been taken from, and to the best of my knowledge those the po
liceman brought, had been taken from that barge.

HENRY JOSEPH KING (Thames police-constable, No. 30.) About six o'clock in the morning of the 14th of March, I saw the prisoners take a boat, and go to the Jane, take the coals off it into their net, wash them, and throw them into their boat—I took them, and showed the same coals to White.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

TRENCH—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

CLARK—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

div1.p:
1342.
TIMOTHY IREDALE was indicted
for stealing 1 bag, value 3d.; 2 half-crowns, and 4 shillings; the property of
Benjamin Keable.

MARY ANN KEABLE . I am single, and reside with my father, Benjamin Keable. On the 22nd of March I left the shop for about five minutes—I was sitting in the parlour, and lifted my eyes, and saw something passing from be
hind the counter—I saw a boy running from it, and heard money rattle—he ran out into the street, and I after him—I saw him throw away a box, which had been in our till, on the next area—it contained, to the best of my belief, two half-crowns and four shillings—I looked at the till directly I returned, and missed it—the prisoner was taken in about an hour—to the best of my belief, he is the boy.

WILLIAM BURT . On the 22nd of March I saw the prisoner run out of the prosecutor's shop, and place something on the area of the next shop—Keable followed him, calling, "Stop thief"—I followed, and never lost sight of him, only in turning the corners—it was nearly an hour before he was taken—I suppose he ran for a mile.
Prisoner. I throw myself on your consideration. Being out of employ, and being about the streets, has brought me into contact with bad characters.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Months, One Fortnight solitary.

1343.
DENNIS NEALE was indicted
for stealing 4 gas cocks, value As.; and 6 union joints, 6s.; the goods of
Andrew Spottiswood and others, his masters.
HENRY WORCESTER . I am store-keeper at the gasworks at Vauxhall;

Andrew Spottiswood and others are the proprietors. The prisoner was in their service—on the 20th of March I placed some gas cocks and fitting in a drawer—I received information, and placed myself, with another party, on the watch—at twenty minutes past eight o'clock the prisoner undid the door at the bottom of the stairs, then undid the room door where these things were, and was inside about three minutes—he then came out, locked the door, went down stairs, and locked the bottom door—I went into the room, and missed these articles—when he left work, about five minutes past nine o'clock, we followed him to a marine store-shop, but we were too late there.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Did you go to this room directly after he left? A. Yes—it was then past eight o'clock—it was not dark, there was a gaslight at the corner—we have never found this property—the prisoner comes at six o'clock to relieve the door-keeper, and the key of this room hangs down-stairs in the lodge—the prisoner has the care of the lodge when he comes, to see that no one goes into the room—the men leave work at half-past five o'clock, except about fifty of them—I had no orders to stop the prisoner—I went into the room and missed the cocks which were there safe when he went in, and they were gone when he came out—I saw them safe at five o'clock, and again at a quarter before six—there has been no ill feeling between him and me—he has been most respectable up to the present time.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—Recommended to mercy,—
Confined Three Months

1344.
ROBERT GRAY and
CHARLES CHILDS were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Harrison, about the hour of ten in the night, on the 26th of March, at St. George the Martyr, Southwark, and stealing 1 coat, value 3l.; and one pair of trowsers, value 10s., the goods of
Henry Henley; and that Childs had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY HENLEY . I live at No. 7, Martin-street, in the parish of St. George, Southwark. I occupy a back-room in the house of George Harrison—it is a lodging house—on the night of the 26th of March, I left Sarah Harrison, to go to the Strand Theatre—I left a coat and trowsers locked up in my box—I am sure my box was locked when I left—I came back about one o'clock in the morning—my room door was then open, my box broken open, and the coat and trowsers gone.

SARAH HARRISON . I went to the theatre—I left home about half-past six o'clock, after the last witness—I went and shut his door, and locked it—I am sure it was locked at half-past six—I returned home with him.
HENRY HARRISON . I remember my mother locking the room door—she placed the key on the table—my brother William had the key for a little while, while I went to take the child home.

MARY WHITEHEAD . I am the wife of James Whitehead. I occupy the back-room on the ground floor of this house—between half-past eleven and twelve o'clock that night, I heard some person go up stairs—I spoke to him as he went up, and it was Childs—he went into Henley's room—I saw him go up, and come down in about five minutes—I did not hear him open any door, but walk right in—when he came down he said all was right—I had seen him before—he bad no business there.
Child's. Q. Had you a candle in your hand? A. No, but there is a gas-light right opposite the door.
JOHN COLE . I was passing the house that night about half-past ten o'clock, and saw Childs standing at the door, and Gray came out with a bundle—they both went away together.
JOHN PALMER . I live in Flint-street; I know the prisoners. On the day

after this robbery I was standing at the corner of my own street, and heard a conversation between the prisoners, and two or three persons whose names I am not aware of—I heard the others say to Gray, "You have got a pair of boots on—I suppose you have been up to something "—he said, "Yes, done something last night round the corner in Martin-street"—the other said, "What was it?"—he said, "A coat and a pair of trowsers," and he said Childs had done him out of 6d.—he said he had sold them to a person named Evans.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

MART QUINLAND . I live at No. 5, Duke's-court, Paviour's-alley, Gravel-lane. I do washing or charing—I am a widow and have four children—Gray and his mother live in the same room with me—I have known him from in
fancy, and never knew any harm of him—he was in my place from that Tuesday night till the Wednesday morning—he came to my place about seven o'clock in the evening, and his mother gave him his supper about eight—I believe it was bread and coffee and a rasher of bacon—she told him to eat what he liked, and go to bed—I believe he went to bed about eleven o'clock—he never stirred out of the room—I got up first the next morning—he was then in bed—his mother got up before him—she went out to work—he had his breakfast before he went out.
GRAY. I am Gray's mother; I live at No. 2, Little Suffolk-street, which leads into the Borough—my son slept at home that night—I do not know Duke's-court.
(Mary Walsh, of Laystall-street, and Mary Lyons, gave Gray a good character.)
THOMAS GOOSE (police-constable L 160.) I produce a certificate of Childs' former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.

GRAY—
GUILTY .** Aged 15.—

CHILDS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—

1345.
WILLIAM DEAR was indicted
for stealing 1 gelding, price 15l., the property of Thomas Wheatley.

WILLIAM LEWIS ROGERS . I am foreman to Thomas Wheatley, a stage proprietor at Greenwich—the prisoner lived with him as horse-keeper, and left him on the 24th of March—Mr. Wheatley had a gelding which I saw safe on the 4th of April, at a quarter before nine o'clock at night in his yard at Greenwich—I missed it at half-past six the next morning—I saw it again on Saturday morning, the 6th of April, at Mr. Giddens', the slaughterer's, in Green-street, Black friars—I saw the prisoner at Union
hall—he had lived with Mr. Wheatley two years, and knew his premises as well as I did—I always found him honest.

JAMES GIDDENS . I am a horse slaughterer, and live in Green-street, Black friars—the prisoner came to my place about a quarter past six o'clock on the morning of the 5th of April, with a bay gelding—I looked out of window and asked where he brought it from—he said from Mr. Archer, a fishmonger at Dorking—I got up and let him into the yard—I asked if he knew anybody at Dorking—he said yes, and his master had told him to bring the gelding to me, and get what he could—I asked it he knew Mr. Doudeney, a harness-maker at Dorking—he gave me an account of him that I knew was not correct—I told him to wait till I went to get change—I went and called our inspector, Mr. Harris—he came, and we all walked to the station house.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I am inspector of places for slaughtering horses—I received information from Mr. Giddens last Friday, and I saw the prisoner at his place—he said the gelding was Mr. Archer's, of Dorking, and he had brought it there because it was glandered, which it was—I asked if he came through Kingston gate—he said yes, and that he started at two o'clock in the morning—I asked where the toll ticket was—he said he had not got it—I then took him to the station—I made inquiries at Kingston gate—I came back and told the prisoner what I had heard—he was locked up—he was taken in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark—Mr. Wheatley identified the gelding in the prisoner's presence, and the prisoner then said a man gave it him to take to the knacker's—Mr. Wheatley said that was false—he then put his hand to his hat and begged forgiveness—he said it was through poverty, and his wife and family had only had a penny loaf to eat for two days.

GUILTY . Aged 26—
Confined One Year.

1345.
HENRY HAMBURY was indicted
for unlawfully uttering coun
terfeit coin.
MESSRS. SCRIVEN and CHARNOCK conducted the Prosecution,

JOHN GARDNER . On the 21st Feb., I was near Kennington church and saw the prisoner—he asked if I would get him some beefsteaks and he would give me a halfpenny—he gave me a shilling—I went to Mr. Holdsworth's, near the church—I got the steaks and gave the shilling—I received eight
pence halfpenny in change—I went and gave the steaks and change to the prisoner—he gave me a halfpenny, and we then parted—a short time after I saw him again at the same place—he said if I would go to Mr. Green's and get a pennyworth of salts he would give me another halfpenny—he gave me a shilling—I went, and Mr. Green cut the shilling in halves—I went back to the prisoner and told him it was bad—he said, "You got it from the butchers "—I told him I did not (I had not brought any shilling from the butchers)—I went to the butcher, and when I came back the prisoner was gone—I did not see him again till the 7th of March, when he was in Horse
monger-lane—I picked him out as the man, from a number of others.

Prisoner. Q. When the policeman came with you, did he tell you what sort of a man I was? A. No—he asked if I was sure it was you—he said nothing to me before I came into the yard—I have no doubt of him.

JAMES RUSSELL . I am servant to Mr. Holdsworth, a butcher. Gardner came for half a pound of beefsteaks—he gave me a shilling—I gave him a sixpence and 2 1/2 d. change—I did not give him any shilling—the shilling he gave me I put into the bowl—there were three sixpences in it, but no other shilling—in a few minutes he brought me another shilling, and said "You gave me a bad shilling"—I said, "I could not, you only gave me a shilling"—I kept that shilling and the shilling he gave me first, and put them into a box—I afterwards gave them to the policeman.

THOMAS EMMERSON (police-constable V 16.) I received these two shil-lings from Russell on the 2nd of March—I was present when Gardner iden
tified the prisoner—he had no difficulty about it—I had not instructed him—he pointed him out—he was with ten or twelve others.

WILLIAM THOMAS . I saw the prisoner on the 29th of Feb. near Kenning
ton-gate, against the church—he asked if I would get him some pieces of meat, and he would give me a halfpenny—he gave me a shilling—I went to Mr. Griffin, the butcher, and gave the shilling which the prisoner gave me—I did not see the prisoner again—he was gone.

HENRY TYLER . On the 29th of Feb. William Thomas came to my mas
ter's
shop to buy some pieces—he offered me a shilling—I took it into the parlour to my master, to take 2d.,—I then went with William Thomas to where he said the man was who sent him, but the man was gone.
JOHN JAMES GRIFFIN . My servant Tyler gave me a shilling on the 29th of Feb.—I told him it was bad, detained it a little while, then gave it to the policeman.

HANNAH APPELBEE . My husband is a baker. On the 29th of Feb. the prisoner came to our shop for 1d. worth of bread, or a 1l., loaf—he gave me a good half-crown—I gave him 2s. 5d.—I noticed the two shillings which I gave him—one was old, and one new, but both were good—he turned and said, "You have given me a bad shilling"—I said, "No, I have not, I am too good a judge to take bad money"—I took the 1s. from him, and took it into the parlour to Mr. Appelbee.

WILLIAM JOSHUA APPELBEE . My wife gave me a shilling—I took it, and went into the shop to the prisoner—I said, "Did my mistress give you this shilling?"—he said "Yes"—I said, "I am sure she did not, I will have you searched before you go out"—he mumbled, and said, "I suppose I must be at the loss of it"—I went to shut the door, and he ran away—I caught him—I kept the shilling till it was cut, and then gave it to the policeman.
EDWIN POFFLEY (police-constable V 302.) I took the prisoner, and found on him five penny-pieces—I produce this shilling, which I got from Mr. Griffin.
WILLIAM TOMPKINS (police-constable V 119.) I assisted in taking the prisoner—I received this shilling from Mr. Appelbee.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are all counterfeit, and the two first were cast in the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw either of the boys.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

1346.
JOHN JENKINS was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

SARAH GREEN SCRIVENER . My husband keeps a tobacconist's shop in Blackfriars-road. On the 12th of March the prisoner came for half an ounce of tobacco—he gave me a shilling, which I had in the till—there was no other money in the till, in silver—I did not perceive at the time that it was bad; but my husband came in. and found it was—I had not taken any other money.
RICHARD CAMPION SCRIVENER . On the 12th of March I recollect taking the shilling from the till—there was no other there—I kept it in my pocket, and gave it to the policeman the next morning.

SARAH WHITTAKER . I am the wife of Joseph Whittaker, and live in Mark-street, St. Saviour's. On the 12th of March the prisoner came for six
pennyworth of gin—there were three men with him—the prisoner gave me a bad half-crown—I bit it, and gave it to my husband, and the prisoner was taken.
JOSEPH WHITTAKER . I received the half-crown from my wife—I gave it to the policeman.

WILLIAM POOLE (police constable M 33.) I received this shilling from Mr. Scrivener—I took the prisoner at Mr. Whittaker's, at the Noah's Ark—I received this half-crown from Mr. Whittaker—as I was taking the prisoner to the station, a female followed him—he put his hand to his mouth, and said, "I have coped you."
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months ,

1347.
ELIZABETH: NEVILLE was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

SOPHIA COOMBER . On the 6th of March the prisoner came to my father's house for half-a-pint of beer—she gave me a sixpence, which I gave to my sister—she went out, and gave it to Mr. Coton—Mr. Coton gave it to me, and I gave it to the policeman—my father would not have the prisoner detained.
OLIFF COOMBER . I received the sixpence from my sister to get change—I gave it to Mr. Coton—I went back, and Mr. Coton came soon after.
Prisoner, You came back, and the halfpence were given to me. Witness. No: they were not.
WILLIAM COTON . The last witness came to me with a sixpence for change I gave her the halfpence—I then discovered the sixpence was a bad one—I went and gave it to Sophia Coomber.

JANE CHARMAN . I am housekeeper to Mr. Garratt, in the Borough-road—on the 30th of March the prisoner came for a half-quartern loaf—she gave me a bad shilling—I said it was a very bad one, and she was constantly bringing bad money—she ran off; but was brought back—I marked the shilling, and gave it to the policeman—she had been to the shop the evening before, and brought a bad sixpence, which I gave her back.
WILLIAM SMITH (police-constable M 170.) I produce a sixpence, which I got from Sophia Coomber.
EDWARD HILL (police-constable M 135.) I produce a shilling I got from Mrs. Charman.
Prisoner's Defence. I work in a lodging-house; I had the sixpence made me a present of; the shilling was given me to fetch a half-quartern loaf.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 60.—
Confined Six Months.

1348.
THOMAS LEAVER was indicted
for stealing 3 sovereigns and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Moses Miles, from his person.

MOSES MILES . I am a costermonger. I went to lodge at the Cock at Clapham on the 1st of April—I gave four sovereigns and eighteen or nine
teen shillings to the landlord to take care of for me—he gave it me back next morning, and I began to drink, and fell asleep—the officer awoke me—my money was then gone—I am sure I had three sovereigns and some silver when I went to sleep.

JOHN TURNER . I am a wine-cooper, and live at Clapham. On the 1st of April the prosecutor came to the public-house, and about three o'clock the next, afternoon he was the worse for liquor—I saw the prisoner take three sovereigns from his pocket.

Prisoner. I took it, but not to steal it; I showed it to the company more than once or twice. Witness. He did expose the money to the company—he said, "Here is three sovereigns, if I had not taken it some one else would"—I asked him for it to give to my brother, who is the landlord, to take care of, but he would not give it—he was the worse for liquor.

HENRY GUTHRIE . I saw the prisoner take the money out of the prosecu
tor's pocket, and put it into his own pocket—he then took it out and showed it to all the company, and said there were three sovereigns, and if he did not take them some one else would—he then went out, and came back—he had two sovereigns when he was searched.

THOMAS BENT (police-constable V 95.) I took the prisoner about five o'clock that day—I found on him two sovereigns, one shilling, and two six
pences—before I searched him he told me he had none.

Prisoner. The sovereign might have been lost in going to the station, there was a great struggle between them and me. Witness. He resisted very much; I was forced to get another officer, but the money could not be lost; it was in his trowsers pocket, and I kept my eye on the pocket; his waistcoat was torn.
NOT GUILTY .

1349.
LEWIS HAMMOND and
CHARLES VAUX were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of John Durdin, about the hour of two in the night of the 29th of March, at Lambeth, and stealing 1 watch, value 3l. 10s.; 2 coats, 21. 10s.; 1 box, 10s.; 1 tea-caddy, 1l.; 2 pairs of spectacles, 5s.; and 1 bird-cage, 5s.; the goods of John Durdin: and 1 pair of scissors, 1s., the goods of Mary Durdin: also for stealing 1 tub, 5s., the goods of
Charles Decimus Crosley.

(MR. CLARKSON offered no evidence.)
NOT GUILTY .

1350.
WILLIAM GILL was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Mary Ann Healey, putting her in fear, and taking from her person, and against her will, 1 purse, value 1d.;'three half-crowns, and 1 shilling; and that he im
mediately before, at the time, and immediately after the said robbery, did feloniously beat, and strike, and use other personal violence to the said
Mary Ann Healey; and that he bad been before convicted of felony.

MARY ANN HEALEY . I am an unfortunate girl. I lived in Martin-street, at the time this happened—I now live in Union-street, Borough-road. On Friday evening, the 29th of March, I received two sovereigns from some one—in the morning of the next day I was taking a walk, and met some girls like myself—we drank together—I had my purse after I left them—part of the time it was in my bosom, and part of the time in my hand—I was out from five in the morning till six—I was at Newington-causeway at five—I was not the worse for drink till I went to the Elephant and Castle—I had my purse when I went there, which was about half
an-hour after I left home—I do not remember seeing the prisoner at all, till I saw him coming out of the station—I lost my purse—I cannot say how I lost it—the last time I had it safe was ten or twenty minutes after six in the morning—I was then at the Alfred's Head, near the Elephant and Castle—I had been home at night, and been to bed, and had got up—I am sure I had my purse then—I was not sober enough that night to remember what I was doing—I remember having it at that time, but I do not remember how long I had it after—I was taken to the station—the prisoner was there.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How much of your money did you spend that evening? A. 5s., and I paid away 10s. besides the 5s.—I went to bed about half-past twelve o'clock—I was sober then—I got up about half-past four on Saturday morning, with another person who lives in the house, to go and buy some flowers—I only drank at one place that I remember—I drank with several persons, from five till half-past six.

MARGARET WHITE . I am fourteen years old, and live with my brother, in Bennett's-buildings, Kennington-lane. On Saturday morning, the 30th of March, I saw the prosecutrix in the London-road—she was tipsy—she fell down—she got up, and crossed the road—there was a mob of persons—the prisoner and another young man were there—the prosecutrix went down a court, and the prisoner and the other followed behind her—I followed and looked on—when they got down, the prisoner asked her if she had any money—she said she had—he said, "Let me look at it"—she put her hand down her bosom, and took out her purse—she emptied the money from her purse into her hand, and the prisoner tried to snatch it from her—she held her hand tight—the other man then asked her to come in doors—she said, "No"—the

prisoner took hold of her, threw her down, and tried to take the purse from her hand—she held her hand fast, and then he hit her in the face with his fist—she was lying on the floor in the court at the time, he then dragged her by the hand along the ground, he then took the purse from her hand and ran away.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A shoe-binder—I went down this court, to take some work into my brother's shop—I saw the prosecutrix going down the court, and I went to see what was the matter—there was a man and woman down the court besides me—I screamed, and took the prosecu
trix's hand, to help her up—the other young man ran away—after the pri­soner tried to take the money away from the prosecutrix, she put the money back into her purse—it was not a dark passage—it is a little archway down the street.

GEORGE RAYMANT . upholsterer, Bond-street, Vauxhall. At nine o'clock, on the 30th of March, I was working at Nelson-place—I saw the prosecutrix, White, and the prisoner there, and another man and woman—the prosecutrix was very drunk—I heard the prisoner say, would she go home with him—she said, "No "—he asked if she had any money—she took her purse out of her bosom, and emptied the contents into her hand, and then he told her to put it into her purse—he then seized her purse with his left hand, and her throat with his right, and then he let go his right hand, and struck her in the face, and knocked her down, he dragged her and kicked her—she screamed "Murder," and he ran off with the purse in his hand—I ran, and hallooed, "Stop thief"—the prisoner said to me, "What the h—II are you making that row for?"—I said, "For knocking down this young woman"—he said, "It is ray sister"—two policemen came up and took him.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not interfere? A. I did not know what set lived down that court—that was the first morning I had been to work at that place—I had the prisoner in my charge, and collared him—I should think this lasted altogether four or five minutes—there were houses up the court, but they are of a bad sort—there were not a great many persons going by the court that morning—this happened in the centre of the court.

RICHARD JARVIS . cabinet-maker, Elizabeth-place, Between eight and nine that morning I was going to the Borough—I passed the Alfred's Head pub
lic-house—I saw the prosecutrix, and the prisoner, and two other men together, about nine o'clock—I saw the prisoner run out of Nelson-court, Raymant ran after him, and cried "Stop him"—the prisoner turned back and said it was only his sister—the policeman came up and took him into custody—as they were going to the station I saw the purse drop from the prisoner's trow
sers—I said, "There is the purse," and the constable took it up—when we go to the station I saw there were three half-crowns and 1s. in it.
Cross-examined. Q. How near were you to the prisoner when you saw the purse drop? A. About two yards.
JOHN EDGAR (police-constable L 78.) I took the prisoner—he said the prosecutrix was his sister—as we were going to the station I saw the purse in Wakefield's hand—the prisoner was sober.
ALFRED WAKEFIELD (police-constable L 171.) I saw the prisoner taken. I was following him going to the station, and saw this purse drop from him—there were three half-crowns and 1s. in it.

MARY ANN HEALEY
re-examined. This is my purse—it had three half-crowns in it, and more than that.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you swear to it? A. Yes—I have had it four
Years—the tassels and rings were lost as he pulled it out of my hand—I know it by the make of it.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace of Surrey—(read)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 6TH OF MAY.
